A star (*) denotes that prisoners have been previously in custodyâ€”two stars (**) that they have been more than once in custodyâ€”an obelisk (â€ ) that they are known to be the associates of bad charactersâ€”the figures after the name in the indictment denote the prisoner's age.
LONDON AND MIDDLESEX CASES.

div0.p:
PRESENT,â€”The Right Hon. the LORD MAYOR; Mr. Ald. SALOMONS, M.P.; Sir
FRANCIS GRAHAM MOON , Bart Ald.; Mr. RECORDER; Sir
HENRY MUGGERIDGE , Knt. Ald.; and Mr. Ald. PHILLIPS.

div1.p:
87.
JOHN CORSS SMITH (33), was indicted
for that be, having been adjudged a bankrupt, feloniously did omit to surrender himself to the Court of Bankruptcy on the day appointed.
MR. SERJEANT PARRY and MR. TINDAL ATKINSON conducted the Prosecution.

THOMAS WILLIAM MURTON . I am clerk to Mr. Stnbbs, messenger of the Court of Bankruptcyâ€”I produce the proceedings in bankruptcy in this caseâ€”the name and description is John Corss Smith, of 64, King William Street in the City of London, jewellerâ€”the petition of adjudication is dated 12th August, and the adjudication 13th Augustâ€”the petition states that the petitioning creditor is Richard Willis, 15, Clerkenwell Green, manufacturing jewellerâ€”the summons to surrender is dated 22d Augustâ€”he was required to surrender on the 2d or 26th of Septemberâ€”the 26th was the principal meeting, the first was for the choice of assigneesâ€”I was present on 26th, the prisoner did not surrenderâ€”there was a record or memorandum made, as was our custom, on the back as to his non-surrendering under the hand of the Commissioner. (This was dated 26th September, signed by Mr. Commissioner Goulburn, stating that the said Court sat at the time and place mentioned, from 11 to 3 o'clock, to receive the surrender of the said bankrupt to pass his last examination, but the said bankrupt did not surrender himself)â€”I know of my own knowledge that the Commissioner did sitâ€”I procured his signature imme
diately after; I proclaimed the bankrupt on that day; this is the London'Gazetle (produced), it is dated Friday, 23d August, lastâ€”it contains an advertisement requiring him to surrender on these datesâ€”I inserted it immediately after the adjudicationâ€”I gave one of our men named Freeman, who went in possession, a duplicate of the adjudication, and he served it by posting it upâ€”I examined the document with othersâ€”they are always in triplicate, three adjudications are always made outâ€”I made out the summonses to surrender, myself.
THOMAS FREEMAN . I am assistant to Mr. Stubbs, the messenger in this

bankruptcyâ€”I posted a paper on the shop No. 64, King William Street, on 13th Augustâ€”I had another paper, which I posted on 22d August; one I took with me, and one was sent when I went into possession; I read them myself; the first was an adjudicationâ€”I do not know where it is now, I left it there when I came away; they were posted in the shopâ€”I was in possession getting on for six weeks, during that time the bankrupt, Smith, did not come to the premisesâ€”I do not know what became of the notices; I left them in the shop when I had my dischargeâ€”I read them over.

JOHN JAMES TOZEN . I was in the employment of the prisoner for seven years and a halfâ€”I now carry on the business at 64â€”when I paid my money for the concern I tore the two papers up that were left by the last witness and threw them on the ground; I believe they were swept out into the street ultimately.
THOMAS FREEMAN (re-examined). The two papers I served were the adjudication and the summons.

RICHARD WILLIS . I carry on business alone, and am a manufacturing jeweller, and wholesale dealer in jewellery, at 15, Clerkenwell Greenâ€”I was a creditor of the prisoner; on 10th August last he owed me 456l.â€”I called at his shop on Saturday, 10th August, about 12 o'clock in the day, I think I saw himâ€”I called respecting the account that was to be drawn for, and he promised to look at the account in the course of the day and give me a cheque for it on Monday morning, with a bracelet that I had left on approbationâ€”I never saw him afterâ€”I had left the bracelet for approbation a few days before; the wholesale value of it was 6l. 10s.â€”I noticed the shop on that occasion, and I saw it afterwards on Monday, the 12thâ€”I received this letter from the prisoner on Monday morning about half-past 8, dated 11th, by post (Read: "Sir, I must request you to make me bankrupt and enforce your deed at once; I have been most shamefully robbed, but shall be ready to explain all when wanted. Pray do not fail the first thing; an execution will be in before I, and I am afraid of being arrested")â€”I received that about half-past 8 on Monday morning, by postâ€”I am the petitioning creditorâ€”I went to the shop on the Mondayâ€”I took a general survey of the two shops, both N s. 15 and 64â€”I should say from 1,000l. to 2,000l. worth of property had left the shops between Saturday and Monday; that is my judgmentâ€”the prisoner was almost always at the business at 64.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFF. Q. Had you dealt with him long? A. Yes; ever since he has been in businessâ€”I sold him the first parcel of goods; that is seven years agoâ€”he at first had merely one shop, No. 64â€”I think he was successful in that; he took the other shop, No. 15, about five years ago, about two years after he had the otherâ€”I cannot say whether No. 15 did not succeed so wellâ€”I am not in a position to form any judgmentâ€”for some considerable time he conducted himself in a very tradesman-like and business-like wayâ€”I think it is very possible I made him an advance in September, 1860â€”I have made advances to himâ€”I think it was towards the close of 1860 that I advanced him 200l.; he had that all at one timeâ€”I deducted 20l., 10 per cent.â€”he did not afterwards pay me 10l. interestâ€”I gave him a cheque for 180l.â€”I had taken the interest; he paid me nothingâ€”I received no more interest on that loan, that was done with, it was a further loan of 100l. that he paid me interest uponâ€”I received 10l. on thatâ€”I lent him altogether 300l.â€”I cannot say that the 200l. was paid off, he gave me a promissory note, promising to pay it three, four, or five mouths, and then he came aid said that his payments were running very heavy from outstanding debts he had with

other creditors; that these were coming very inconvenient to him, and would I let him have a little more money, and do away with the bills altogether and draw it on bills that would come due on separate acceptancesâ€”it was a renewal of the note, and an additional loanâ€”I took 10 per cent interest on the 100l.â€”not on the renewalâ€”I don't think it was a renewal, it was a fresh contract altogetherâ€”I got three of those ten pounds, one 20l., and one 10l., on the 300l., but a good deal of it had been paid offâ€”200l. was partly paid off and partly not; he came to me and said, "I am in a fix here"â€”there was a deed as security on the second loan, not Or the first; it was dated 8th of February, 1861â€”altogether I lent him 350l. and bad 30l. interestâ€”I fancy some that portion of the money has not run out yetâ€”I fancy some portion of it is this very debt I am now onâ€”it was to run, I think, from three to twelve or thirteen monthsâ€”notes were drawn at intervalsâ€”some of that was to run three months and over, four, five, and six until the amount of 240l. odd ran outâ€”I think this is a portion of the debt I am now petitioning forâ€”I am not quite positiveâ€”I cannot say it for a certaintyâ€”I think I have received all the money I lentâ€”I have not given up the deed to the assigneesâ€”it was given to me to cover the sum then owing to meâ€”it was for the good as well as the moneyâ€”the goods sup
plied to him since then amount to 212l.â€”from that time to the present I don't think I have received anything from himâ€”I remember his first taking the shopâ€”he put a very nice stock into itâ€”he has not furnished me, since he has been in custody, with a list of the trade debts that he has paidâ€”I have never seen anything of the kind; he has written to me from Newgate to say that he would do so, but I never went thereâ€”I do not know whether or no he has furnished it to the solicitor for the assigneesâ€”I am one of the assignees-no list has been communicated to meâ€”I have left everything in the hands of the solicitorâ€”Mr. Orans, the other' assignee, has taken the management of all that part, and I have taken this unpleasant part of itâ€”no request was made in my presence that a list should be furnishedâ€”I have never examined the booksâ€”I have looked upon it as a hopeless case altogether, and I really do not think the estate will get one halfpenny out of it, but Mr. Orans has taken all the managementâ€”the books hate been given up to the assigneesâ€”I have not investigated them at all, therefore I do not know what trade pay
ments have been madeâ€”I cannot tell whether the money raised by pledging was paid away in trade debtsâ€”Mr. Orans is the other trade assigneeâ€”I do not know of my own knowledge that he has gone through the booksâ€”I do not know whether he is hereâ€”I think you will find that everything was pawned, except the few things we took possession ofâ€”if the books weft kept properly they would show the stock received, and how, and to whom it was disposed of; if the prisoner had surrendered we should have gone all through thatâ€”when I went from the shop I went straight to the Bankruptcy Court, and then down to Sydenhamâ€”there was not a meeting of creditors called shortly afterâ€”I was present at the meeting at the Bankruptcy Court: that was allâ€”it was not proposed by some of the creditors that he should be allowed to return and make up his accounts-nobody dreamt of finding himâ€”a reward of 50l. was offered very soon after he had gone awayâ€”it was placarded about in the usual wayâ€”I don't think it was put into the papersâ€”I don't knowâ€”I, with two or three others, advised that step to be takenâ€”I had been urging it from the very first, and I wished 100l. offered instead of 50l.â€”there was no proposition made that the placard should be withdrawn, and that he should be allowed to return and make up his accountsâ€”I was not pressing him for money on the day he

went awayâ€”I did not know that there were writs out against himâ€”I do not now know that there were a great number of writs out at that timeâ€”I heard that there was an execution in the house the day I was thereâ€”I did not find a great number of writs among the papersâ€”I never examined his papersâ€”I have not examined the duplicatesâ€”I heard Mr. Wontner, the prisoner's solicitor, request at the police court that a list should be furnished of the property that I thought was deficientâ€”that has not been done by me.

MR. SERJEANT PARRY. Q. Has that list been shown to you before? A. No. I cannot say whether these figures are the prisoner'sâ€”my debt of 467l. was made up from a book debt of 212l. for goods supplied and not drawn for at all; 244 4s. 6d. for bills which he had given me and which were dishonoured, and 6l. 10s. for the bracelet which was left on approbationâ€”I fancy the whole of that amount was for goods sold and delivered; the borrowed money had been all repaid.

JOHN JAMES TOZEN (re-examined). I have been in the bankrupt's employ for seven and a half yearsâ€”I had the management of his business when he was absentâ€”I was at 64â€”he was as much at one shop as the otherâ€”he was between the two shops; in fact, he did not spend more time at 64 than 15â€”our practice, at the close of the day when the business was over, was to clear the goods out of the window and put them in an iron safeâ€”I generally had the key of the shop and the safe too; he had nothing but the shopâ€”it communicated with a passage that led upstairsâ€”when you shut the door into the passage you shut off all communication with the shopâ€”I generally used to have the key of the safeâ€”I remember the Saturday night, the last time I saw him at the shopâ€”I saw him about twenty-five minutes to sevenâ€”I went to Clapham by appointment to take home a dockâ€”I was away about two hours, when I came back the shop was closedâ€”that was about half-past eight or a quarter to nineâ€”I saw the prisoner thereâ€”it was my duty to close the shop, except when I was out of the way, and then of course he used to take charge of itâ€”I had returned from Clapham when I found the shop closedâ€”he did not say anything to meâ€”he was outside the shopâ€”I asked him for the key, and he gave it to me, after some little talkingâ€”on Monday morning I came back to the shop as usualâ€”the prisoner was not thereâ€”he did not come to his duties at all while I was thereâ€”when I opened the safe on the Monday morning I found the cases put away as if they contained goods, but they were emptyâ€”I went to the prisoner's private residence at Lewisham next dayâ€”I did not find him thereâ€”the house was emptyâ€”I had been to that house two or three times and seen the furniture thereâ€”I afterwards saw a pile of that furniture at Hollingsworth's the auctioneers, in Holborn, on the Tuesday.

Cross-examined. Q. Before the prisoner left an execution had come in, we hear? A. Yes. I believe there was an execution in the previous part of the week, before the Saturday, and Mr. Smith paid a certain amount to get the man to go outâ€”that was on the Wednesday or Thursdayâ€”I cannot say how he obtained the money to enable him to do thatâ€”I cannot remember whether there was sufficient cash in the house to pay out the executionâ€”there was not a very short balance at the time, but he was very much pressedâ€”I know he was served with a great many writs on the Friday and Saturdayâ€”none of those writs were by the tradeâ€”there was a Mr. Jenksâ€”I do not think he was pressing him very much at that timeâ€”I think he was non estâ€”he had runâ€”he kept a shop in Regent-streetâ€”the prisoner had transactions with him in accommodation billsâ€”most of the writs were about those transactionsâ€”I cannot say how long before the prisoner went away it was that Mr. Jenks took him
self

offâ€”it was some little time beforeâ€”I do not know anybody in the trade that issued a writ against himâ€”Mr. Willis was not pressing him very muchâ€”there was a 50l. bill of Mr. Willis's due that Saturday, and he did not payâ€”I was not in at the time Mr. Willis cameâ€”the prisoner had pawned a great deal of property during the last six or twelve monthsâ€”the tickets were left in the shop when the assignees took possessionâ€”that was how he kept the business going as long as he didâ€”he used to come to business about 10 o'clock, and stop very often till a late hourâ€”he attended to his business properlyâ€”I have not gone through the booksâ€”I was never at No. 15â€”we did a very good trade at 64 from time to timeâ€”it always did a very good trade from the openingâ€”it was not for some time after the taking of No. 15 that the prisoner began to get into difficultiesâ€”I think Mr. Jenks was the main cause of itâ€”I have the business at 64 now, on my own accountâ€”the as
signees have not asked me to go through the books so as to try and make out what stock is missingâ€”there have been a few book debts which I have given my aid to get inâ€”I think eight or nine books were given up relating to 64â€”they were the ordinary trade books, day book, ledger and stock book, and two banker's books. with the counterfoils of the chequesâ€”the bill book contained copies of the invoicesâ€”sometimes I kept the books, and sometimes Mr. Smithâ€”the stock book was not kept so well, because I never had the control of itâ€”the day book was kept very wellâ€”there were two separate bankers, the Unity, and the London and Westminsterâ€”it was not one for each shopâ€”Mr. Smith opened a fresh account at the Unityâ€”I do not know why there were two accountsâ€”there is no book that I know of which shows the amount of stock that was received recently before the bankrupteyâ€”there is no stock book that I know of, containing an account of what had recently come inâ€”I think the stock book contains no account for about three monthsâ€”we enter from the bill book into the stock bookâ€”the ledger would' show the stock received up to about last Christmas, but not since, I thinkâ€”the bill book contains the invoices, but Mr. Smith had not kept them for the last three or four monthsâ€”I do not think you will find any stock entered in the stock book for the last four monthsâ€”there is no book which would show the stock re
ceived during that time; only the invoices, and they were not entered upâ€”they were taken possession of by the Bankruptcy Courtâ€”all the invoices were left by the bankrupt.

MR. SERJEANT PARRY. Q. Was he in the habit of allowing his wife a sum of money a week? A. Yes, 3l. 2s. 6d.â€”I took that sum to her the last Saturday nightâ€”he kept a separate establishment of his own for the last three years, or nearly soâ€”the average takings a week at No. 64 were about 40l.â€”the profit on these articles is very enormous.
COURT. Q. Can you give any idea of the net profits per week at 64? A. From 12l. to 14l.; but about 5l. has to be taken out of that for expensesâ€”it would be about 7l. net.
MR. METOCALFE. Q. Had not his wife behaved very badly to him? A. Not at all.
COURT. Q. What was the value of the stock that you had left on the Saturday night, and which you found missing on the Monday morning? A. I should imagine between 400l. and 500l.â€”that is at No. 64.

JOHN MURTER . I was employed as a porter by the prisoner, at 15 King William-streetâ€”Mr. Predicaux acted in the shop with me as a fellow-servantâ€”I was there at the time the shop was closed, on Saturday, 10th Augustâ€”we usually closed about 8 o'clock on Saturday; we generally began to clear away a little before 8â€”it was the practice to clear the window and put the

property into the safeâ€”on that Saturday night I was sent by Mr. Smith to Billingsgate for some fish; I left him at the shop, and no one else; when I returned to the shop, the goods were all cleared out of the window and put into the safe, according to the usual customâ€”Mr. Predicaux used generally to have the key of the safe, and I had the key of the shop doorâ€”I left at half-past eight that nightâ€”I went again on Monday morning; I did not see the prisoner afterwardsâ€”when the safe was opened on the Monday, and the things came to be looked at, some of them were found to have been taken away.

Cross-examined. Q. You know that the prisoner was considerably pressed at the time he left, do you not? A. Yes, very much; there were six or seven writs out against him then, he was afraid of being arrested, it quite frightened him out of the shopâ€”I saw the placard offering a reward for his apprehension afterwardsâ€”I was at No. 15, and used occasionally to go to assist at No. 64â€”up to that time the prisoner was struggling to pay his way very muchâ€”No. 15 was a losing shop; I think he lost a great deal of money by Mr. Jenksâ€”I do dot think there was the property taken away that was stated, but I was only a porterâ€”there was very little at No. 15 that was taken away; there were some plated goods had in, that we used to put into the window for gold goodsâ€”we were very short in stockâ€”I cannot form any estimate of the amount that was taken, but I do not think it was anything like what Mr. Willis saysâ€”there was very little to take from No. 15, I do not know as to 64.

FREDERICK PREDICAUX . I was employed by the prisoner previously to 10th August, in his shop at No. 15â€”Murter was my fellow-servant thereâ€”he acted as porterâ€”on this Saturday night I left the shop it might be after 5; I left the shop as usualâ€”I left Mr. Smith thereâ€”on the Monday morning I came to the shop as usualâ€”I discovered a deficiency in the stock I do not know what it was; I cannot sayâ€”there were things not there, that I had seen there on the Saturdayâ€”I don't know the character of the things taken awayâ€”Mr. Smith never gave me any goods.
Cross-examined. Q. There was not very much to take away? A. Noâ€”I dare say there might be something like 100l. worth taken away.

LOUISA JENKS . I was the landlady of the house occupied by Mr. Smith at Lewishamâ€”I do not remember about 8th August last any furniture being removedâ€”I lived next doorâ€”I cannot tell when I saw Mr. Smith last at the house in Lowishamâ€”Mr. Lewis has not examined me for the purpose of my proofâ€”I have not given any statement to him, or told him anything before I came here; not at allâ€”I do not know Mr. Smith's solicitorâ€”I remember receiving the keys of my house by parcels deliveryâ€”that was a week after the goods were removedâ€”I remember the goods being removedâ€”I saw them removedâ€”two vans of goods were removed on Friday, the 9th of August, and the house was shut up on Saturdayâ€”no notice was given to me.

Cross-examined. Q. Your son was a jeweler? A. Yesâ€”he has gone awayâ€”I really do not know his affairs, but I believe he was indebted very considerably to the prisonerâ€”I have joined with my son in security to the prisonerâ€”I became security for him for money advancedâ€”I knew that my son was indebted to him.
MR. SERJEANT PARRY. Q. How much were you security for? A. The first security was 130l.â€”Mr. Smith joinedâ€”a portion of that was paid, and afterwards I signed a bill for Mr. Smith for 100l.
SUSAN GABBITAS I was in the service of Mr. Smith, at Lewishamâ€”I last saw him there on the Thursdayâ€”I cannot say the day of the monthâ€”I

believe he slept there on the Thursdayâ€”I did not see him on the Fridayâ€”he did not sleep there on the Thursdayâ€”Thursday was the last time I saw him thereâ€”the house was afterwards closed and shut up on the Saturdayâ€”I was paid my wages up to that time, all but eleven daysâ€”I left when the house was shut up.

ANDREW MURRELL . I am a carmanâ€”Mrs. Smith employed me in August last to remove furniture from the house at Lewisham to a Mr. Hollings-worth'sâ€”I removed all the furniture from the house, and took it to Mr. Hollingsworth'sâ€”the prisoner was there after I had unloadedâ€”he came there and saw his furniture thereâ€”he paid me himselfâ€”I did not lock up the house on the Fridayâ€”I did not see it doneâ€”I did not take the key of the house anywhereâ€”I never put my hand on any key.

WILLIAM HOLLINGSWORTH . I am a gentlemanâ€”I appear here for my sonâ€”I know most of this transactionâ€”my son knows nothing of itâ€”I do not carry on any business myselfâ€”I bought this furnitureâ€”I was at the auction rooms on the Saturday morningâ€”I gave 38l. 10s. for itâ€”I bought it of Aun Haynesâ€”I never saw Mr. Tozen, the witness, till a fortnight ago, when I saw him at the Courtâ€”I did not see the furniture broughtâ€”I never saw Mr. Smith in my life till to-day.

COURT. Q. Was your son subpoened? A. We have been both subpoenedâ€”he is not hereâ€”I was subpoened on the former occasion, and my son on thisâ€”he knows nothing of the matterâ€”Mr. Willis's clerk on Saturday stated that he considered I was the witness who would be requiredâ€”we did not both comeâ€”I am only superintending the business for my son generallyâ€”I pass my time with him mostly.

MR. SERJT. PARRY. Q. Did you advance the money yourself? A. I paid the moneyâ€”I could do so in my son's absenceâ€”I did do soâ€”I never saw the prisoner about this matter, and I understand my son never saw himâ€”I do not remember the furniture being broughtâ€”I first saw it on Saturday morning, 10th Augustâ€”I went into the auction rooms to value itâ€”I have my booksâ€”I have the receipt of Ann Haynesâ€”that is dated the 10thâ€”there was some inquiry made, and I pointed out to the gentleman who inquired, the furniture which we boughtâ€”I think I took him to the auction rooms myself, and showed it to him, but who that gentleman was I really do not knowâ€”I paid 38l. 10s. for the furniture.
MR. TOZEN (re-examined). I saw this gentleman who has been examinedâ€”he pointed out to me the furniture he had boughtâ€”I believe that to be the furniture I had seen at Lewisham.

THEODORE HALSTED FOULGER . I am a detective officer of the City policeâ€”I received a warrant from Mr. Lewis, the solicitor, on Friday, 16th August (this was a warrant by Mr. Commissioner Foublanque, dated 15th August, for the apprehension of the prisoner)â€”I afterwards received a warrant from Sir Robert Cardenâ€”at that time a reward of 50l. had been offeredâ€”in consequence of inquiries I made, I proceeded to Brusselsâ€”I met the prisoner there on the evening of 14th Octoberâ€”I had known him for some yearsâ€”I followed him into a pastrycook's shopâ€”he said, "What do you want?"â€”I said, "You ought to know"â€”he said, "You have no authority here; you are no officer here; you may do very well in England"â€”I said, "I want you to accompany me to the Vice-Consul's"â€”he said he should do no such thingâ€”I then told him I should give him into custody to the first policeman I met, and have him taken to the Hotel de Ville for travelling in a false nameâ€”I wanted to know what name he was in, and he said, "In the name of Gray"â€”I then said I should take him, and the female that

was with him, and have them both given into custodyâ€”he then consented to go with me to the Vice-Consul'sâ€”the Vice-Consul was not in, and we returned to the hotel I was stopping atâ€”on the road, the prisoner said that he had been fearfully robbed by a person of the name of Jenks; that he could explain it all if I would allow him to see Mr. Willis and Mr. Lewisâ€”he said he would return with me to Londonâ€”I went to his lodging, No. 7, Rue Verte, and in some drawers there, and on his person, I found a gold watch and chain, 5l. 11s. 3 1/2 d., a duplicate for a chain pawned in Brussels, three gold rings, a gold locket, a set of studs, a gold pin, a plated eye-glass, and a gold pencil-caseâ€”the value of the things was from 16l. to 20l.â€”we remained at his lodging all nightâ€”I afterwards took him and the female to Ostendâ€”they were passing as Mr. and Mrs. Grayâ€”I found this card on him, with "Mr. Gray" on itâ€”as we were going along I asked him where the property wasâ€”he said it was only him and Annie that knew; referring to the female that was with himâ€”when we got on board the steamer I showed the warrant to himâ€”he desired me not to read itâ€”I told him what the purport of it wasâ€”I have since seen him in Newgateâ€”I asked him about the property, and he said he had given it all upâ€”I afterwards received some property from the female that was with him on Thursday, 17th Octoberâ€”I have it hereâ€”I should think the value of it was about 200l.â€”this is a correct list of itâ€”it was contained in a parcel and two boxesâ€”it was after that property had been given up that I saw the prisoner, and that he said he had given it all upâ€”I said, "You have not given it all up; I am told there is about 2,000l. odd that you have pawned"â€”he said he could account for every farthing of itâ€”I told him he had better make out an account and give it to his solicitorâ€”Mr. Wontner, his solicitor, afterwards gave me this paper to give to Mr. Willisâ€”I handed it to Mr. Lewisâ€”(This paper contained a statement of the articles pledged by the prisoner; it amounted to upwards of 2,000l., out of which 1,658l. was stated to have been paid for trade expenses, and 400l. for household expenses).
Cross-examined. Q. Was not another paper given to you? A. No; that was the only one I received from or through the prisoner.

ROBERT ELLIS . I am manager to Mr. Harrison, a pawnbroker, of Aldersgate-street, Cityâ€”from lst February, 1861, to 2d August, 1861, the prisoner pawned jewellery, watches, &c. with us to the amount of 9l. 15s., but some of those things were renewedâ€”the pledging extends over about eighteen monthsâ€”besides that sum there was another sum of 200l.; that consisted of jewellery alsoâ€”the assignees have since redeemed that property.
Cross-examined. Q. Is the 200l. within the same dates? A. Extending over about eighteen months.

RICHARD HENRY CLOUD . I am manager to Mr. Richard Attenborough, pawnbrokerâ€”I have here a memorandum, in Mr. James Attenborough's writing, of goods pawned to the amount of 215l.â€”it is signed by the prisonerâ€”it extends from 27th April, 1861, to the 7th August, 1861â€”he has also pawned with Mr. Richard Attenborough to the extent of 129l. 10s., from 6th March to 30th Julyâ€”they were goods left for various loans.

Cross-examined. Q. Can you tell how much of that would be for renewals? A. I believe not anyâ€”when he deposited the goods, he invariably said that the money was to make paymentsâ€”I have known him for about two yearsâ€”he has pawned and redeemed a good deal of property in that timeâ€”about three parts of this was property sold.

WILLIAM FINCH . I am a miller by callingâ€”I am in the habit of advancing money occasionallyâ€”I know the prisonerâ€”during the year 1861 I advanced him money, on the deposit of goods, to the amount of 420l.

Cross-examined. Q. When was that? A. Some time in June and Julyâ€”it was in different sumsâ€”I took the goods as collateral security for bills of exchangeâ€”I charged him, I should say, above five per cent. for the time, but I could not tell exactlyâ€”it was for six weeksâ€”he brought his solicitor with himâ€”I believe Mr. Jenks introduced me to himâ€”I do not knowâ€”I could not say whether Mr. Jenks or his solicitor introduced me.

WILLIAM LEWIS . I am the solicitor to the assigneesâ€”I have examined the books together with my clerkâ€”I have examined the stock book and the invoicesâ€”I could not find all the invoicesâ€”all the books that I examined are hereâ€”I have not been able to make out an accurate account of the quantity of stock that we missedâ€”there is no account of the monies he received at the two shops in this statementâ€”I have not had any communi
cation from the prisoner as to the takings at No. 15 at any timeâ€”there was a stock in that shopâ€”it fetched 290l. at Debenham's, at a forced saleâ€”the stock at No. 64 fetched 462l. oddâ€”in addition to that, about 500l. was received as the takings from No. 64 for six weeks, and 330l. from No. 15.

p.hi: submitted that the indictment must fail, inasmuch as the statute upon which it was founded, the 12 and 13 Vic c. 106, had been repealed by 23 and 24 Vic. c 134; and the only arguable point in favour of the indictment would be, whether section 230 of the later Act continued the offence under the former Act, and prevented the repeal taking effect; for there were numerous cases which established that if an Act of Parliament was repealed, the offences contained in it fell to the ground; this same question had arisen in every Bankruptcy Act that had been passed; it arose when 6 Geo. 4 repealed 5 Geo. 4, and again, when that was repealed by 12 and 13 Vic. (Lord Brougham's Act). The learned counsel referred to the cases of Reg v. Swan and Reg v. Nairn, reported in 4 Cox's Criminal Cases, pages 108 and 115, also in the 31st vol. of the Sessions Papers, pages 227 and 279. The RECORDER inquired, whether in those Acts there was any section at all equivalent to the 230th section of the present Act. MR. METCALFE replied, that the words were almost identical with those used in 12 and 13 Vic.; if the 230th section had stated, that the offences committed under the former Act should still be offences prosecutable by law, his argument would fall to the ground, but it was confined to "proceedings pending;" the word "penalty" might be relied upon on the other side, but in the cases quoted, the word "penalty," which was used in 12 and 13 Vic, was held to refer to pecuniary penalty, and not to penalty of imprisonment or penal servitude; it could not, therefore, be contended that there was any word in the present Act which preserved the offence, or entailed upon the prisoner the possibility of a conviction of it; for though the penalties were preserved and the proceedings kept alive, the offences were not mentioned, and according to the authorities the offences must be preserved in the clearest and most express terms before a conviction could take place.

contended that it was very unlikely the Legislature should have made such an omission, and in Reg. v. Swan the repealing section of 12 and 13 Vic. was held to be most distinctly excepted; in the 230th section of the present Act the exceptions applied clearly and distinctly to civil proceedings only and to proceedings pending.

div1.p: THE RECORDER. But these proceedings were not pending at the time of the passing of the Act.

the words were most general, and he submitted must receive a general construction, and a construction even which went to fix upon a person a crime, which clearly was a crime at the time the Act passed; then would arise the question whether a warrant, duly granted upon a sworn information, was a proceeding pending, and whether there was an act done or a penalty incurred? the act done was the non-surrenderâ€”that act was done on 26th September, and the offence was then completeâ€”then was there a penalty incurred, what was the meaning of the word "penalty?" strictly speaking, perhaps, it had no legal definition, but that it was not confined to pecuniary matters was evident from the common expression of the "penalty of death," the highest punishment known to the law; it was defined by Locke, in a note to the word in Johnson's Dictionary, as a "judicial punishment" and if it was sought to restrict the meaning of the word to pecuniary penalties, some authority jor such restriction should be produced; it appeared to him that those who drew this Act of Parliament intended, by the use of large and general words, to include both civil and criminal proceedings; as the question was one of considerable im
portance, if any substantial doubt existed on the subject, it might be reserved for the Court of Criminal Appeal. MR. TINDAL ATKINSON, on the same side, urged that the word "penalty" must be taken in its largest sense, as it was still preserved, notwithstanding the offence itself was by the new Act reduced from a felony to misdemeanour.

MR. METCALFE was heard in reply: he inquired, if "penalty" applied to imprisonment and punishment for an offence committed under this Act; whether that offence was a felony or a misdemeanour? but for the reservation, the former Act was repealed; that Act made the offence a felony, by the present Act it was a misdemeanour; yet it was contended that notwithstanding the offence of felony was taken amay, the offence was continued because the penalty remained; that tended to show that if it preserved anything connected with it, it ought to have kept alive the offence eo nomire. (THE RECORDER. They are bound to prove a felony; unless it is a felony you have an acquittal.) How did they show this to be a felony? they urged that the penalty for a certain thing was kept alive; he contended that the offence was not kept alive, because the words "shall be deemed a felony" were swept away, and if the penalty remained, there was no power which preserved the right of indicting for this offence. In the Criminal Law Consolidation Act, passed contemporaneously with this, not only were the offences preserved, but the power to try and determine was all to continue as before; here there was no such thing; and supposing "penalty" meant, as was contended, the power of transporting, as well as of inflicting a fine, where was the power to indict or sentence, or what was to be the mode of getting at the parties; he submitted that all that was preserved was the penalty in respect of any matter or thing done; there were no words that were equivalent to an offence, or which showed that it was intended to keep alive criminal proceedings.

p.hi: called attention to 255th section of the old Act, to the sworn information on which the warrant was granted, and the direction of the Commissioner to prosecute.

div1.p:
THE RECORDER. "I must say that I am very much impressed by the last point put by Mr. Metealfe; I am inclined to think that the penalties are pre
served and continued, but I am doubtful whether the offence of felony is continued; and it is necessary for the prosecution to show that a felony has been committed; upon that point I entertain so much doubt that I feel disposed to reserve it, as a similar question may occur in other cases."

p.hi: Henry Henderson, jeweller, of the Strand, and James Corss, clothier, of Shoreditch, deposed to the prisoner's good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€”
JUDGMENT RESERVED .

88.
WILLIAM JONES (38)
, Stealing 1 coat, 2 waistcoats, 5 collars, 1 broach, and 1 watchchain, the property of
Sarah Collins; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .*â€”
Confined Eight Months.

89.
QUINTON WOOLNOUGH (19)
, Stealing 4 post letters, the property of Her Majesty's Post Master General; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

90.
EDWARD MCLAREN (18)
, Stealing, whilst employed in the Post-office, a post letter, containing 2 half-sovereigns, the property of
Her Majesty's Post Master General; to which he
PLEADED GUILTY .

hi.rs: He received a good character.â€”Four Years' Penal Servitude

div0.p: PRESENT.â€”Mr. Ald. CONDER, and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

div1.p:
91.
WILLIAM WILSON (16)
, Stealing 38 lbs. of lead, the property of
James Campbell and another, fixed to a building; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

92.
JOHN UNDERWOOD JOSSLYN (32), was again iudicted (See page 44)
for embezzling the sums of 2l. 3s., 3l. 9s. and 5l.; also, the sums of 5l., 2l.,4s., and 2l. 13s. 6d. which he had received on account to his master,
William Walker, upon which MR. SLEIGH for the Prosecution offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

93.
LILY YENDINNING, Unlawfully
conspiring with a man unknown to defraud
Henry Edwards. Other Counts for obtaining goods by false pretences.

HENRY EDWARDS , I am a lodging-house keeper, of 16, Grove-place, Bromptonâ€”the defendant was my lodger thereâ€”she left in October last, in my debt, and at her own consent I detained some of her propertyâ€”I have not got the papers with which I was served from the Hammersmith Police-courtâ€”a man afterwards called on me.

MR. HANDLEY. I was retained to conduct the prosecution, but was not employedâ€”I object to produce anythingâ€”I was asked to go and compromise this matter, and declinedâ€”I will answer no questions unless His Lordship orders meâ€”I am retained. in writing by the prosecutorâ€”I have been acting as clerk to Mr. Munday for the last seven yearsâ€”the prosecutor did not entrust me with any papers relating to this matter; papers were entrusted into my hands by the Magistrate of the Court, Mr. Daymond.

COURT. Q. Hive you got them in Court? A. Yes; these are themâ€”I did not abandon the prosecution, but I was repudiated because I would not go and compound it, having a written retainerâ€”he wanted to compromise the matter a week ago, and I refused to see himâ€”I said I will have nothing to say to himâ€”I obtained these summonses (produced) against Henry Edwards from the Magistrate.

COURT to HENRY EDWARDS. Q. Is this your signature. (To the retainer)? A. Yes; I did not know that it was a retainer when I signed itâ€”I received this paper (One of the summonses) before the man called on meâ€”he called in reference to the matter that this paper relates to.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON, Q. Do you mean to say that that is the paper that was served on you? A. I do not know; I think it would be wrong to answer the questionâ€”I am so disinterested in the matter that I cannot say.
COURT. Q. What did you do with the paper that was served on you? A. Mr. Handley has it.
COURT to MR. HANDLEY. Q. Is this the only one you have got? A. No; I have got othersâ€”there were twoâ€”I cannot find the one mentioned by Mr. Paynter.

COURT to HENRY EDWARDS. Q. Was a paper served on you A. Yes; and I afterwards went before the Magistrate, but I did not appear to the summonsâ€”this other paper (produced) was served on me by the police, on the Wednesday morning. (MR. RIBTON objected to this being ready it not being signed by the Magistrate; it commenced, "The defendant is ordered to deliver up," which might be written by anybody.)

MR. TAYLOR. Q. You say that you received this paper on the Wednesday morning when the man came to you? A. The man came to me on the Tuesday evening, and the defendant was then outside the door on the opposite side of the wayâ€”it was brought by the police-constable Fletcherâ€”I am quite sure that this is the summons he brought.
MR. RIBTON. Q. Will you swear that is the identical paper that was served on you? A. No; how can I swear if? I never looked at it.
COURT. Q. You have just said that it was served on you by Fletcher? A. This is the summons that was served on meâ€”this is, I believe, the paper that I gave to Handley.
MR. RIBTON. Q. Will you swear it? A. No, I will not.
MR. HANDLEY. It is not the one you gave me.

GEORGE FLETCHER . I am warrant officer to the Hammersmith Police-courtâ€”I heard the defendant apply to the Magistrate for a summons against Mr. Edwards for detaining her boxesâ€”the information was taken down afterwardsâ€”her application was granted, a summons was issued, and I served a paper on Mr. Edwards immediately after that application, which I copied from this, the original summonsâ€”I served that copyâ€”I served it upon a female on the premisesâ€”I saw the defendant attend before the Magistrate on 21st Octoberâ€”Mr. Edwards was not presentâ€”I heard her admit that she owed Mr. Edwards 3l. 12s., and the Magistrate ordered the goods to be delivered up upon payment of 3l. 12s.â€”this is what I usually sign when an order is made by the Magistrateâ€”I have seen no order besides this.
COURT. Q. What you call making an order is the Magistrate saying that the goods are to be delivered up? A. Yes.

MR. TAYLOR. Q. Then do you get that minute? A. Yes; from the clerk, I saw him write itâ€”I received this from Mr. Edwards. (Upon MR. TAYLOR proposing to read the minute, MR. RIBTON objected, it being drawn up by the clerk only).

COURT. Q. Was this written in the prisoner's presence? A. I can hardly say; but she was told that she was to receive her boxes upon payment of 3l. 12s. (MR. RIBTON contended that it was necessary to prove the summons first, and then an actual order for the payment of 3l. 12s.)

MR. TAYLOR to MR. HANDLET. Q. Did you receive a paper from Mr. Edwards? A. The only paper I received from him was a minute of that order, I never had a copy of the summons, and I told Mr. Lewis so when he subpoened me to produce a summons by Mr. Ingham, or Mr. Daymond, and I found it was Mr. Paynter's summons that I had. (THE COURT suggested that it was possible that the order never came to Mr. Edwards hands as it was not served upon him personally. MR. TAYLOR contended that as the order was made in the. Defendant's presence for the delivery of the goods, there was enough to support the Third Count. THE COURT considered that it was necessary to prove that the summons was served upon Mr. Edwards. MR. RIBTON further contended that it would be necessary to call all the Magistrates to prove that they gave no order for the delivery of the goods upon the payment of 2l., as the name of any Magistrate had not been mentioned. THE COURT suggested that the Magistrate's clerk ought to be called.)

WILLIAM HENRY ANDREW . I am clerk to the Magistrates at Hammer
smith police-courtâ€”I remember the defendant applying to the Magistrate relative to her clothesâ€”I was present on 21st October when the summons came on to be heardâ€”the defendant stated her case, and I made a memo
randum of what she said; it is very short in consequence of the non-appearance of the defendantâ€”Reading: "Henry Edwards, summons for detaining; George Fletcher served summons on 17th, at defendant's house; Lily Vendinning swornâ€”I live at the defendant's house, 16, George-place, Bromptonâ€”I left on Tuesday lastâ€”he detained three trunks of wearing apparelâ€”I demanded them and was refusedâ€”I owe him 3l. 12s."â€”Order to give up goods upon payment of 3l. 12s. and costs"â€”the defendant made no other application about her goods to the Magistrateâ€”this minute is in my writingâ€”I describe it as a minute of the order under Jarvis's Actâ€”all the statute requires is for that to be served on the defendant.
HENRY EDWARDS (re-examined). Q. When a man accompanied by the prisoner called on you on Tuesday evening what took place, did you see the things put into the cab? A. Certainly not.
MR. RIBTON. Q. Was the prisoner near enough to hear what was said? A. I think not.

p.hi: considered that this evidence was not enough to make the defendant responsible for what the man said.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

94.
JAMES FINNETT (20)
, Stealing 1 pair of trousers, value 10s., the property of
James Butcher; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

95.
MATTHEW MILLERM (18)
, Embezzling the sums of 1l., 15s. 11d., 2l. 0s. 10d., and 6l. 3s. 0d., the property of
James Lowden, his master. to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

96.
WILLIAM GEORGE (24)
, Stealing I watch, value 50s., the property of
Alfred Cray, from his person, having been before convicted; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald. SALOMONS, Mr. RECORDER, Mr. Ald. PHILLIPS., and Mr. Ald. CONDER.

div1.p:
97.
JOHN HART (21),
JAMES WILLIAMSalias
STEWART (27), and
HENRY EVANS (28)
, Feloniously breaking and entering the ware-house of
John Innes and another, and stealing therein 6 tons of canvas, value 300l., and 1 cask and 1,680 lbs. of sugar, value 60l., their property; Second count, Feloniously receiving the same.

JOHN INNES . I am in partnership with my brother, James Innes, carrying on business at 210, High Street, Wapping, as warehouse-keepersâ€”on the 1st November I went into the warehouse in Cinnamon-street, Wappingâ€”I found that a window on the first floor, about sixteen feet from the ground, had been openedâ€”I found marks on the window-sill as if ropes had cut into itâ€”there was the mark of a rope clearly as if something had been loweredâ€”I also found ropes on the floor with running nooses in themâ€”I found an empty hogshead on the floor which had previously been filled with sugarâ€”I cannot say how shortly before I had seen itâ€”I do not examine all the packages, they are so numerousâ€”it ought to have contained sugarâ€”I found the wrappers of three bales of canvas on the top floorâ€”I missed six bales of canvasâ€”nearly all the ropes which had bound the bales were left on the floorâ€”the ropes that were made into the nooses were a portion of themâ€”with those ropes they could lower those bales out of the window into a court below quite easily, they were just the length to reach to the groundâ€”the weight of the canvas I missed was about six tons, and the sugar about fifteen cwt.â€”the value of the canvas was I believe from 200l. to 225l., and the sugar about 30l.â€”I drew the attention of the police to this matterâ€”I have since seen the canvas produced to me by Stimson, and this is a part of it (produced)â€”they are all marked, and correspond exactly with the way in which my canvas was markedâ€”it does not belong to usâ€”we are merely warehouse-keepersâ€”it corresponds exactly in every respect with the canvas I missedâ€”the sugar has not been foundâ€”I have had between five and six bales of canvas produced to meâ€”some of it has been made up into bagsâ€”reckoning what is made up into bags, there is more than five and less than six balesâ€”this roll does not represent a whole bale, only about a twenty-fourth part of oneâ€”there are twenty-four of these in each baleâ€”ninety-six rolls have been discovered in their original stateâ€”there are a certain number which have had the mark cut offâ€”we have discovered ninety-six of these rolls, and I think twenty-four of these other rolls; they have just been cut openâ€”that is allâ€”I think the canvas came from the manufacturers at Dundee, and the mark that I speak of is their mark, and comes up on the canvasâ€”it is the length and breadth of the canvas.

THOMAS HENRT RYMER . I am clerk to Messrs. Innes, and live at 3, Portland Villas, Clapham-roadâ€”on 24th October I was in the Cinnamon-street warehouseâ€”it was at that time safeâ€”the bales of canvas were in the ware-house and the sugar in the hogsheadâ€”I locked the door and kept the keyâ€”as far as I am aware of there was no other key to the warehouseâ€”I kept the key till I gave it to Mr. Innes on 1st Novemberâ€”in consequence of what he told me I went to the warehouse, and I then found it in the state that he has representedâ€”the hogshead that he has spoken of as being then empty, I had previously seen filled with sugarâ€”it was apparently full when I was there on 24th October.

JOHN LOOKER . I am a carman, at 3, Eliza-terrace, Limehouseâ€”I do not let vans out, I go with them myself when anybody hires meâ€”on Thursday, 29th October, I saw Mr. Stewart (Williams) at half-past 5 in the morning,

in my stableâ€”I was in my stable doing up my horseâ€”he asked me whether I could do a job for himâ€”I said, "Yes," and I went with him to do the jobâ€”he said I was to be at the firm at 6 o'clockâ€”I said I could be there at that timeâ€”he jumped into the van and rode with meâ€”he said it was to move some canvasâ€”he did not say why he wanted to move itâ€”I went with him with the van to the firmâ€”I did not know what firm he meantâ€”I did not know which way to go to it without he went with meâ€”he took me to a wood wharfâ€”I backed into a side place, Clement-street, I thinkâ€”I did not know the name of the placeâ€”he went with me to show meâ€”I am now speaking of the place where I subsequently took the canvas fromâ€”I have been there since with Sergeant Stimsonâ€”I know now whose warehouse it isâ€”they tell me it is this gentleman's (Mr. Innes)â€”it is in innamon-streetâ€”Stewart jumped out there, and a man came out who I thought was the foremanâ€”he said he was the foremanâ€”he said, "You are all behind"â€”I said, "No, I am here at 6 o'clock"â€”he then showed me where to back the van inâ€”I stood at my horses's headâ€”there was not room for me to get either one side or the other when my van was backed inâ€”they were about five minutes loading itâ€”we packed it in the wood yard, not in the warehouse; it was alongside of itâ€”they loaded me up in about five minutes with this canvas; it was in the shape of theseâ€”I had one horseâ€”I should think there was a ton of canvas; nothing else besides canvasâ€”I should know the man who said he was the foreman if I were to see himâ€”I have not seen him sinceâ€”I then drew the van outside and saw Stewartâ€”he said, "It is going all in your road home, go on"â€”I went as far as my own houseâ€”I did not see Stewart, so I put the nose-bag on my horse and left it in the road, and had my breakfast; and then, not seeing Stewart, I drew it for safety into my brother's yard, and left my little boy to mind it, and took my horse out and went to brick cartingâ€”the van stood there one day and a half with the load on itâ€”Stewart came and sent my little boy home, the same morningâ€”I was not there thenâ€”I saw no one at all during that day and a half about itâ€”I was told something by the little boy at the end of the day and a half, and I called and saw Stewart, and told him I must have the vanâ€”I saw him at my own house; be cameâ€”I told him I wanted the vanâ€”he said he had not got room at home the place was so full, and asked whether I knew of a shed where he could take it to work up into sacksâ€”I sent him to my brother's who has a blacksmith's shop, and he told him it would take nearly a week or a fortnight to clear it out, or he would let it to himâ€”I did not go with him to my brother thenâ€”he asked me if I would allow him to put it on my pig-stiesâ€”it was put there by Stewart and the foreman the same morningâ€”Stewart said he had an order for so many sacks; that was the reason he wanted some place to make it upâ€”it remained there that afternoon, andhe took an empty room that I had, and he brought it in and cut it up into bags, and the women came to work the next day for him, and worked it upâ€”the day it was put into the shed was a day and a half after the day I took it from the ware-houseâ€”it stood over at my brother's a day and a half, and at 2 o'clock on that day they unloaded it in front of my shed, in the road, and on the same evening put it from the shed into the roomâ€”Stewart and his man did that, and on 31st the women began to work it up into bagsâ€”there, was also a little man there; I do not know who he wasâ€”I have never seen him sinceâ€”I do not see him nowâ€”I saw ne'er a one of these men there besides Stewartâ€”I have seen Hart at my place at work with the bags, folding them upâ€”I first saw him there the next day, I think; at the some time the women came; I mean the day after it was put into the roomâ€”he came with the

women, and he came that same night to help carry them out of the shed into my room with Mr. Stewartâ€”he used to come now and then, according as Stewart ordered him to do anythingâ€”I was not always at home, and cannot say how often he was thereâ€”I think this went on about a week before the police cameâ€”I dare say Hart might have been there four or five or six times during that weekâ€”I saw Stewart there pretty well every day.
Cross-examined by MR. ORRIDGE (for Hart). Q. You say Stewart directed the women, and I suppose, as far as you saw, he directed Hart also? A. Yes, Hart was employed by Stewart.

Cross-examined by ME. RIBTON (for Stewart). Q. Did you think that all this was right and proper? A. I did not at last, not for about two days before it was found outâ€”when I was asked to go and fetch the canvas I thought it was all right and correctâ€”I was in the yard just as the clock struck 6â€”it was not dark then, it was getting daylightâ€”I had known Stewart beforeâ€”I knew where he livedâ€”I did not go to his house with the van, because it was not my roadâ€”he told me to go on towards my own houseâ€”I made sure he was behind meâ€”he did not order me to take them to his houseâ€”he did not order me to take them to my brother's, or' to my own houseâ€”he said he would overtake me, or something of that sortâ€”I left my little boy with the van while I went and had my breakfastâ€”I have never been charged with any offenceâ€”I was never charged with stealing some stores on any occasionâ€”there was nothing about a private still found working at my premises; I swear that; there was a suspicion six years ago, but there was no private still in my placeâ€”they came, and I asked them to come in and look at the placeâ€”I do not know what they came forâ€”the officer asked whether there was such a thing as a private still there, and I said, "Walk in and look"â€”it had not been removed a short time before his arrivalâ€”I swear thatâ€”there were two men assisting to load this vanâ€”Stewart was one, and the tall man the otherâ€”there were three women assisting to make the canvas into sacks while Stewart was thereâ€”I do not know whether any of them are hereâ€”they were not before the Magistrate; they would not come upâ€”my wife went for them and they would not comeâ€”I told the police where they were to be found, and my wife went with the police and showed themâ€”I am sure this occurred on 29thâ€”I never called at Mr. Stewart's house on 29th or 30thâ€”I have never called there for two or three yearsâ€”I saw him on 29thâ€”I believe that was the dayâ€”I am no scholarâ€”I do not know Stewart's cousin (Raynham Stewart was here called in)â€”I do not know that manâ€”I never saw him before in my lifeâ€”Stewart did not say to me in that man's presence, "I am going out and shall not be long," and ask that man to remain till be came back, nor did we leave together; it is falseâ€”I have never called at Stewart's this two years.

Q. Did you and Stewart return in about an hour; and did you say in that man's presence to Stewart, "What can you do with it, Stewart?" A. I never saw that man, so I could not say so in his presenceâ€”I first gave information about this, I think, a week afterwardsâ€”I first began to think there was something wrong about it on the Fridayâ€”the 29th was on the Tuesdayâ€”I think I first gave the information on the Mondayâ€”on the Friday, Stewart told me he had a bill in his pocket, and he could prove that he had bought it and paid for itâ€”that was in my own house in the presence of my wife, and another lady and her husbandâ€”Mrs. Collins was the other lady; she is hereâ€”I thought there was something wrong about it, because two gentlemen knocked at my house, and Hart and Stewart were indoors at the time, and when I came to look for them they were goneâ€”in my opinion

they thought they were two officers come for themâ€”they were not two officersâ€”I did not think they were, but I think Stewart did; and when he came back again at night I asked him if the stuff was all right, and then it was he said, "Yes; and I have got a bill in my pocket to prove I bought and paid for it"â€”he pulled a piece of paper out of his pocket, whether it was a bill or not I cannot sayâ€”I did not ask to look at itâ€”I cannot read or writeâ€”I was satisfied about the bill, and that was the reason I did not give information thenâ€”the policemen came on the Saturday, and I gave them all the information that I could, on the Monday; I did not see them on the Saturdayâ€”I gave the information to Stimsonâ€”I saw him at my own house at 8 in the morningâ€”I stopped at home on purpose, as my wife bad told him I would meet him there.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON (for Evans). Q. You say you believe it was on the 29th; are you quite sure it was on the Tuesday? A. I am no scholarâ€”it was on the Tuesday morning that I went to fetch it, but I am not sure of the day of the month.
MR. ORRIDGE. Q. Did Hart assist in making the bags? A. No; one morning when I came down he was holding the stuff while his master was cutting it, and the women afterwards made it up.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Did you take the constables and show them where you brought the stuff from? A. I did; I went with them every where they asked me to go.

WILLIAM PEGLXY . I live at 9, Bird Cage-walk, Hackney-road, and am a line and twine makerâ€”I know Evansâ€”I have been in the habit of buying a great deal of hemp from himâ€”on Thursday, the last day in October, he come to meâ€”I was a-bed when he came, and when I got up he showed me a small bit of canvas as wide as my handâ€”he said would I oblige him by going up to my shop to know' the value of that canvasâ€”I said I did not mindâ€”we then went together in his horse and cart to Mr. Unite's at Paddington, in St. Alban's-place, Edgeware-roadâ€”I went in and saw Mr. Duthoitâ€”Evans was with meâ€”I asked Mr. Duthoit what the canvas was worth that Evans had brought meâ€”after I had ascertained the value from him I and Evans came home together; next morning Evans came to meâ€”he brought the canvas, and asked me if I would let him put it into my warehouseâ€”there was a van load of itâ€”I do not know whose van it wasâ€”I did not go and look at the name on itâ€”he asked me to let him put it into my warehouse for a few daysâ€”I called off two of my men and told them to go and help the carman to get the canvas inâ€”I was indoors, but I came oat and assisted as well as Evansâ€”we all assisted in taking it inâ€”it remained there a week, till the following Thursday, and then Evans took it away, and I saw no more of itâ€”the canvas was in rolls when it was brought to me, the same as thisâ€”I did not notice any mark on itâ€”I said there were seventy or eighty rollsâ€”I should think there was all that; of course I did not count them, and I cannot sayâ€”there was a great quantity.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. How long have you known Evans? A. Between three and four yearsâ€”he is a hemp-dresserâ€”he prepares the hemp for as to spinâ€”I have had considerable dealings with himâ€”I have known him also as a particular friendâ€”he was always a very hard-working manâ€”we both worked together journey workâ€”he has always borne a very good characterâ€”when he brought the piece of canvas to me, I took it to Mr. Uniteâ€”a person of the name of Shepherd came down that same evening in his horse and cartâ€”he was a stout manâ€”he was a person who answered to the name of Shepherdâ€”he came the same evening that

went up to Unite'sâ€”when I speak of Thursday, it was 31st Octoberâ€”Evans told me that that was the gentleman that belonged to the canvasâ€”he was a respectable manâ€”I had never known him beforeâ€”he appeared to act as the owner of the canvasâ€”I conducted a negociation with Shepherd for the purchaseâ€”I told him I could sell fifty bolts, but I should expect a farthing a yard commission for my troubleâ€”I saw Shepherd twice; he was with Evans both times, and on both occasions the goods were treated as Shepherd'sâ€”the goods were put into a regular warehouseâ€”I am a rope line and twine makerâ€”I have no shop.

MR. RIBTON to JOHN LOOKER. Q. Did you superintend the making up of the bags? A. Never; I had my own mason's work to doâ€”I did not give any direction to a person of the name of Mary Donovanâ€”I do not know any of them by nameâ€”(Mary Donovan was here called in)â€”that was one of the women at workâ€”I gave no direction to her in the leastâ€”she did not put a piece of the canvas up against the window, nor did I take it down and say I did not wish it to be seen.

JOHN STIMSON (Police-sergeant, K 21). On 5th November, I went to Stewart's mother's house in Broad-street, Ratcliffe, in company with police-constable Smithâ€”we found Stewart and Hart thereâ€”I asked them if they had had any canvas offered, telling them what sort it was, and I produced a sample which I had with meâ€”I have the sample hereâ€”I asked if they had any canvas of that description offered; Stewart said no, they had notâ€”I told them that a warehouse at Wapping had been broken into, and nine biles of canvas stolen there from, and they would be offered either in rolls or in boltsâ€”this is what they call a bolt or roll; some people call them one thing and some anotherâ€”he said no he had not had them brought there; they would not bring them there, they would take it farther a-fieldâ€”we then leftâ€”it is a marine-store dealer's shop; that was the reason I made inquiriesâ€”I went to all the marine-store dealers about the neighbourhoodâ€”on Friday, 8th November, I was in Roadswell-street, Stepneyâ€”I saw Stewart there in a van, and two other menâ€”I do not know who they were; I am not confidentâ€”I was then in plain clothesâ€”Stewart looked toward where I was standing, the van was coming towards the right, and he made a signal to the man driving to go the other way, towards the leftâ€”I was coming over a bridge, one of the turnings inclined to the right, and the other to the leftâ€”I then commenced watching about there, and afterwards went to No. 3, Roadswell-road, that is Looker'sâ€”I did not see any more of Stewart then, he went awayâ€”I went to Looker's house the next morningâ€”I there found 24 bolts of canvas and 165 large sacks, and 400 small sacksâ€”I produce one of each, all the bolts had the marks removed from themâ€”Luker gave me information; he showed me where he had taken the van to, and the timber yard where he had backed the van inâ€”it was just underneath the window that had been broken open in Mr. lnnes' warehouse; he gave me every information and every facilityâ€”on Saturday, the 16th, I went to Evans, 7, Green street, Bethual-greenâ€”I saw himâ€”he is a hemp dresser and dealerâ€”he had some hemp in his shedâ€”I went to him as a hemp dresser; he did not know who I wasâ€”I asked him if he had had any canvas offered him for saleâ€”he said no, he had notâ€”I said, "Is your name Evans?"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”I said, "Are you quite sure you have had none offered, or have you been offering any?"â€”he said, no, he had notâ€”I then took him to the witness Pegley's, in Bird-cage-walkâ€”I then said, "Step inside"â€”I put him in first, and the first words he said were "Did I bring any canvas here"â€”(I had previously asked him if he had taken any there and he said he had not)â€”Pegley

replied, "Evans, you did; why don't you tell this man the whole truth about it?"â€”he said he did not know anything about itâ€”I then asked him if he had not been with Pegley to Mr. Unite's at Paddington, offering it for saleâ€”he said he had notâ€”I said "You went there in your pony and cart"â€”he said no, he had notâ€”I then took him to the station, and there he denied it again, and said he knew nothing about itâ€”on the Monday following, when he went over to the police court, he said he wished he had told the whole truth about it; that a man of the name of Shepherd had brought it to him, and he had taken it to Pegley's.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. I believe when he was denying it and telling what was clearly a lie, Pegley said to him, "Why don't you tell the whole truth, no harm can come to you?" A. Yes; he didâ€”in spite of that he went on stating that he had nothing to do with the canvasâ€”he was crying the next day.

REBECCA LOOKER . I am the wife of John Lookerâ€”I know Stewartâ€”on 30th October, be came to my house and asked me if I would let him a roomâ€”I said, "Yes"â€”I asked him what it was forâ€”he said he had bought a quantity of canvas and wanted it worked up into bags; if I would let him a room at half-a-crown a week he would pay meâ€”I let him the roomâ€”the canvas was brought from the pig-sty into that room the previons night, and the next morning I saw Stewart and Hart at half-past 5â€”one woman came that day, and the next morning three womenâ€”Stewart and Hart worked with themâ€”I did not know what the stuff was, but they were making it up into bage.

Cross-examined by MR. ORRIDGE. Q. Hart worked in the room with the women, did he? A. Occasionally; not with the women, he assisted Mr. Stewart in cutting up for the womenâ€”the women did the sewing part, making the bagsâ€”I do not know who the women areâ€”I know one, by a gentleman sending two policemen with me down a court, and I pointed two of the women out to one of the officersâ€”they were quite strangers to me, and so was Hart, I never saw him beforeâ€”I had known Stewart beforeâ€”they all came to work at the canvas.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Was it on Wednesday that you saw Stewart for the first time? A. Wednesday eveningâ€”he came after I came home from my day's workâ€”I saw nothing of them on the Tuesdayâ€”I did not see my husband go out on Tuesday morningâ€”he went out at half-past 5â€”he got up very early, he always does; I cannot tell what timeâ€”it was not earlier than 4â€”I cannot tell you whether it was 5, I do not knowâ€”it was not in the middle if the nightâ€”I did not see Stewart the remainder of Tuesdayâ€”I first saw him on the Wednesday evening after I came home from my milk walkâ€”I first saw my husband on Tuesday at breakfastâ€”no, he had had breakfast before I got homeâ€”I do not remember whether he was in the house when I arrived at homeâ€”I did not see him till dinner timeâ€”he told me that he had put the van into his brother's yard, for he wanted the horse to go to work withâ€”I do not know whether he was out that afternoonâ€”I attended to my milk business all the afternoonâ€”I am out all the afternoonâ€”I never-knew there to be a private still at work at our place in my lifeâ€”I do not know what such a thing isâ€”there was a gentleman came; I do not know whether he was an excise officer or what, but he came and examined two empty rooms that my lodgers had leftâ€”I had no water on for eight years, so there could be no still; whether he searched or not I cannot say.
WILLIAM LOOKER . I live at 13, Brighton-terrace, Roadswell-road, and

am brother of John Lookerâ€”I am a smith and boiler makerâ€”on a Tuesday I saw the van in my yard, but I did not take notice of the day of the monthâ€”it was not my brother's vanâ€”the name of Price was on the vanâ€”canvas was in the van, in rolls, from what I could see of itâ€”I did not take a deal of notice of itâ€”I saw Stewart that same dayâ€”I never knew him beforeâ€”I was a bed at the timeâ€”it was between 10 and 11 in the morning; I was not very wellâ€”my little boy came in and said something to meâ€”Stewart came to my place with my brother, who said he had been drawing a load of goods for this gentleman, and had only put it into the yard till 4 o'clockâ€”I asked him what business he had to put it in the yard without my consentâ€”he laid he thought he could take the liberty of putting it in, and Stewart and he went away togetherâ€”Stewart did not say anything about it thenâ€”I saw him the next afternoonâ€”he wanted a place to put some canvas; it was gone out of my premises thenâ€”he wanted me to let him my shedâ€”I told him I would, but could not do so for a week or fort-nightâ€”I have got a smith's shop, and also let a place out where carts standâ€”he then went awayâ€”the van had been taken away before thatâ€”on the following Monday evening I saw him againâ€”he then asked me whether I could let him a room, as I had got two rooms to letâ€”he said he wanted it' to put the canvas in just for a month or six weeks, or two months; he would pay me a month's depositâ€”I had two rooms, but I told him I could not say I could let him the room; I would converse with my wife upon it, and let him knowâ€”I did not let itâ€”my wife said she was going to make a best room of the upstairs room, and a bed-room of the back room.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Was any one present when this con
versation took place? A. Yes; but no one who is hereâ€”there was a woman of the name of Wiggins, a beer-shop keeperâ€”she is not hereâ€”I suppose she heard this conversation.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Which conversation? A. Regarding Stewart's ask
ing me for the roomâ€”that was on the Monday.

ROBERT SMITH (Policeman, K 253). On Sunday afternoon, 17th Novem
ber, I was passing the cell in the police-station where Evans wasâ€”he asked me what it was a clockâ€”I told him it was about 3, he commenced cryingâ€”and said, "I wish I had told you the truth, as Pegley did; I should not have been here any more than he has"â€”he said, "I will tell you the truth, and where it was"â€”he told me that he carted the ninety-six rolls of canvas from Pegley's, in Bird-cage-walk, to Ernest-street, White Horse-lane, Stepney, where he put it into a shedâ€”he said that a man of the name of Shepherd had brought two loads to his house in Green-street; he housed one, and one he took to Pegley's, and that was the one he took to a man named Appleton, in Ernest-streetâ€”he said he housed one in his own place, and a man he called Little Jemmy had taken that away, a few rolls at a time, in a pony and cartâ€”I do not know who Little Jemmy isâ€”I then went with Stimson to Ernest-street, and knocked at Appleton's doorâ€”I saw a shed there, with a lock on it, and through a crevice, against the shed, I saw one of the rolls of canvasâ€”I drew the staple, and found the canvas; ninety-six rolls of this description; this is one of the rollsâ€”we took possession of them, and they are part of what has been produced to-day.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. When was the first examination before the Magistrate? A. Stewart was first examinedâ€”he had been examined at that timeâ€”Evans was examined on the 18th, I think, the day after this conversationâ€”he appeared to be in great distress at the time, and considerably excited.

JOHN APPLETON . I live at 1, Ernest street, Stepney, and am a rope and twine makerâ€”I have known Evans for some timeâ€”the constable took away a qnantity of canvas from the shed at my placeâ€”Evans brought it thereâ€”I do not know whenâ€”it was about from the 1st to the 9th or 10th Nove
mber; on one of the days between the 1st and the 9th; I cannot say whichâ€”I did not see Shepherd at all at my placeâ€”I saw him and another man in a public-house, and had some conver-sationâ€”that was before the stuff came to my placeâ€”I have never, to my knowledge, seen the person that was with Shepherd with Evansâ€”I went to Evans' house, and had some conversation with him about the canvasâ€”I asked him how Shepherd came to know where I livedâ€”this was after the constable had been; after I had heard the evidence at the Thames-policeâ€”he said that Shepherd told him that he had taken the shed of me, and they brought the canvas there.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Had you been in the habit of seeing Shepherd before this? A. Once or twiceâ€”he was a very decent-looking personâ€”I am not well known about the neighbourhood where I saw themâ€”I saw him at the public-houseâ€”Evans did not say that he had not told Shepherd to hire my place; he never said anything of the kind to meâ€”he said that Shepherd had told him he had got my address elsewhereâ€”he said, "Shepherd told me he had taken the place of you, and we took the canvas there"â€”I do not recollect his saying that Shepherd had told him that he had learnt from somebody else about my shed.

MARK STRICKITT . I live at Blundell-street, Caledonian-road, and am a rope makerâ€”on 3d November, Evans and his wife came to me in a pony cartâ€”Evans showed me a sample of sacking; I call it canvas; it was this sort of canvasâ€”he said he had some to sell for a party, and offered it to me at 3 1/2 d. a yardâ€”I did not buy itâ€”it was Sunday morningâ€”he did not say where he had it, or who the party was.
Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. He mentioned no name? A. No.
JOHN INNES (re-examined). There would be three or four van loads of the property I lostâ€”I identify that which came from Appleton's.

MR. RIBTON. Q. I understand the quantity found at this place is much less than what you lost? A. Yesâ€”we know it by the marks of the length and breadth-others might have exactly the sameâ€”we lost a quantity of sugar alsoâ€”I was at the warehouse on 1st November; not on the 30th or 31stâ€”it was not open.

COURT. Q. There is not a great quantity missing, is there? A. There are missing, I suppose, about seventy or eighty more rollsâ€”I do not know the value of this a yard; I believe about 4d. or 4 1/2 d.

CATHERINE COLLINS . I am a married womanâ€”my husband lives at 18, St Phillips'-terrace, St. Dunstan's-road, Stepneyâ€”I was present at Mr. Looker's one Thursday eveningâ€”I saw Stewart come in that eveningâ€”I was there for a little whileâ€”I forget the monthâ€”it was about six weeks ago I should think, I did not take particular noticeâ€”I heard him say that the goods were bought and paid for, and he had got the receipt in his pocket to prove itâ€”I did not hear what was said in answer to itâ€”I only heard thnee words.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. What time was it? A. I should think about 9 o'clock in the eveningâ€”my husband was with me at the timeâ€”Mrs. Looker was also present, and Mr. Stewartâ€”they were the only four in the roomâ€”Mr. Looker was not thereâ€”my husband is not hereâ€”I was not examined before the Magistrateâ€”it was not in answer to any questions 1 heard that he made that remarkâ€”I am no relation of Mr. Looker, nor of

Mrs. Lookerâ€”I am not particularly a friend of theirs, nor in the habit of visiting them very often; perhaps once in a mouth or two, or it may be more than thatâ€”I have known them about two yearsâ€”my husband is a permanent man at St. Katharine's docksâ€”he goes round to Looker's at times, because he keeps pigs the same as Mr. Looker, and he goes round to get stuff for themâ€”my husband does not keep a vanâ€”he was at Mr. Looker's perhaps about once a week or once a fortnight, just calling when passingâ€”I merely called in that evening to see how Mrs. Looker and her family were, as I passedâ€”I and my husband called in.

COURT to WILLIAM PEGLEY. Q. What day was it that you went with Evans to Unite's and showed them the sample? A. On Thursday, the 31stâ€”I asked 4d. a yard for it, and he said, "Well, then, they want too much for it, Pegley; duty has risen lately; sometime ago we could buy it for 3d., but I believe that we could buy it in Scotland for 3d., but stop a minute, I will go and look in the book," and he went and looked in the book and said, "Six weeks ago we were buying it at 3d."â€”he said he would take fifty bales of me at threepence a yard if I could get anything out of it"â€”I told Evans, and then Evans brought Shepherd down to me in the evening.

WILLIAM STEWART . I live at 145, Rotherhithe-street, and am a labourer in the employment of Mr. Mullens of Old Gravel-laneâ€”I recollect the 28th Octoberâ€”it was my birthdayâ€”I saw my brother, the prisoner, on that dayâ€”he came to tea and supper with meâ€”he came just before 6â€”it might have been 6â€”I have been in the habit of celebrating that anniversaryâ€”I keep that day not every year, but sometimesâ€”I did it on this occasionâ€”my cousin, Rayuham Stewart, came with him, and remained till about half-past 11â€”my cousin leftâ€”the prisoner did not leave, he remained till about 9 in the morningâ€”he had had a little drop to drink the same as we hadâ€”I proposed he should sleep there, and made him up a bed and he slept thereâ€”I saw him go to bedâ€”I got up next morning about 6 or a little before; it might be a quarter to 6â€”he slept in the next room to meâ€”I saw him before he leftâ€”I went into his room and had some conversation with himâ€”I saw him in bed, and left him in bedâ€”I returned to my breakfast at 8 o'clock, and he was there thenâ€”he breakfasted with meâ€”I do not know when he leftâ€”I left him there at half-past 8 o'clock.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. How old are you? A. Thirtyâ€”I have no register of my brother's birthâ€”I, my wife, my cousin, and my brother, the prisoner, were keeping my birthday, no one elseâ€”we waited on ourselvesâ€”we don't keep servantsâ€”my income won't allow usâ€”we fetched the beer ourselves; at least, I brought the most part of it from Mr. Fowler's, the Noah's Arkâ€”I do not keep my birthday every yearâ€”this was not an accident; it was because it completed the ten yearsâ€”I kept it once when I was twenty, and not sinceâ€”we might have had a drop the day I was twenty-nine, but no friends at all, no such meeting as thisâ€”there were only four of usâ€”I did not speak to Stimson, the constable, at any time that I am aware ofâ€”I saw him at my mother's house in Broad-streetâ€”I cannot state the date of thatâ€”I dare say it might be three weeks backâ€”my brother was not there at that time, he was in prisonâ€”I never recollect seeing the man before my brother was locked up this timeâ€”I told him that I had not seen my brother for a long time, and I can prove itâ€”I told the constable about three weeks back, when he came into my mother's house, that I had not seen my brother for about three monthsâ€”that was trueâ€”I can prove it to be trueâ€”you are putting questions to me that I really cannot answerâ€”he asked me if I had seen my brother to-dayâ€”I had been at the House of

Detention to see himâ€”I said I had not spoken to him for months before; that was trueâ€”he was at my place on the birthday and I spoke to himâ€”I never said that I bad not seen my brother for three monthsâ€”the constable came into the shop and asked me if I had seen my brother that dayâ€”I said, "Yes"â€”he said. "What did he have to say?"â€”I said, "Nothing much."
COURT. Q. What did you mean by saying just now that you told the, constable you had not seen your brother for three months? A. I said I had not spoken to him for several months before.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Then you did not speak to him on the birthday? A.
