That was sinceâ€”not since he was locked up, but beforeâ€”I said I had not spoken to him for several months before this transaction that he stands charged withâ€”I did not tell the constable that he was at my house on the birthday, and that I had spoken to him then; I had no occasion to do itâ€”I told him when he came into my mother's house that I had not spoken to himâ€”I can prove that was trueâ€”I told him that I had nothing to do with my brother, that I did not speak to himâ€”I knew then that he was inquiring about this matter, but I was not going to tell him all I knewâ€”I did not say anything about the birthdayâ€”I did not go before the Magistrate and tell him of itâ€”my brother was three times before the Magistrateâ€”I believe I was there twiceâ€”I did not say anything about the matter thereâ€”I was never asked such a thingâ€”I could not have got him out if I had stated it.

MR. RIBTON. Q. Where was it that this took place between you and the constable? A. In my mother's shopâ€”I do not know the dateâ€”I suppose it is about three weeks agoâ€”he and another came in private clothesâ€”they were talking to my mother, and she called me outâ€”he said to me, "Have you seen your brother to-day?" I said, "Yes"â€”he said, "What did he have to say?" I said, "Nothing much"â€”that was all, and then I walked inside againâ€”it was the same evening that I told the consatab'e that I had not seen my brother or spoken to him for several monthsâ€”it was not exactly at the same timeâ€”it was a few minutes afterwardsâ€”I came into the shop again, and had a second conversation with himâ€”my mother got talking about one thing, and I said to him, "I have not spoken to my brother for weeks and for months"â€”I know it was not true that I had not spoken to my brother for months.

COURT. Q. But you have said several times that it wan true, are you still quite sure that you saw him at your house on your birthday? A. He was at my house, and he slept at my house in the way I have described.

RAYNHAM STEWART . I live at 5, Clarence-street, Waterloo-town, Bethnal
greenâ€”I am a traveller, in the employ of Higley and Co., bottle merchantsâ€”I remember the 28th Octoberâ€”it was the birthday of my cousin, the last witness, William Stewartâ€”I was invited to go to his houseâ€”the prisoner John Stewart, accompanied meâ€”we got there about 6, and left about half-past, 11, and I left the prisoner behind meâ€”I did not bear any conversation about his sleeping thereâ€”I went straight home from thereâ€”I saw him again the next day, Tuesday, the 29th, about half-past 10 o'clock, at his mother's house, 95, Broad-street, Ratcliflfâ€”I know the witness John Lookerâ€”I was in the parlour that day and saw a personâ€”I did not know his name but I could recognise himâ€”I was afterwards told his nameâ€”his name was John Looker (looking at him), that is the personâ€”he came in and asked my cousin to go and look at some canvasâ€”my cousin said, "I will see, and I will let you know"â€”and he came in to me and said, "I must leave you"â€”he went away with Lookerâ€”I remained till he came backâ€”he told me to do soâ€”he was away about an hour, and they came back togetherâ€”I heard

Looker say to my cousin, "Well, can you do anything with it?"â€”my cousin said, "Well, I don't know"â€”Looker said, "Do you think you can get it made up into bags for me?" my cousin said, "I don't know, but I will let you know in a day or two's time"â€”and that was all I heard pass between themâ€”I left about one o'clock, or a little afterâ€”I saw Looker go out of the house before meâ€”I left at 1 o'clockâ€”my book will prove where I was on the Fridayâ€”it shows the day I worked at Ratcliffâ€”I worked at journey workâ€”this is my order book (produced).

Cross-examined. Q. What do you say about the Friday? A. That was the day I was asked to go to my cousin's house to supperâ€”it was the Friday previous to the 28th, which was on the Mondayâ€”I walked to the prisoner's house at half-past 5, on the Monday, and went with him to my cousin's houseâ€”the prisoner supped with usâ€”my order book will show that I was at work in Ratcliffeâ€”the conversation that I have spoken of took place at the Marine store dealers, my aunt's house; she was out at the time, and so was my other cousin, and there was only the prisoner and myself in the shop; by my aunt, I mean the mother of the prisonerâ€”I believe William Stewart lives thereâ€”it was on the Tuesday morning, the day after the birth
day, that I saw Looker thereâ€”I do not know whether John lives thereâ€”I went to inquire how he was, and found he was thereâ€”Alfred, a younger brother, lives with his mother alsoâ€”I do not know whether the prisoner lives thereâ€”I went there about half-past 10, on the Tuesday, and I had not been in the parlour long before Looker came inâ€”my cousin was in the shop when I went in, and I said to him," John, how are you after last night?"â€”he said, "Nicely, thank you"â€”and I went into the parlour which adjoins the shopâ€”I only called as I passed to see how he wasâ€”I had left him in a state of intoxication over nightâ€”I did not know that he lived thereâ€”I had not seen my cousin for a term of nearly twenty years, and I had only found him out the day before, by soliciting ordersâ€”I took an order of my very aunt, and that was how I found she was my aunt, and that he was my cousinâ€”I do not know whether his brother and he had not been on good termsâ€”I had not seen John Stewart before the day I took the order of my auntâ€”I have not seen William Stewart's wife hereâ€”she was present at the supper.

MR. RIBTON. Q. Was it on the Friday that you were invited to go and spend the evening on the Monday? A. It wasâ€”it was the prisoner, John Stewart, that asked me to goâ€”I had accidentally found out where his mother lived the day before, the Friday, by calling to solicit orders for coals, as the saying is, and I found out that she was my auntâ€”I had never seen her before e in my lifeâ€”when I asked her for an order she gave her name to me, and I told her mine, and then I understood she was my aunt, by making inquiries the same evening when I went homeâ€”it was the next day, Friday, that I saw the prisoner at his mother's house; having found that she was my aunt I went again, and then saw him there, and then it was he asked me to go to his brother's on the Mondayâ€”I left him on the Monday, having drunk a little too much, and I called at my aunt's to know how he wasâ€”I did not know where else to go to inquire for himâ€”I had not seen him for twenty years before.
JURY. Q. What is your age? A. Twenty.

COURT. Q. How old is the prisoner? A. I am told he is twenty-eightâ€”I had never seen him until the Thursday when I called at my aunt'sâ€”his father is deadâ€”I did not know the prisoner's brother till I went there on the Mondayâ€”I did not find out that she was my aunt until I got home on the Thursday night, and then I called next day, and then it was I saw the

prisoner thereâ€”I had taken his brother Alfred home with me the same night that I found my aunt outâ€”Alfred was there on the Thursday when I went in, and I took him home on the Mondayâ€”I am quite sure they are my cousins, because I have my aunt's certificate at home to prove itâ€”I live with my parentsâ€”the prisoner's father was my father's brotherâ€”my father had never told me about these relationsâ€”I had heard him speak of his brother John being dead, that was the prisoner's fatherâ€”he has been dead for some yearsâ€”we never had any family talk about itâ€”my parents are generally a bed when I go home, and I am generally out before they get up.

MARY DONOVAN . I know the prisoner, John Stewartâ€”I recollect going to his house some time in Octoberâ€”I suppose it was five or six weeks agoâ€”I went to look for some workâ€”it was on a Fridayâ€”he told me he had none at present; but he knew where I could get a week or two's workâ€”I thanked him, and he said, "If you go anywhere near Bow-common, ask for Mr. Looker's place, and you may get a week or two's work there"â€”I went the following morning, about half-past 6 o'clock, and got employment thereâ€”there were some bags in the roomâ€”I saw Mr. Looker's eldest boy, and after some time I saw Mr. Looker himself, and they set me and the other young women to cut bags according to a pattern sack that was thereâ€”some time after Mr. Stewart and Mr. Looker both came into the roomâ€”Stewart said he thought the bags were not saleableâ€”Looker went down and brought in a rule and measured the bags, and said, "Will they do?"â€”Stewart said, "I don't know"â€”I said, "If they are to be made like that we must hem the tops"â€”we made the bags according to that, and then Stewart said, "If there were some of the small ones we might get a sale of them better than the large ones," so we made some small and some large; but I have not got paid for eitherâ€”it was Mr. Looker's son who opened the door when I went there, and pointed where I was to goâ€”nothing was said to me about how the sacks came thereâ€”Mr. Looker told us to make them as exact as we we couldâ€”on the Monday he came in with a small piece, which he gave a young woman next to meâ€”it was on the Saturday that I went thereâ€”I worked there all day Saturdayâ€”it was not on the Saturday that I saw Stewart and Looker there; it was on the Mondayâ€”oh, yes, it was on the Saturday, I made a mistakeâ€”there was a piece of canvas put in the window where there was a broken pane, and Looker said, "Take that piece of stuff away," and the girl went and brought a piece of cotton bed-curtain, and fastened it up with a fork at each endâ€”he said he did not want the stuff to be seenâ€”we were supplied with twine to work the sacksâ€”Looker was in and out while we were at work, and his wife and daughter tooâ€”he gave us some oil and candle to work with at nightâ€”we worked till 9 o'clockâ€”the girl brought in the light.

Cross-examined. Q. How often did you see Stewart there? A. I saw him on the Saturday and on the Thursdayâ€”he was there pretty late on the Thursdayâ€”I cannot call to mind whether he was there on the Monday or Tuesdayâ€”I saw him there several timesâ€”I saw Hart there on the Thursday not on the Saturdayâ€”he came into the room and began to fold the bagsâ€”I only saw him there that day, and I showed him how to fold themâ€”I am in the habit of working at marine warehouses, and have been for the last twelve yearsâ€”that was why I called at Stewart'sâ€”he was not at this place when I went there on the Saturdayâ€”it was a good bit after breakfast that he came inâ€”there were two other women employed thereâ€”I know themâ€”they would have come here, but they are in great trouble in consequence of their brother being drowned last Wednesdayâ€”I was at Arbour-square, but

was not called on to say anythingâ€”I did not tell the constable that I was employed by Stewartâ€”I told him that Stewart had directed me there to workâ€”I did not tell the constable that I would not come up unless I was well paid for itâ€”I said I could not waste my time, I had to go to work; and he said, "You are going the wrong way to get paid"â€”I did not hear of the police coming to the place on the Thursdayâ€”it was 9 o'clock on Thursday night when I leftâ€”the other young women left with meâ€”Stewart and Hart did not leave with usâ€”when we went on the Friday Mrs. Looker said that the officers had beenâ€”we did not work any more after that.

MR. RIBTON. Q. Was it on the Friday that you first knew of the police having been there? A. Yesâ€”I went on the Saturday night and saw Mrs. Lookerâ€”she sent oat for a pot of beer and gave it to each of usâ€”she said if the stuff was cut too long she would burn the stripsâ€”we did not remain there on the Saturdayâ€”I was at work five days altogether.

HARTâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

STEWARTâ€”
GUILTY
on Second Count.â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

EVANSâ€”
GUILTY
on the Second Count.â€”
Confined Nine Months.

p.hi: Recommended to mercy on account of his good character.

div1.p:
98.
CHARLES MORHANGE (24)
, Stealing, on 1st July, 100 opera glasses; on 13th September 400 opera-glasses, 2 harmoniums, 1 telescope, 1 barometer, 6 stereoscopes, 1 case of mathematical instruments, and 6 figures; and, on 19th October, 600 opera-glasses and 100 marine-glasses, the property of
Leopold Weil, his master; to all of which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”Recommended to mercy by the prosecutor.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

99.
ELIZABETH RUSH (24)
, Feloniously forging and uttering an order for the payment of 5l. 18s. with intent to defraud, having been before convicted in 1859; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

100.
JAMES BERRETT (26)
, Feloniously forging and uttering a request, for the delivery of 10 dozen hat and coat rails, and 2 dozen dining-table fastenings; also, a request for the delivery of 3 dozen dining-table holders, and 4 sets of castors; also, a request for the delivery of 2 sets of brass castors, with inten to defraud, he having been before convicted; to all which he

PLEADED GUILTY .**â€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

101.
WILLIAM THOMPSON (30)
, Robbery on Hariette Spry, and stealing from her person 1 umbrella, and 7s. 6d. the property of
George Spry; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Three Months.

div0.p:
PRESENTâ€”Sir
JOHN MUSGROVE , Bart Ald.; Sir
HENRT MUGGERIDGE , knt. Ald; Mr. Ald. CONDER; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

div1.p:
102.
MARTHA THOMAS (16)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

103.
ELLEN THOMPSON (24), was indicted
for a like offence; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

104.
HEZRY MILFORD (21),
EMMA THEOBALD (22), and
JANE DYER (18)
, Feloniously having in their custody 2 moulds impressed with the obverse and reverse sides of a sixpence, to which

MILFORDâ€”
PLEADED GUILTY .

JAMES BRANNAN . I was formerly Inspector of Police, and am now in the service of the Mint authoritiesâ€”on 22d October I went to 27, Flower-and-Dean Street, Spitalfields, with Inspector Bryant, and two or three other officersâ€”we found the door open, and proceeded to the second floor front room, the door of which was shutâ€”I broke it open with a sledge hammer, and saw Milford sitting by a clear bright fire, in his shirt sleeves, with a plaster of Paris mould in one hand, wrapped in a pad, and a pipkin con
taining molten metal in the otherâ€”he placed the pipkin on the stove, flung the mould down and stamped upon itâ€”I pushed him off of it, and he was seized by Sergeant Brannanâ€”he resisted violently, and used every effort to destroy the mouldâ€”on his being secured, I picked off the floor frag
ments of a double mould for casting fourpenny-piecesâ€”a portion of lead lodged on the window, which I afterwards picked up; it was hotâ€”on a shelf in the cupboard I found this double mould for sixpences, which was warm (produced)â€”the prisoner Theobald picked up this cup off the table, con
taining sand and water, flung it at my face, and out dropped a large quantity of sixpences and fourpenny-piecesâ€”I caught the cup between my arm and body, and did not let it fall to the groundâ€”the sixpenny and four-penny pieces are hereâ€”here are twenty-four, dated 1856, and sixteen of 1823â€”Dyer was with her back to the door, she threw down a quantity of sixperices and fourpences on the table, which I afterwards picked up (pro
duced), and which were wet with sand and waterâ€”it is a very small room, the table was near the fire, and they all sat round itâ€”I told Milford I had received instructions to look after him and endeavour to put a stop to his practice in dealing largely in counterfeit coinâ€”he said, "I have not been long at it, Mr. Brannan; not more than three or four months, indeed, I might say this is my first time"â€”I found a file on the table with white metal in it's teeth as if recently used; a piece of glass with plaster of Paris adhering to it; some plaister of Paris in powder, and all the neces
sary implements for coiningâ€”there was no battery, they colour the coins with a saucer and a wire, which is immersed in a solution of cyanide of silverâ€”we found everything necessary for coiningâ€”I gave the coins and moulds to Mr. Websterâ€”I found two genuine sixpences and three or four groats.

BENJAMIN BRYANT (Police-inspector, G). I followed Brannan into the room, and saw Milford throw away the mould, and saw the two women sitting at a table scouring sixpences with sand, to rub off the blue and prepare them for silveringâ€”I took Theobald in custody, and took from her right hand these five counterfeit sixpences wet with sand, as were her handsâ€”I said you have been scouring theseâ€”she said, "Yes, I suppose I have"â€”at her feet I found a packet of ten sixpeuces separately wrapped in paper; they were finished and fit for circulationâ€”she asked me to give her her gown, shawl, and bonnet off the bed, which I didâ€”I asked her whether she lived thereâ€”she said, "You see I do"â€”I took her to the stationâ€”Dyer was in charge of another officerâ€”they were throwing the things about so that we were obliged to look very closely after them.

WILLIAM BROAD (Police-inspector, H). I went with the other officersâ€”on entering the room I saw Theobald take the cup from the table and throw the contents at Mr. Brannanâ€”there was then a complete scattering of coin all over the roomâ€”Dyer was behind Mr. Brannan, and went towards him with her hands as if to take hold of himâ€”I caught her by her hands, then let go of one hand and held her by the other, and picked from the floor eight sixpences and four groats (produced)â€”two of the groats were quite blueâ€”on the floor, at the head of the bed, I found a saucer with wet sand, in which were these four sixpences and four groats embeddedâ€”in a cupboard by the fire-place I found this piece of copper wireâ€”I heard Milford say, "We all three live here"â€”the other two could hear him say thatâ€”I said, "You cannot all three sleep in that bed, it is a very small one"â€”they made no replyâ€”I said to Milford, "What rent do you pay for the room?"â€”he said, "Three shillings a week"â€”from some nails in the room I took down two more women's dresses, one of which Dyer put on, also a bonnet and cloak which were in the room, and a silver guard which was on the mantel-pieceâ€”it was taken from her at the stationâ€”she said that it was her property.

JAMES BRANNAN, JUN . (Police-sergeant, G 21). I went with the other officers, and taw Milford struggling with the first witnessâ€”I secured himâ€”both the female prisoners rose from the table and scattered the things on it about the room.

WILLIAM WEBSTER . I am Inspector of Coin to her Majesty's Mintâ€”this is a fragment of a double mould for fourpencesâ€”here is a counterfeit coin which fell from it at the time, with part of the get attached to itâ€”here is a double sixpenny mould of 1853 and 1856â€”and among the counterfeit coin produced, I find two good sixpences, which have been used to make this mould fromâ€”here are sixteen counterfeit sixpences of 1853, all from that mould, and twenty-four from the 1856 mouldâ€”I also found some counterfeit fourpences in the moulds in which they were made, and the patterns used for making the moulds.

THEOBALD and DYERâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

p.hi:
James Brannan, Sen., stated that Milford lived by coining, and employed women and children to pass it, in shops where there were old persons or children serving.â€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

div0.p:
PRESENTâ€”The Right Hon. the LORD MAYOR; Mr. JUSTICE KEATING; Mr. Ald. COPELAND, M.ZP.; Sir
JOHN MUSGROVE , Bart. Ald.; Mr. Ald. SALOMONS, M.P.; Sir
HENRT MUGGERIDGE , Knight, Ald; Mr. Ald. CONDER; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

div1.p:
105.
THOMAS MADDELY (39)
, Feloniously killing and slaying
William Sylvester.

THOMAS WEST . I am a cigar-maker, of 22, Park-street, Tabernacle-squareâ€”on Saturday, 23d November last, I was with the deceased, William Sylvester, at the White Hart public-house, in Hooper-square, Whitechapelâ€”we went into the parlourâ€”the prisoner was thereâ€”the first thing that called my attention was the prisoner making use of bad language, and the deceased

said he was surprised to hear such language from a man, especially in the parlourâ€”after that they had a few words of talking, and the prisoner made a blow or shove with his elbow at the deceasedâ€”the deceased was then sitting on a seat in a corner close by the prisonerâ€”after that the prisoner struck him in the face, a back-handed slapâ€”I do not think he did anything when the prisoner shoved him with his elbowâ€”he said something, but I cannot say whatâ€”he did not strike the prisonerâ€”the back-handed blow was a heavy one, it drew bloodâ€”I saw his nose bleeding a trifle, not muchâ€”on receiving that blow Sylvester got up and tried to return it, but I do not know whether he did or notâ€”the prisoner then commenced fighting with his fistsâ€”he struck him several times about the face, as it appeared to meâ€”I should say five or six timesâ€”the deceased was then in a sitting posi
tion in the cornerâ€”the prisoner got up when he made the blows with his fist-**the deceased tried to get up, but the prisoner being so much heavier a man, forced him down againâ€”the deceased was a smaller man than myselfâ€”about this time, James Sylvester, the deceased's brother, came into the roomâ€”he went to his brother's assistanceâ€”I believe he made a blow at the prisonerâ€”I cannot say whether it took effect or not; they had a scuffle between the threeâ€”the landlord then came in and said he would have no fighting there, and he proceeded to push them out of the roomâ€”a few minutes afterwards I heard a scuffling at the bar, and I went to see what was the matterâ€”I had remained in the parlourâ€”I saw several persons round the bar, and the deceased lying on the floorâ€”I believe the prisoner was one of the persons round himâ€”I saw James Sylvester endeavouring to pull his brother upâ€”I think I remarked, "Let the man get up; do not strike him when he is down," and then his brother carried him to the doorâ€”I followed him out of the door; he laid his brother down on the ground, and then told him to get up, and he replied, "I cannot; my leg is broken"â€”I afterwards helped to put him in a cab, and take him to the hospitalâ€”I saw that he was injuredâ€”he had been drinking a little, but knew perfectly well what he was aboutâ€”the prisoner appeared to be in about the same state.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. Do you mean by that, that they were both drunk? A. No; not drunk, they had been drinking a littleâ€”you could hardly term it worse for liquorâ€”it was obvious they had been drink
ingâ€”I should say it was the prisoner who first made use of the bad languageâ€”I had been there about three-quarters of an hour, I should sayâ€”I had been drinking very little indeedâ€”I had about half a glass of gin in the house, and I do not think I had had three pints of beer the whole afternoonâ€”the scuffle which resulted in the fall of the deceased was in the bar, not outside the houseâ€”I was not there when it commenced; it was all over when I came upâ€”I should say about five minutes intervened between their leaving the parlour and my seeing the deceased on the groundâ€”I do not know how he came on the groundâ€”I did not see him struck when he was downâ€”I merely used that expression in the flurry of the moment.

JAMES SYLVESTER . I am the brother of the deceased, and am a cigar
maker, living at 8, Black Don-yard, Whitechapelâ€”he died on Wednesday, 27th November, at the London Hospitalâ€”I was at the White Hart on the 23d, attending a club in the upstair's roomâ€”I was about leaving the house with other members, when I heard that my brother was in the parlour, and I went to bid him good nightâ€”I found him sitting at the further corner, at the extreme end of the seatâ€”the prisoner sat on his right hand, close to himâ€”it was a small room, and very fullâ€”I saw the prisoner in the act of striking him in the face with his right hand as hard as he couldâ€”the blow produced

a bruise on his face, and his nose bledâ€”those who knew my brother could see that he had been drinking something, though he was decidedly not drunk, or in any way incapableâ€”I should say the prisoner, from his appearance, was more advanced in drinkâ€”I saw him deliberately strike my brothe again, and I crossed the room hurriedly, and got to him as soon as I could; but the room being full, it was occupied in the middle of it by persons sitting on chairsâ€”I called to the prisoner as I got near him, and meant to stop his arm, for he was about striking a second timeâ€”I was about getting hold of his arm, and he threw it over my face, to keep me off, and I was in
stantly engaged in a scuffle with himâ€”I pulled him out of the seat, turned him round, and got into it to screen my brotherâ€”he held on to me, and hugged me, and forced me down with my back on the settle, in the place he had sat in, and we were in that position when the landlord enteredâ€”he said he would not hare any noise thereâ€”he first pushed the prisoner out of the roomâ€”my brother did not want to go out; he was forced out by the landlordâ€”he resisted with all his mightâ€”I followed themâ€”I appealed to the landlord not to turn him out, as he might get ill-usedâ€”when we got to the bar the pri
soner stood in front of my brother, and a companion of his, of the name of Piersonâ€”they were both calling on my brother to come out and fightâ€”he said nothingâ€”he remained at the bar alongside of meâ€”the prisoner kept calling my brother names, and me also, and urging him to go out to fightâ€”from Pierson's threatening me, I was forced to leave my brother, and as I did so my brother struck at the prisoner, and said, "Get away"â€”the prisoner was in front of him at the time, in a threatening attitude, demand
ing that he should come out to fightâ€”there was great passion displayed when my brother struck himâ€”he took hold of my brother by the collar, and hugged him close to him, turned him round from the bar, and they reeled or inclined towards a corner, about six feet from where my brother had been standing, and they fell into the corner, my brother downwards, and the prisoner on the top of himâ€”I do not know whether he threw him, or how it was, but my brother went under himâ€”he was a very slight manâ€”I do not know that he laid bold of the prisoner; I could not see thatâ€”the prisoner is a very powerful man compared to my brotherâ€”I picked him upâ€”I found that he did not attempt to use his legs, and as soon as I got him out of hearing of the others, he said his leg was brokenâ€”he had had no other fall as far as I saw.

Cross-examined. Q. Was not this scuffle commenced by your brother going up to the prisoner and striking him a blow right full in the face. A. No; my brother did not go up to himâ€”he stood with his back against the barâ€”he struck at him; whether the blow reached his face or not I cannot sayâ€”Pierson engaged me, while I was endeavouring to protect my brother, and he wanted to fight me for interferingâ€”I am sure my brother did not go up to the prisoner and strike him; it could not have occurred without my see
ing it.

HENRY KULKE . I keep the White Hart public-house in Hooper-square, Whitechapelâ€”on this night I saw a scuffle take place between the prisoner, the deceased, and the last witness, in the parlourâ€”that was what I first observedâ€”on seeing that, I caught hold of the deceased and pushed him out of the room, and said I did not want any fighting or any row in my establish
mentâ€”I likewise pushed the prisoner outâ€”there is a passage leading from the parlour to the bar, about thirty or forty feet longâ€”I walked up to the bar and stood there for about a quarter of an hour-there were still very angry words on both sides; they were talking about fighting and what they

would doâ€”the prisoner said something about licking the deceased, or any
body elseâ€”another man stood between the prisoner and the deceased, and the deceased's brother stood behind himâ€”all of a sadden the deceased rushed by the man that stood between him and the prisoner, and struck the prisoner in the faceâ€”a scuffle ensued, and they both fell on the floor in the barâ€”I believe each laid hold of the otherâ€”I can't say who laid hold firstâ€”I am sure I saw the deceased strike the prisoner in the faceâ€”I found after
wards he had struck him in the eye, and almost blinded himâ€”I can't say who fell uppermost, but I believe it was the prisonerâ€”the deceased's brother took him outside, and he said he could not stand, that his leg was brokenâ€”they appeared to have been drinking.

Cross-examined. Q. Was the deceased very much the worse for liquor? A. I can't say that he was; I think they were both alikeâ€”they were not what you would call drunkâ€”this occurred about 11 o'clockâ€”I only knew the prisoner as an occasional customerâ€”I have not been there long.

MR. LING. I am house-surgeon at the London Hospitalâ€”the deceased was brought there on Saturday night, 23d Novemberâ€”he had sustained a compound fracture of the right thigh boneâ€”he died on the following Wednesday evening from the shookâ€”he never recovered from the shook caused by the injury.

Cross-examined. Q. Was he a man of bad habit of body? A. He was rather; he was about thirty years of ageâ€”he was not labouring under any diseaseâ€”I made a post-mortem examination, and found nothing else to account for deathâ€”mortification did not set inâ€”he died from the shock to the nervous systemâ€”the local injury was progressing favourablyâ€”he had his senses all the timeâ€”I apprehended serious consequences from the firstâ€”he was taken suddenly worse on the day he died, and he died about 8 in the eveningâ€”I had seen him about an hour before, and again about three hours before thatâ€”I was called to him suddenly about an hour before his deathâ€”when I saw him three hours before I anticipated fatal results, he had sick
ness and was very faintâ€”I examined all the visceraâ€”I found tubercles of the lungs, not sufficient to account for deathâ€”they were not in a state of suppurationâ€”I examined the brain.

MR. PLATT. Q. Would a fall arising in a scuffle between two persons, the other being the more powerful man of the two, be likely to cause the frac
ture? A. Yes; I have no doubt that he died from the results of the fracture.

CHARLES JOSHUA GEAVES (Police-sergeant, H 14). I took the prisoner into custody, on 28th November, at his houseâ€”I said, "Maddely, you will have to go with me"â€”he said, "What for?"â€”I said, "For this unpleasant affair about poor Sylvester"â€”he said, "Very well"â€”I told him he was deadâ€”he said "I am very sorry; I have asked after him several times, but I did not hear that he was dead."

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Three Months.

106.
JOHN FORD (59)
, Feloniously forging and uttering an order for the payment of 20l., with intent to defraud.

WILLIAM GLASS . I am a millwright, residing at Henry Cottage, Philip-street, Bathâ€”I became acquainted with the prisoner prior to March last-some time before March I spoke to him about an action against somebodyâ€”he advised me as to an attorneyâ€”he mentioned the name of Mr. Tood or Todd, I am not sure whichâ€”in consequence of that advice I came up to London with him and saw Mr. Toddâ€”it was somewhere in Newgate-streetâ€”I generally live at Bathâ€”I know very little about Londonâ€”I never was here

but three times in my lifeâ€”it was arranged, in the prisoner's presence, that I should send 20l. to Mr. Todd to carry on the actionâ€”after that I returned to Bath with the prisonerâ€”I was to advance the 20l. to Mr. Toddâ€”the prisoner heard me say thatâ€”he was in the room at the same timeâ€”after my return to Bath, I asked the prisoner for Mr. Todd's proper direction, and he gave me "William Todd, 95, Newgate-street," and I put it in my pocket-book, and I have it now (producing it)â€”it was made at the timeâ€”I asked him for the proper address to which I was to send the money, and I entered this at the time from what the prisoner told meâ€”I told him I was going to send it through the West of England Bank, where I cash, to Glyn and Company in Londonâ€”the address he gave me was "William Tood, 95, Newgate-street, London, E.C."â€”after that conversation with the prisoner I sent to 95, Newgate-streetâ€”the cheque was sent through the bank, not by meâ€”I sent a letter to 95, Newgate-streetâ€”I was to send the 20l. through the West of England Bankâ€”I sent the money to Glyn's to the credit of Mr. Toddâ€”I also sent a letter of advice to Mr. Todd's, directed, to 95, Newgate-streetâ€”I went to the West of England Bank and told them to send 20l. out of my cash to Glyn and Co., to the credit of Mr. Toddâ€”(some letters were here produced by Mr. Oke from the Mansion House)â€”this is a letter dated, "Bath, March 15th, 1861"â€”that is not my letterâ€”it was not written by me or with my authorityâ€”I know nothing about it, and never heard of it till I saw it produced at the police-officeâ€”I saw it once before in Mr. Todd's hands, at his office, while this matter was pendingâ€”that was the only timeâ€”it was produced at the police-court in defence of the prisoner, by the prisonerâ€”Mr. Todd was acting as the prisoner's attorneyâ€”(Read: "March 15th, 1861. Mr. Ford, Sir, if you will call on Messrs. Glyn and Co., bankers, in Lombard-street, in the City of London, you will be paid the sum of 20l. which I have paid into the South Wales Bank here in Bath, W. W. Glass").
COURT. Q. You say no portion of that is in your handwriting? A. None at all.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Look at the other letter which you have there, dated 17th August? A. I never saw this beforeâ€”this purports to be signed W. Glassâ€”it is not my handwriting, or written by my authorityâ€”I first saw that in Mr. Todd's hands, and I saw it at the Mansion House the second timeâ€”it was produced there in defence of the prisoner, produced by the prisonerâ€”(Read: "Received of John Ford five pounds, in part of money due to me from the twenty pounds he received of Messrs. Glyn and Co. bankers, in Lombard-street, London, under my order to William Toode and himself, W. Glass, Bath, August 17th, 1861.")â€”it is not correct that I received 5l. out of the 20l.â€”I never authorized the prisoner to take the 20l.â€”he was in Bath at the time I sent up the money, and subsequently, in Augustâ€”I should think I should scarcely send money up to London for him to receive it, and pay me a portion of itâ€”I never authorized the prisoner to write that letter to 95, Newgate-street, or to receive the money at Glyn'sâ€”I know his handwritingâ€”this," William Tood," on the cheque, is in the pri
soner's handwriting, to the best of my belief, and the letter is his writingâ€”I have seen him write I should say twenty timesâ€”I see the name of John Ford, on this 10l. Bank of England noteâ€”that is in the prisoner's writing.

COURT. Q. Look at these two letters, whose handwriting do you say they are in? A. I do not know whose that isâ€”this receipt is in Fords writingâ€”I do not know whose handwriting the letter of 15th March is.
MR. METCALFR. Q. On 17th March, after you had sent the money did

the prisoner say anything to you about going to London, shortly after you had paid the money into the bank? A. Yes; he came on the Sunday morning, and said that Mr. Tood or Mr. Todd had written to him to be in London on Monday morning to help make up the briefs for the Assizes, in my actionâ€”that was the day after I had paid the money in to the bankâ€”a few days after that I saw the prisoner back again in Bathâ€”he said it was all right, Mr. Tood had received the moneyâ€”he said he had been up to London.

Prisoner. Q. Did not you sign that order at the public-house on Friday, the 15th? A. No; I will swear thatâ€”I did not receive 5l. of your wife in part of that moneyâ€”I received 5l. of what you owed meâ€”you know what you owed it me for.
COURT. Q. You did receive 5l. you say? A. Yes; of his wife.

Prisoner. Q. Was it on 16th July that my wife paid you the money, in the presence of myself and my son? A. It was the end of Julyâ€”I gave a little bit of a memorandumâ€”it was on a piece of tax paper.

COURT. Q. I thought you said you did not give a receipt? A. Not thisâ€”I did receive 5l. from him at the end of July, I thinkâ€”I received it from his wifeâ€”I did not give a receipt for itâ€”I put my name to a bit of paper; not thisâ€”I think this is it on the back of this receiptâ€”the 5l. was paid to me for money owing to me for different things, and for putting my name to a loan society for some moneyâ€”I think this is the piece of paper that I wrote on, which is pasted on thisâ€”I say it was pasted on on purposeâ€”I do not know anything about this piece of paperâ€”I did put my name to some paper when the 5l. was paidâ€”it was a little corner bitâ€”like that on the back.

Prisoner. That is the paper he signed; my wife paid him over the 5l., and he signed that in the presence of my sonâ€”I do not owe him a shillingâ€”the order was written at the Lion and Lamb public-house, about 7 o'clock one evening.
Q. Did not I write the letter of 15th March for you about this money, and did not you sign it in the bar? A. No, I never did; I swear that.
Q. Did not you write down Mr. Todd's right address in his own office? A. I never had a pen in my hand there.

Q. Did you make a memorandum in your pocket-book of "Mr. Todd, 75, Newgate-street"? A. I did notâ€”I put down 95, at my office at Bathâ€”this is the memorandum I madeâ€”you did not tell me I sent it wrong, to 95 instead of 74â€”I did not tell you I had sent to 95, in the name of William Toodâ€”I was not refused by a loan office as a surety for you for 30l. nor did you get a man of the name of Mitchell, because they would not let the money go on my securityâ€”I wish they had refused to take my security, for then I should not have had to pay 7l. 10s. last week.
MR. METCALFE. Q. You say you did become surety for him to a loan society? A. Yes; and had to pay 7l. 10s. last weekâ€”I never owed him 20l.
Prisoner. Q. Did not I get you 50l. on a bill of sale on the goods of your son? A. That is another thing. Prisoner. The goods belonged to his son before he (the prosecutor) was convicted of felony.

COURT. Q. Have you ever been convicted? A. Yes; for shooting, but I never shot, it was an apprentice of mineâ€”I was convicted of shooting at a man, but there was no powder in the gun, only something I picked up off the floorâ€”my sentence was six months' imprisonmentâ€”it is twelve months ago last March that I came out.

Prisoner. Q. Did not you apply to me to get your debts in at Cardiff? A. No, not on any occasionâ€”I did not apply to you to make a conveyance, and date it back before my convictionâ€”I did not get it done in Mr. Bon
ham's office, and show it to you and say he had an old stampâ€”I did not show you a newspaper of Walsall County Court, where it was held that a man that had been convicted could not recoverâ€”I did not recover 7l. odd of Morgan Edwardsâ€”I did not recover any from Mr. Gubbardâ€”I swear thatâ€”I had money, but not through youâ€”you got me 50l. on a bill of sale on goods belonging to my son, before my convictionâ€”that is all paid offâ€”I don't know where you obtained it.
Q. Are you not making a claim on the British Nation Insurance office, upon the policy of William Henry Fisher? A. That is another questionâ€”I have got the money.

Prisoner. He got me to make a conveyance from Fisher to himself, of a life policy for 500l., and he never gave me a farthingâ€”Fisher would not sign it, be only put "William Henry"â€”he would not sign any moreâ€”Mr. Glass made a claim on the office, and he says he has got the moneyâ€”the Fisher family have set up a claim, and I should not have been here if he did not think I had disclosed to them that he never had a proper assignment at all. Witness. You never did anything in itâ€”I did not put in the name of Fisher to enable me to recoverâ€”you did not draw up the assignment for meâ€”I did not employ you to do itâ€”you have been guilty of it all your lifetimeâ€”I did not employ you to do anything of the sortâ€”you drawed me down to the Cardiff Assizes, and I had no business thereâ€”I did not tell you to advance Merry half a sovereign and his fareâ€”you have not done other services for meâ€”I have not employed you to pledge my tools.

JAMES MITCHELL . I am a cashier at Glyn'sâ€”on 19th March I paid 20l. to the person who produced this cheque, a 10l. note, and 10l. in cashâ€”the number of the 10l. note was 76,550, dated 22d October, 1860.

RICHARD ADYE BAILY . I am a clerk in the accountant's office in the Bank of Englandâ€”I produce this 10l. note cancelledâ€”it was paid in on 4th April last, through Barclay's the bankersâ€”I find the name of John Ford endorsed on itâ€”it was in that state when it was paid in.

ROBERT HERMAN . I am a cashier at the Bath City Bankâ€”I changed this Bank of England note on 1st Aprilâ€”the prisoner produced it to meâ€”at my request he wrote his name on itâ€”I knew him by sightâ€”I am quite sure he is the personâ€”we sent it into Barclay's.

Prisoner. Q. Did I not call twice at your bank? A. Yesâ€”I declined to change it at first on account of its being so torn, but I offered to send it to London for you for advice, and on 6th April you called for the money, and I paid you the amountâ€”I did not write part of this endorsement for youâ€”I did not write Oak-street upon itâ€”there is no Oak-street hereâ€”there is the letter Oâ€”I might have begun to write it.

JOHN TODD . I am a solicitor, at 75, Newgate-streetâ€”Mr. Glass was in
troduced to me by the prisoner at my office in Newgate-street, on 13th Marchâ€”I have my call book hereâ€”they both came togetherâ€”I had procured the papers in an action from a Mr. Crosby of Bath or Bristol, I am not sure which, and it was arranged that I was to carry on the action, in lieu of Mr. Crosbyâ€”I asked Mr. Glass to remit me 25l., and he agreed to send 20l.â€”I never received the 20l. nor any part of it, with the exception of 5l. which wax paid to me by the prisoner subsequently, which might or not be part of itâ€”that was paid somewhere about 19th August, 1 think, on Mr. Glass's accountâ€”this "William Toode" to this cheque was not signed by me or by
my authorityâ€”I saw nothing of this cheque until these proceedingsâ€”I think the first time I saw it was when it was produced by Mr. Beard, the attorney for the prosecution.

Q. Did you know until that time that a letter or a cheque had been sent to 95, Newgate-street? A. I knew it from the correspondence that took place between me and the prosecutor, when inquiries were made about the receipt of the moneyâ€”that was in Augustâ€”those inquiries originated through my receiving a letter from the prosecutorâ€”I never signed this, or gave the prisoner authority to sign it and receive the money.

Prisoner. Q. Did Mr. Glass call at your office with me on 13th March? A. Yes; he wrote down my name and address in his pocket-book in pencil, not with a penâ€”the action that has been spoken of, was in the name of his son, Frederick Glass, not in the name of the prosecutorâ€”I did not defend an action of ejectment for him at Cardiffâ€”I entered an appearance to an action of ejectment, and no further proceedings have been had sinceâ€”Mr. Glass called on me some time in Augustâ€”I produced to him two documentsâ€”you were not there thenâ€”these are the two, the letter of 15th March, and the receiptâ€”the body of this, the prosecutor acknowledged at the Mansion House, was in your handwritingâ€”I believe the signature of William Glass to be the prosecutor's signatureâ€”I am acquainted with his handwriting by corresponding with him; by letters that I now have, and a comparison of the handwritingâ€”I have corresponded with him, and acted on the correspondenceâ€”I am now speaking of the letterâ€”I believe the signature of William Glass, to this receipt for the 5l., to be also the prosecutor's writingâ€”I first showed him this authority, which he denied writingâ€”then A question was put to him whether it was his signature, he said, "Certainly not"â€”he was then shown the receipt, and he said that was all right.

COURT. Q. Did he examine it before he said that? A. He did so, and read it throughâ€”this was in the presence of Mr. Hughes, the chief of the police at Bath, and be immediately said to the prosecutor, "Why, if that is all right, what do you say to this!" calling his attention to the fact that it would be admitting the authority, and then he said. "Oh, no; I never saw the paper before"â€”he denied the receipt.

Prisoner. Q. Have you any letters in your possession that you received from the prosecutor, to show his handwriting to the jury? A. I haveâ€”I have four letters here, all from himâ€”the first is dated August, 6thâ€”that came to me in this envelope, directed to William Toode, Esq. 91, Newgate-street, Londonâ€”this is the letter which is contained in that envelope, the first of the four: they are pinned togetherâ€”that letter is in Glass's hand
writing, and the address alsoâ€”one of these letters is directed, J. Toode, Esq.â€”they became more correct after the correspondence with me in Augustâ€”the first is William Toode, the second is J. Tood, the third is J. Tood, and after that J. Toddâ€”these are all in the prosecutor's handwritingâ€”I am of course speaking of the letters themselvesâ€”that which is on the back are copies of the answers which I sent, in short handâ€”they are all about this money, the 20l., except the first oneâ€”the first says nothing about the 20l.â€”it is asking me whether I think it would be the best plan to go to Cardiff, and, as I had never received any money, I thought it was a very unreason
able thing to expect me to go, and I never answered the letterâ€”I think it was in the second letter that I communicated to him that I had not received the 20l.â€”I received a letter from him, dated the 15th, on the 16th, and then I wrote a letter to him, of which I have a copyâ€”it was on 16th August that I first communicated to him that I had not received the 20l.â€”this is the

letter, without troubling your Lordship with the whole of it; "If you recol
lect, your engagement in the first instance was to pay 20l. on my taking the business in hand, and if this had been done, as in good faith it ought to have been, your business would have been properly attended to"â€”that caused an explanation from him, and some further correspondence took placeâ€”I have his letter here in answer to thatâ€”in that letter he states that he did send the moneyâ€”(The letters were here put in and read as follows:" Bath, August 6th, 1861, to Mr. William Tood. Sir, I write to know whether or no you think it the best plan for you to come down to Cardiff on Monday the 12th instant, by the train, to see the place and the witnesses on the spot, and hear what they got to say, and put down their report, and I will meet you up at the Queen's Hotel; the packet sails Tuesday morning, half-past 8, and we can all come over together, and then we shall be in Bristol before 11 o'clock. Please send me word back by Mr. Ford. W. Glass. Honery Cotage, Philip Street, Bath." "Bath, August 15th, 1861, Mr. J. Tood. Sir, I am surprised at Ford's conduct; I was sory of not hearing from you, and leaving me in the dark; I was was in bristol Tuesday and cald acording to order at the Rumer they told me you whould be there at 2 o'clock: cald at 2. 4 and 6 but no Mr. Tood; next day went to bristol, cald againe went to the Cardiff Packet and seen Ford; him told me a round about tale, I could make nothing of it; him had plenty of money from me for to serve the supeneys for this asizes, and time enough. Please to send me answer by the return of Poast Will oblidge." "Bath, August 20th, 1861. Mr. J. Ford. Sir, I am surprise to read your letter; the 20l. was sent on the 15th of March last, through the Bank in Bath that I cash with to the Bank in London they cash with for Wm.' Tood Esq., Newgate St No. 95. I wrote to you the same day to go to the Bank for it and have been surprise all along of not hearing from you, but Ford being in London on the 18th March when came back after a long told it was all right and brought the Plea of Rawlinson and others at the suit of Glass by Robert Cunliff there attorney. I wrote to you on July 14th to meet me at Cardiff on 19th of July last, but being told by Ford of your wrong direction Mr. Wm. Tood 95 Newgate St I had a return letter back, there was no such person and now I find your direction is J Tood Esq. 75 Newgate Street. Please send answer by the return of post and wether or no you was in Cardiff last week and they gave offer to settle. Ford told me they had: for Frederick Glass, my son, W. W. Glass. Henery Cotage, Philip Street, Bath." "Bath August 20th. 1861. Mr. J. Todd. Sir, the letter that was posted in March last I put in the post office myself; the Bank was the North Wilts and South Whales Banking Company to Messrs. Glyn, Mills & Co. Lombard Street, Londo, 20l. for W Tood Esq 95 Newgate Street London, the Bath Bank having writing about to the London Bank by the return of post they say the 20l. was taken out on the 19th March in the name of W Tood Esq; the cashire of the Bath is gon to Bristol this to head quarters about it and to compair the writing that I had by me of fords and writing on the check of 20l.: ford told that you and him left Bristol on Monday 12th of this month to go to Cardiff to see the place and the wit
neses. I thought of going but Ford said to save expence you and him could do it and supene the witnesesâ€”when him came back he told me that Mr. Todd said it was to late this asizes there was not time to get breef up; it must remain till march next, and told me a great deal more. Please to send a reply by the return of post: ford came on Sunday the 17th March, stating that him received a letter to be in London to meet you on the Monday morning to help make out the and borrowed 10s. of me to cary him upâ€”W.
W. Glass. Henery Cotage Philip Street Bath. J. Todd Esq 75 New gate Street London. I have attended to the windows.")
Prisoner. Q. Have you got a subpaena among your papers, to subpaena arties to the County Court? A. No, I have not; nothing of the sortâ€”I have a bill of Mr. Morgan Edwards.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Have you a letter of 22d August? A. I have not the original letter, I have a copy of itâ€”I gave some of the letters to a per
son to copy, and unfortunately he lost them, but he brought me the copies, and I am perfectly willing to put them in.

COURT. Q. Is that a letter from the prosecutor? A. Yes; a copy of it (The copy was read as follows: "August 22d, 1861. To Mr. J. Todd "Sir, Ford never had any athoraty from me; it dos seem likely after sending the 20l. to you through the bank, what would the bank think of me; he never had any signature from me; I never had 5l. from him on the bank account; it was owingâ€”the 5l. that you had from he, I know nothing about W. W. Glass; Henery Cotage, Philip-street, Bath. J. Todd, Esq., 75, Newgate-street, London, E. C.")â€”It was subsequent to that corres
pondence that the documents were produced to the prosecutor, when he called on meâ€”I can tell you the date from my call-book (referring); it was on 30th August.
Prisoner. Q. Have you a bill of Morgan Edwards? A. I haveâ€”I believe that to be the prosecutor's writing.

Prisoner. That is one of the bills that I was to collectâ€”the prose
cutor has sworn that he never gave me any authority to do it, and I have here a list of the parties that I was to subpaena, to show that the prosecutor employed me for that purpose, and gave me the money to subpaena the witnesses, and other things, and this money was to be so appliedâ€”these are the names of the parties I was to subpaena (handing in a paper)â€”he states in his letter that he has given Ford plenty of mousy to subpaena them. Witness. This is a list of persons, whether they were to be witnesses or not I do not knowâ€”I produce it for the purpose of comparison of the hand
writing of the prosecutorâ€”they are in his handwritingâ€”I do not know what they were intended forâ€”this was sent up by the prisoner's wife from Bath to me, and when I came to look at it I saw that it was in the prose
cutor's handwriting, and from this document, with the others, I give my opinion about these signaturesâ€”I believe them to be in the prosecutor's handwritingâ€”I have not got any subpaena here, which has been sent up to me.

MR. METCALFE. Q. You say you produced to the prosecutor the letter and the receipt? A. I didâ€”I got them from the prisonerâ€”he wrote for themâ€”I can tell by my copies of my letters when I did get themâ€”it was after the charge of forgery was made, and after the Bath police had been communicated with and were in search of the prisonerâ€”the prisoner then wrote down to Bath for these documents, and they were sent upâ€”I am not quite certain whether they came to my office directed to him, and he opened them there, or notâ€”these are the envelopes I received from the prosecutor, and there are othersâ€”here is one from Mr. Hughes, and another from a subordinate in his office, and there is another, I think, from Hughe sâ€”there are three from the police-office at Bathâ€”I do not recollectwhether the prisoner gave me the documents, or whether he gave them to me after opening an envelope in which they were contained, directed to my office, but I rather think the latter was the caseâ€”it was after the charge of forgery was made; it was that which caused the documents to be sent forâ€”I have

only known the prisoner since March, 1860â€”he has not brought me a great deal of business; he has brought me two matters, this and another, in which an appearance was enteredâ€”I knew nothing of the prosecutor till the prisoner introduced me to himâ€”he has not brought other persons to my officeâ€”he was not acting as my agent down thereâ€”there are plenty of attorneys at Bathâ€”it appears that he was acquainted with a man of the name of Holly, who laid claim to some property, and had been a client for twenty-five years, or more, of Mr. Hawkes, of Frome, to whom I was agent Mr. Hawkes died some months ago, and I having been so long agent to him, Holly came to me, he being also acquainted with the prisoner; that was the origin of itâ€”I have not been acting as attorney for the prisoner in this matterâ€”I went to the Mansion House and I cross-examined the witnesses there, because he had no means to procure any assistanceâ€”I learnt from him that the receipt was given in the presence of his sonâ€”I have not taken steps to subpoena his sonâ€”I have is hereâ€”I took steps to produce him at the police-court, at the prisoner's requestâ€”he was not thereâ€”it appears he did not get my letter in timeâ€”I do not know whether Mr. Hughes is here, I have not seen himâ€”I have not taken steps to get him hereâ€”I believe he was not at the Mansion House; not on the occasion that I was there, to my knowledgeâ€”I was not asked, at the Mansion House, whether the prosecutor had admitted the signature of the receipt, and that I believed it to be hisâ€”I was not attorney for the prisoner thereâ€”I merely acted on his behalf on that occasion, purely out of benevolenceâ€”I admit that I cross-examined the witnesses, but it was entirely from a benevolent motiveâ€”I thought there was no occasion to tender my evidence, because I knew there would be a com
mittalâ€”I was examined on the part of the prosecution, and was asked the questions that I have been asked here to-day; whether I knew anything about the cheque, and I answered it as I have answered it to-day; further than that I did not goâ€”I produced the letter and the receipt in the course of the examinationâ€”I told the Lord Mayor that it was a question as to the handwriting, and that if the prisoner had not committed forgery, the prose
cutor must have committed perjury; I think that was about as strong as I could put itâ€”I did not give evidence that I believed it to be the prosecutor's handwriting; I put it as an advocate and I did not interfere further, because I knew that he must be committed on the oath of the prosecutorâ€”I did not tell the Lord Mayor that I heard the prosecutor admit the signature to the receiptâ€”that took place in the presence of Mr. Hughesâ€”I did not take steps to have him brought here, it was the prosecutor's place to do thatâ€”Mr. Hughes was there on the first examination when I was not; so I have heardâ€”I do not knowâ€”I got it from a newspaper report, in which it was stated that they would not allow the expenses of their coming up from Bathâ€”I knew the Lord Mayor would not try the caseâ€”I knew it would be tried hereâ€”I did not consider it my place to take steps to get Mr. Hughes here; I am not the prisoner's attorneyâ€”I am perfectly impartial, as I told Mr. Mulleus and Mr. Beard alsoâ€”I did not threaten the prosecutor, and advise him not to take proceedings against the prisonerâ€”I will swear that (looking at a letter)â€”I hinted that he could take civil proceedingsâ€”I advised him not to take criminal proceedingsâ€”I knew at that time that the charge of forgery had been made, and that the Bath police were in search of himâ€”if you will allow that letter to be read, it contains my reasons.
Q. The prosecutor had long before that told you that the documents were not his? A. He had denied the one and admitted the other: and then he

retracted as to the letter; that was the state of thingsâ€”he had previously stated by letter that the prisoner had no authority from himâ€”all those letters were anterior to the production of the two documentsâ€”I did not authorize the prisoner to sign the name of William Toodâ€”I think it is the prisoner's handwritingâ€”he had no authority whatever from me to do soâ€”I saw the prosecutor write his name and address in pencil in his pocket-book while he was with meâ€”I cannot identify the pocket-bookâ€”the one he had contained a vast number more leaves than this (produced)â€”I cannot possibly explain how it was, if he did write my address, that these letters were directed to No. 91 and 95â€”91 would be as likely to find me as 95, and the inference is, that if one came the other wouldâ€”I do not venture to make a specula
tion as to whether the letter was sent or notâ€”I do not say that the cheque was an imaginary thing altogetherâ€”I think it is possible it might have been returned to the prosecutor if you ask me; and I will tell you why, because in one of his letters he states that one of his letters, directed to William Tood, 95, was returned to him from the post-officeâ€”if that was so, I should think it very likely that the other had been returned; and in one of my letters I believe I put a question to him about that.

Q. Perhaps you think it very likely that a man at Bath would send up money, and the very day he sent it up, or a day or two alter, would authorize a person to go up and receive it, and pay back a portion to him? A. No; I do not think it at all likely; but if you ask me what has passed between these parties, I will tell you what I do think likely about itâ€”I understood afterwards that the prosecutor's son was a lunaticâ€”I did not know it in the first instanceâ€”the body of the receipt is wholly in the handwriting of the prisoner.

COURT. Q. The signature being, as you think, the protestor's? A. Yesâ€”would your Lordship allow me to see the signature to the original deposition? I only wish to speak to that which is the conviction of my mind (referring to it)â€”yes; it agrees.

MR. METCALFS. Q. You said something about pasting a piece of paper over that receipt? A. Yes; because it had got torn by accident, and I pasted a piece of waste paper at the backâ€”a little water and a wet sponge would take it off in a moment; it is only gumâ€”it was torn at the left cornet, and would have carried away the word "receipt," and some other words, and for the purpose of preserving it I tore off part of an old letter and pasted it at the backâ€”the body of the receipt is in the prisoner's writingâ€”the signature, I am prepared to swear, is the prosecutor's, even by a comparison with the depositionsâ€”I do swear that it is the prosecutor's handwritingâ€”I never saw him write, but I have communicated with him by letter, and have acted upon those lettersâ€”that is the conscientious conviction of my mind.

COURT. Q. Did you see what he wrote with pencil in his pocket-book? A. No; he sat by the sideâ€”I took no particular notice of itâ€”I saw him pull out a pocket-book with more leaves in it than this, and I saw him write the name.

HENRY BERRY . I am a sergeant of the Bath detective policeâ€”I took the prisoner into custody on 23d November last, in Westcot-street, Bathâ€”I told him he was charged with uttering a forged cheque on Glyn and Co., of Londonâ€”he said, "Glass will have to prove that; I can show that I was authorized to receive the money. I am quite prepared to meet the case now."
MR. MKTCALFE to WILLTAM GLASS. Q. You have heard it stated that in

conversation with Mr. Todd you said the receipt was yours? A. No such thing; I never said the receipt was mine in the presence of Mr. Hughesâ€”if Mr. Hughes was here he could not say soâ€”I never heard it stated until to-day that I had done soâ€”I still persist in saying that the signatures are not mineâ€”I wrote the letters that have been producedâ€”some of them are directed to 91, then to 95, and then to 75â€”75 was where I found out his name and directionâ€”91 must be a mistake; still he got themâ€”the letter sent advising the money, was returned to me through the postâ€”no, no, not the letter which advised the moneyâ€”I have the letter which was returned by the postâ€”Mr. Beard, my solicitor, has it somewhereâ€”it came through the dead letter-officeâ€”that was the only letter that was returned by the post.
COURT. Q. Did you post the letter yourself advising the sending of the 20l.? A. Yes.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Did you ever say anything that was intended to induce Mr. Todd to believe that you wrote or signed either of those docu
ments? A. Not at all.

COURT. Q. Look at the documents again, are the signatures like yours at? A. Not the least; that "W" is a more fanny one than mineâ€”the "W. Glass" is unlike mine; it does not resemble mine at all, not the least, no part of it; neither of the signaturesâ€”one of these addresses in the pocket book was written since I came to London along with Mr. Hughes; that was some time in August, I should think about the 28thâ€”I don't know exactlyâ€”(looking at a paper) this is my handwritingâ€”it is a list of witnesses to be subpoened at the assizes, by the prisonerâ€”this (another paper) is my writingâ€”this was one picked up in my shopâ€”it is a claim against Morgan Edwards, and othersâ€”I recovered the amount of that after My convictionâ€”the prisoner was not concerned for me in thatâ€”he was not thereâ€”he picked this up in my counting-house when I flung it downâ€”I had two or three of these bills, and I dropped it down, and he picked it upâ€”I saw him pick it up, no doubt I didâ€”I allowed him to take it away with himâ€”I had the thing on the books, and it was no goodâ€”I can quote t say why he took it away, I did not ask himâ€”(looking at another paper) this is my sig
natureâ€”these letters to Mr. Todd are signed by meâ€”I sign my name in different ways at different times; sometimes I sign "W. W."â€”I never sign "W. M"â€”I sign "W" and a small "m" for Williamâ€”I thought you meant "W. M." in capitalsâ€”I do sign "Wm."â€”sometimes I sign "W. Glass," without the "m"; that is three different ways.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Look at that yellow envelope; is that your envelope which you sent to 95, Newgate-street? A. Yes.

Prisoner. Q. Was I at Cardiff County Court with you in July last? A. Well, you were there, I believe, but I never asked you to comeâ€”I did not serve a subpoena upon you in Glove's caseâ€”I did not say when you came, "I am glad you have come; I am all of a tremble"â€”I did not send you to Morgan Edwards two or three times after the money that I had got an execution against his goods forâ€”I did not receive 7l. 4s. of Osmond, and tell you I had not had a shillingâ€”you drew 10s. from himâ€”I gave you an order to do soâ€”you had no business there, nor I either; however, that don't matterâ€”you were not subpoened in the case.

JOHN FORD (examined by the prisoner). Q. Do you remember seeing Mr. Glass at our house on 16th July last, the afternoon of Friday? A. On 16th August I saw him thereâ€”he came in, and my mother gave him 5l. and I saw him

sign the receiptâ€”I saw you draw up the receipt and he sign itâ€”he read the receipt before he signed itâ€”I should know the paper if I was to see it againâ€”this is it (looking at the receipt produced)â€”I and mother were present when he received the money and signed the receiptâ€”he shook hands with you, and wished you a pleasant journey to London.

Q. Did you ever see Mr. Glass, at my house, make out any bills for me to get in debts for him? A. I have seen him there on business, but I can't say what it was aboutâ€”I have seen him there, it may be five or six times, some
times before you were up.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Was this at a public-house? A. No; at a private houseâ€”I am quite June of thatâ€”I and my mother and father were there aloneâ€”there was a little child running about the house, but I can't say that she was in the roomâ€”there was no one else thereâ€”it was on 16th August; I am sure of that, on Friday eveningâ€”I was first asked about this when my father came to London, when I heard the charge made against himâ€”my father asked me about itâ€”he asked if I could recol
lect seeing Mr. Glass sign the receipt, and I told him yes.

Q. Where was Mr. Glass sitting when you say he signed it? A. Well, he generally stands, with his back to the wallâ€”I can't recollect whether he was sitting or standing when he wroteâ€”I was sitting having my teaâ€”this part if Mr. Glass's writing (pointing to it); father wrote the otherâ€”he wrote it before Mr. Glass's eyes when he was thereâ€”I don't know any reason why Mr. Glass did not write the other partâ€”I am quite sure that it was not in July that he paid the moneyâ€”I do not know of any money being paid by my father on 16th Julyâ€”I did not go to the police-courtâ€”I was not asked to goâ€”I was not at home at the time.
Prisoner. Q. You have not seen me since I have been in custody, have you? A. No.

Prisoner's Defence. I cannot say any more than that Mr. Glass signed the document, and I received the money in London to pay witnesses, and to pay Mr. Todd to go to trial; unless I had he would not do it. The prosecutor gave me a list of the witnesses. He gave me the order after I told him he had made a mistake in putting 95, Newgate-street, instead of 75. I paid him 5l. on account of the money in August, as the receipt bears date, only it is dated the 17th, instead of the 16th, by mistake; the 17th was on a Saturday, and it was signed on Friday. I paid Mr. Todd 5l., andâ€”I paid 10s. to a man of the name of Merry as a witness, and 15s. on another occasion, and the rest went towards my debt, for what I did for him, in going about the country. The reason of it all is this: I was to have 40l. for drawing up an assignment for him, upon which he has received 500l. since I have been in prison. The man who deposited it in hits hands signed, in my presence, "William Henry" and would not sign any farther, and his relations have put in a claim for the 500l.; and I should never have been here had it not been that I made known my views of it, that it was signed "William Henry" only, and he wants to get rid of me. I leave it in your hands. I am inno
cent of the charge that is laid against me; if I had been guilty I should not have gone twice to the bank about the 10l. note; but I told the clerk I would pay the expense of their sending the note up to the Bank of England. They charged 1s. 7d. for making the inquiry. I must have been well aware that the note had my name and address on it, and would be evidence against me if I committed myself in any way. He was going to pay me in sove
reigns, and I asked him to give me a 10l. note. Had it not been for the 500l. that this man got through my instrumentslity, I should not have been
here, only he thought I should turn round and assist the widow; but he never gave me a shilling for it.
NOT GUILTY .

107.
JAMES CONNELL (21)
, Feloniously, carnally knowing and abusing
Mary Ann Oxford, a girl under the age of 10 years.

GUILTY .â€”
Seven Years Penal Servitude.

108.
WILLIAM FLICKER (18), and
CHARLOTTE BELTZ (16)
, Robbery on the person of
Martha von Muller, and stealing 1 purse and other articles, her property.Second Count, receiving the same.

MABTHA VON MULLER . I am a widow, and reside at 2, Euston-squareâ€”on the afternoon of 9th November last I was in that neighbourhoodâ€”I had a porte-monnaie with me, which contained between 9s. and 10s. worth of loose silver, 3s. or 4s. worth of postage stamps, some envelopes, and a cheque for 8l. 6s. 8d.â€”this is the cheque (produced)â€”the porte-monnaie was in my handâ€”I had a small tradesman's book at the same time, and I felt them both wrenched from me, but I clasped them tighter, and was turning round to see who it was, when my hand was knocked, which opened my hand, and my purse and the book were taken from meâ€”it was a boy who knocked it out of my handâ€”I cannot identify any one present as being that personâ€”I followed himâ€”he ran away directly, through Euston-grove, past the hotels, into Drummond-streetâ€”I gave information to a policeman directly I saw one.
COURT. Q. You only saw the boy run away? A. No; another boy stopped me, and tried to detain me by asking me what was the matter.

MATTHEW HAMILTON . I live at 17, Polygon, Clarendon-square, and am a gasfitterâ€”on the afternoon of 9th November last, I was standing in front of the terminus of the railway at Euston-square, and saw the male prisoner running with a piece of paper in his hand, which I thought looked like a 5l. noteâ€”I am quite sure he is the personâ€”Mrs. Von Muller came up shortly afterwards, and complained that she had been robbed.

Flicker. Q. What time was this committed? A. little after 4 in the afternoonâ€”I did not come and give evidence against you before, because I was not summoned to come up; if I had been, I should have comeâ€”you were not looking at the cheque; you were carrying it in your hand.
Flicker. The policeman has got him for a fake witness against me, or why did he not come up before? I am innocent of the case, and I can prove that I was somewhere else.
Witness. I had never seen the prisoner before that day, but I know his face, and am quite sure of himâ€”I was up before the Magistrate when he was committed, and I identified him there.

JAMES WARNER . I am barman to Mr. Arkrill, at the Golden Compasses, Fitzroy-street, Euston-roadâ€”on the evening of 9th November last, the female prisoner came and asked my master for change, for a cheque for 8l. 6s. 8d.â€”I was by the side of him at the timeâ€”she said, "Will you change this cheque for Mr. Carter?"â€”Mr. Arkrill called me on one side, and sent me across to Mr. Carter; he is a doctor immediately oppositeâ€”I went, and came back very soonâ€”in consequence of what Mr. Carter said, Mr. Arkrill changed itâ€”the girl had been over to Mr. Carter firstâ€”on my return my master gave her change for the cheque, on account of what Mr. Carter said, and she leftâ€”two or three days afterwards, on the Monday morning, it âœ—at the bank when Mr. Arkrill presented it; and in the evening

I went, in company with some police-officer, to the Queen's theatre, and pointed the female prisoner out to the officerâ€”she was sitting with the male prisoner and two others, male and femaleâ€”they were together, sitting side by sideâ€”we saw them together afterwards, before they were taken in custodyâ€”I gave her in custody to Merrick, the policeman.

CHARLIES MERRICK (Policeman, S 328). On 13th November, between 8 and 9 o'clock in the evening, from information given to me, I went, in com
pany with the last witness, to the Queen's theatreâ€”I there saw the two prisoners; they were sitting together in the galleryâ€”I told the female that she was charged with changing a cheque at Mr. Arkrill's, which had been stolen from a ladyâ€”she said, "I do not know what you mean; I have not seen any cheque"â€”I told her she must come with me to the stationâ€”on the way she told me she would say all about itâ€”she said she met with a gentleman in Upper Fitzroy-street, Fitzroy-square, who gave her the cheque to get cashed, and he would give her half a sovereignâ€”she took it to Mr. Arkrill's, and got change, and he only gave her 5s. for her troubleâ€”she did not know himâ€”he was a strangerâ€”on the next afternoon, from information I received from Hamilton, I stopped at the police-court, and about half-past 3 o'clock the male prisoner came thereâ€”I saw him outside the court, went up to him, and asked what he was doing thereâ€”he said he had come to see Charlotteâ€”I told him I should apprehend him for being concerned with another in stealing a porte-monnaie; that I had got a description of him, and he must go with me to the stationâ€”he said, "I will go with you, but I will see Charlotte first," and as I was laying hold of him by the coat he knocked my arm up, and stooped down and ran away as fast as he couldâ€”I followed him for about three-quarters of a mileâ€”he was stopped by a gentleman, and I laid hold of himâ€”he said, "All right; I will go with you now, but there is another one in it; if I had had ten yards more start of you, you would not have caught me.

RICHARD CARTER . I am a surgeon, of 7, Upper Fitzroy-street, Euston-roadâ€”this cheque was brought to my surgery on 9th November, by a young woman bearing a resemblance to the female prisoner, but I cannot be positive it was herâ€”I did not give her the cheque with a request that she should get it changed for meâ€”she said she came from a patient of mine, of the name of Simmonds, a laundress, and would I oblige her with change for the chequeâ€”I said I had not change, but probably she would get it at the baker's oppositeâ€”I never advised her to go to Mr. Arkrill, or mentioned his nameâ€”some time afterwards the witness Warner came to me with the cheque, and asked if I knew itâ€”I said no, I did not know the cheque, but the person the girl said she came from I did know, and she was a respectable woman.

Flicker's Defence. I can prove that I was at home at the time of the robbery, working with my father at his business. I went to the Queen's theatre along with this girl, and as I was seen in her company I went down to ask her what she was locked up for. She would not tell me, Next day I went to see if I could hear her trial, and the policeman took me.

Beltz's Defence. I an not guilty of knowing the note was stolen; I am only guilty of changing it. A gentleman, who was looking at the Lord Mayor's show, asked me to change it. I did not know there was any harm in it. I gave the gentleman the money, and he gave me 5s. I told the constable all about it directly he asked me. When I was remanded this young man came to see me. I know no more of him than that I work for

his mother, and a few friends came down to see me as well as him. The following week no witness was there; when we came up the second time the policeman said, "I will put you away if I can," and the third week he brings up this old man to swear he saw this young man running with a note in his hand. It is very strange and unlikely that a thief would stop to pick a note out from a lot of money; and if he ran past him quickly it is not likely he should see him so distinctly as to know him again in a different dress at the end of three weeks. My mother can prove that I was indoors all the Saturday till half-past 7 in the evening.
ELLEN BELTZ . I am the prisoner's motherâ€”on the 9th November she was indoors till half-past 7â€”she has never lived away from me.

Cross-examined by MR. MCDONNELL. Q. Were you at home the whole afternoon of Saturday, the 9th November? A. Yes; and my daughter was in the same room with me, at needle workâ€”I was working about and cleaning upâ€”I know she did not go out before 7â€”there was no clock in the room, but I knew the time.

JURY. Q. What has been her character? A. I have had no fault to find with herâ€”she has borne a good character, but I suppose every one has some faultâ€”she has always earned her own living in an honest way.

SUSAN FLICKER . The male prisoner is my sonâ€”he was at home at work along with his father at the time the robbery was committedâ€”it was the evening of the 9thâ€”I saw it in the newspaper the next day, and the girl's nameâ€”my son was at home all day with me and his father till after we had done our work; 9 o'clockâ€”he was working at tailoring workâ€”he was not out of the house at all.

Cross-examined. Q. How does he gain his livelihood? A. He has learnt the tailoring trade, and he was so employed on the 9th with his father, at 50, High-street, Bloomsbury, where we resideâ€”he was at home the whole of that day, and so was Iâ€”he went out in the evening between 9 and 10, I think; not before thatâ€”I saw this account in the paper, with the young girl's name, and I looked about to the 9th, when my son was taken up, and called to mind thatâ€”he was at home at the timeâ€”he was employed sewing up trousersâ€”his father is not here; he has very bad healthâ€”he is able to come, but he is not hereâ€”I cannot remember now what it was that took my son out that evening, but he generally goes out of an eveningâ€”I know it was between 9 and 10 that he went out, by our supper-timeâ€”we generally leave off work about 9â€”he had his supper before he went outâ€”I swear that from the morning, until between 9 and 10 at night, he did not go outâ€”none of my neighbours were there during the eveningâ€”her brother was thereâ€”he is not hereâ€”he has been learning the tailoring off and on for these two years.

COURT. Q. You say you saw in the newspaper an account of the robbery? A. Yes; and I have known this girl a long time, and never knew any harm of herâ€”she was to and fro my place, and I thought of the name directlyâ€”I knew she knew my son, and it struck me directly that my son was not out that eveningâ€”he had not been charged at that timeâ€”his character has not been so good as I could wish, but still I am in hopes he may be betterâ€”he has been very good and steady since he has been from sea, and learning the business; never out late, and never away from home.
MR. MCDONNELL. Q. Don't you know that he has been convicted? A. Yes; I am aware of that; on one or two occcasions.

FLICKERâ€”
GUILTY on First Count.

BELTZâ€”
GUILTY on Second Count.â€”
Confined Three Months.

p.hi: Flicker was further charged with having been before convicted.

div1.p: JOHN TUCKER (Policeman, E 168). I produce a certificateâ€”(This certified the conviction of Thomas Flicker, on his own confession, at the Westminster Police Court, in March, of larceny.â€” Confined Six Months)â€”the prisoner is the person to whom that appliesâ€”I was present when he was convicted.

GUILTY.**â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

div0.p:
PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald. COPELAND; Mr. Ald. SALOMONS, M.P.; Mr. RECORDER; and
SIR HENRY MUGGERIDGE , Knt. Ald.

div1.p:
109.
ALFRED THOMPSON (25)
, Feloniously being at large without lawful excuse before the expiration of the period of six years' penal servitude, to which he was sentenced in November, 1859; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
