Six Years' Penal Servitude. (See next case.)

110.
GEORGE CARPENTER (25)
, Unlawfully assaulting
Samuel Doble, a police constable, in the execution of his duty, and attempting to rescue
Alfred Thompson from his custody.

THOMAS POTTER (Policeman, D 2). I produce a certificate of the conviction of Alfred Thompson (Read: "Guildhall Sessions, November, 1859. Alfred Thompson convicted of being found by night with housebreaking implements, having been previously convicted of felony.â€”Sentence Six Years' Penal Servitude")â€”I was present at the trialâ€”Thompson is the person (pointing him out)â€”he was in my custodyâ€”he escaped from Portsmouth, and I received information on the same day.

SAMUEL DOBLE . On Saturday, 25th November, I saw the prisoner and Thompson in the Marylebone-roadâ€”I was with a constable in plain clothesâ€”I told him somethingâ€”I told Thompson in the prisoner's presence that I should follow him and take him in custodyâ€”they ran away, and I halloed "Stop thief!"â€”I followed Thompson 100 yardsâ€”Carpenter turned round and took Pink by the throatâ€”I caught Thompson, and he caught me violently in the privates two or three times, and said, "You bâ€”r, you shall never take poor Alf. back to do his time"â€”I succeeded in keeping himâ€”I believe he has some complaint to make against me.

Prisoner. Q. What distance did I run? A. About sixty yardsâ€”you did not attempt to stop meâ€”I was in front of youâ€”I followed Thompson, Pink followed me, and you after himâ€”Pink was bleeding at the throat when I came upâ€”you said at the station that you were not aware you were in such bad company.

GEORGE PINK (Policeman, D 85). I was with Potter when he met Thompson and the prisonerâ€”I pursued Thompson, and the prisoner seized me by the throat and kicked me violentlyâ€”I said to him, "Let me go, it is not you I want"â€”he said, "No, you bâ€”r, it is poor Alf. you want to send back to do his time"â€”I tried to get away from him, but could not till my brother constable came up, when the prisoner wrenched himself away from my throat, and flung himself upon Doble, trying to separate him from Thompson, and he did so several times between there and the station.

Prisoner. Q. Did I lay hold of your throat with both hands? A. Yesâ€”you had an old pair of boots under your arm, but you dropped them, and a person standing by gave them to youâ€”I did not take you by the collar and
ask you what you had in your possession, nor did you say that you would not tell me till you knew who I wasâ€”the parcel was not undone till you got to the station.
Prisoner's Defence. I am innocent.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

111.
THOMAS THOMPSON (32)
, Stealing 1 necklet, value 68l. 10s., the property of
James Attenborough, in his dwelling-house.

CHARLES LIWINS . I am assistant to Mr. Attenborough of the Strandâ€”on 14th November, the prisoner and another man came into the shopâ€”the prisoner said he had just arrived from America, and had been in England fourteen days, that the weather had been so extremely unfavourable, he had not been able to get out much; that he had a niece who was going to India, and he wished to make her a present before she leftâ€”I introduced a brilliant bird necklet, which he liked very much, but asked to look at a teapotâ€”I brought from the window a beautiful little silver kettle, which he liked very much; his friend admired it alsoâ€”they said they should not decide that dayâ€”the prisoner said that he should be taking a carriage drive, and most likely his niece would call with himâ€”on Saturday, 16th November, about half-past 4, they both called again, and said they had come to decide about the neckletâ€”in the mean time I had procured a few more to show himâ€”he said that he wished to see no other than the one he had seen beforeâ€”I took it from the window and placed it on the glass caseâ€”he took it up and said, "It is the prettiest thing I ever saw in my life"â€”he showed it to his friend, who noddedâ€”he then said, "I will take it"â€”I said, "The price is 68l. 10s."â€”he said, "I am perfectly aware of the price; you have told me once, and I never forget these things; I will take it, and I will pay for it"â€”he put his hand in his pocket to pay for itâ€”I closed the lid, and was going to pack itâ€”he then said, "By the way, there is the teapot"â€”I said, "You mean the kettle"â€”I ordered the porter to go to the window and take it from the window, because I would not leave the neckletâ€”the moment he saw the kettle he said, "That is not the one I saw before, the one I saw before was, a much larger kettle"â€”I assured him that it was the same, as we had no other so smallâ€”he said, "Well, I may be mistaken, I thought it was not the same; could you tell me how much it holds?"â€”I said, "It is what we should call a three pint kettle"â€”he said, "Do not you know what it contains; it is necessary I should know what it holds, because I am about to make it a present to a friend of mine, who intends using it for chemical purposes, and it will be perfectly useless unless I know what it contains; if not too much trouble perhaps you will fetch some water and try it"â€”I hesitated rather, but said to the porter, "Fetch the water, we will fill itâ€”the water was brought, and in the act of pouring it in, the prisoner's friend moved round to his rightâ€”the prisoner said, "I thought it was not the size, I must think it over again, we had much better call again"â€”they both hurriedly went towards the door, and left the shop, which excited my suspicionâ€”I lifted up the necklet case and the necklet was not thereâ€”I ran towards the door, turned to a side street, and saw the prisoner running as hard as he couldâ€”I shouted "Stop thief!"â€”he darted into Hungerford-market, turned into a cigar shop, and threw himself into a corner like a ball, so that I had gone in in a hurry I should not have seen himâ€”I had the door closed and accused him immediately of stealing a brilliant bird neckletâ€”he said, "Sir, you are mistaken"â€”the mob round the door fetched in the police, and I gave him in chargeâ€”there were no other customers in the shop, but Mr. and Mrs. Attenborough, and their nephew, passed throughâ€”I am perfectly sure the prisoner is the man.

Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. Was not the man in the shop handing him a cigar to smoke? A. He was with his back towards me picking up a piece of woodâ€”I should have taken a light from the counterâ€”the two men were not in the shop more than five minutes, if so long, trying the tea-pot and inspecting it; six minutes at the outside, as the necklet was decided upon at onceâ€”I am quite sure the two men were the same as those that came at firstâ€”they both came in together as at firstâ€”I never spoke to the other oneâ€”the prisoner was my customerâ€”the necklet was put on the counter close by me, and the prisoner was close to it; there was only the distance of the counter between usâ€”they were both close togetherâ€”the prisoner was nearest to the neckletâ€”I kept my eye upon it of courseâ€”I was only showing one articleâ€”I shut the lid, and was in the act of packing it up when my attention was taken off by the kettleâ€”it was in the opposite windowâ€”the porter got it out; he is not here, it did not take him three seconds to get itâ€”some water was fetched, and my eyes were on both the articlesâ€”I am quite positive that nobody came in while I had one eye on the tea-pot, and the other on the neckletâ€”I lost sight of them both when they went outâ€”I was, of course, excited at losing such an ornament, but I was quite clearâ€”no necklet was found on the prisoner.

MATTHEW ROBINSON (Policeman, F 166). On Saturday afternoon, 16th November, I went into a shop in Hungerford-market, and the prisoner was given into my charge by the last witness, who charged him with stealing a diamond neckletâ€”I took him to the station, searched him, and found a gold watch and guard, and locket, 7s. 6d., a cigar case, tooth pick, and pocket-handkerchiefâ€”he refused to give his place of residence.
GUILTY .
He was further charged with having been before convicted at Lambeth Police-court, in June, 1849, by the name of Thomas Brooks; to which he pleaded guilty, upon which the Jury found a verdict of

GUILTY.â€”
Three Years Penal Servitude. There were two other similar indictments against the prisoner.

112.
WILLIAM CATER (58)
, Stealing 2 sleeves, and 2 collars, value 2s. of
Lousia Sohmits, in a vessel on the Thames.

THOMAS EDWARD MOGG . I am examining officer of Customs at Graves
endâ€”on the evening of 16th November, I boarded the steamer Seine from Boulonge to Gravesend at about 5 in the eveningâ€”the prisoner was a sea
man on board that vesselâ€”it was my duty to examine the passengers' lug
gageâ€”I examined it in midships, and the prisoner was employed to carry it aftâ€”after I had examined a box, which proves to belong to Miss Sehmits, I gave it to the prisoner to take it aft, where all goods are deposited after undergoing examinationâ€”he threw it down, whether wilfully or not I do not know, but I believe so, and several of the articles fell on the deckâ€”I went aft, picked them up, put them carefully in the box, and put the lid onâ€”I remonstrated with the prisoner, and told him if it occurred again I should complain to the captainâ€”five or ten minutes elapsed when I saw the prisoner slowy and deliberately go to the identical box, raise the lid, take several articles and put them in his pocketâ€”I walked aft to him and ordered him to the gangway, then in the presence of Miss Schmits and several other passengers, I ordered him to deliver up the goods he had stolen from the boxâ€”he said I have not touched the box sinceâ€”I said, "I saw you take several things from the box, and if you do not give them up voluntarily, I shall be compelled to take them from you"â€”he begged my pardon, and said that he trusted 1 would not report himâ€”I again ordered him to take the things out

of his pocket, and he produced two sleeves, and two collars, which Miss Schmitz recognised as her propertyâ€”on the arrival of the vessel at Freeh
wharf, I communicated the whole facts to the captain of the vessel.

Prisoner. He has made a very great mistake in saying that he saw me put the things in my pocket, after the box broke, I never went near it; I never had it in my charge, and never saw him put the things in. Witness. When I remonstrated with you, I said, get a piece of cord and lash this up.

LOUISE SCHMITZ . I am single, and live at 168, Albany-street, Regent's-parkâ€”on 16th November, I was a passenger on board the Seine, and was present when Mr. Mogg spoke to the prisoner, I was standing at my lug
gage, and was called to see my things examinedâ€”I had a bandbox on board, in which were several sleeves and collarsâ€”I heard Mr. Mogg accuse the prisoner, he then asked me whether I identified the articles which were taken from the prisoner's handâ€”I said, yes; they were two collars and two sleeves which had been in my band-box.

ROBERT PACKMAN . I am a dective officer of the City-policeâ€”in cones
quence of information, I searched for the prisoner and found him on 11th. December, in George-street, Minoriesâ€”I told him I was a police-officer, and took him for stealing, on 16th November, from a box on board the vessel Seine, between Boulogne and London, some sleeves and other articles belonging to a ladyâ€”the prisoner said, "I picked some things up, but did not steal them."
The Prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read at follows: "I had made rather too free with the bottle and the glass.

COURT to THOMAS EDWARD MOGG. Q. Was the prisoner sober? A. I do not think he was exactly; he was a little under the influence of drink, but nothing to prevent his knowing what he was aboutâ€”he knew perfectly well, especially after my remonstrating with him.

Prisoner's Defence. I picked the things up on deck, and as soon as the officer asked me for them I gave them to him. If I had known there would have, been any noise about it I should have given myself up long before. The Captain would give me a character, but has been obliged to go awayâ€”a gentleman has been here two days to speak on my behalf. I have lost my situation.

GUILTY .â€”Recommended to mercy by the Jury.â€”
Confined Three Months.

113.
DAVID COCKRANE (25)
, Stealing 2s. in, money the property of
Frederick Helrigel, from the person of
Jane Helrigel.

JANE HELRIGEL . I am eleven years old, and live with my parents in Long-lane, West Smithfieldâ€”on Saturday night about, a fortnight ago, I was going on an errand fur my father in King-street, Smithfieldâ€”I had 2s. 3d. in my hand, and was going to get some napthaâ€”the prisoner came up and asked me if I was going down thereâ€”I said, "Yes"â€”he said, "There are some thieves down there, they have knocked a little girl down, and stolen half a crown from her," and asked me if I had any moneyâ€”I said, "Yes"â€”he asked me to give it to him and he would wrap it upâ€”he would not give it to me till we got to the corner, and then I opened it and there was only threepence in itâ€”I told a policeman, and he walked with me, but the prisoner could not be foundâ€”my father sent a gentleman to the stationâ€”a gentleman came and fetched me to the station the same night, and I picked the prisoner out from a lot of personsâ€”that was about a week back.
WILLIAM HOBSON (City-policeman, 522). I took the prisoner on another charge.

Prisoner's Defence. I think it a very unfair thing that I should have been charged previously on another charge, and this girl was allowed to be in Court all the time; she could hear that the. two charges tallied with one another.
GUILTY .

114.
DAVID COCKRANE was again indicted
for stealing 7s., the pro
perty of
Richard Garner, from the person of
Joseph Garner.

JOSEPH GARNER . I am ten years old, and live with my father at 10, White's-courtâ€”on a Saturday at the end of August Mrs. Shaddock, who I work for, sent me out to receive 7s. 3d., which I was to take home to herâ€”I met the prisoner, who told me there were some thieves on London-bridgeâ€”that was the way I was goingâ€”he took me down Bush-lane, asked me for the money, and said that he would wrap it up; he wrapped it up in paper, and when I got home there was only threepenceâ€”last Saturday week he came up to me again on London-bridge, and said that there were two boys coming over the bridge who had knocked down another boy and stolen half a crownâ€”he then said, "Not boys, but men"â€”I said, "Yes, and you robbed me of 7s"â€”he ran across the road behind a cartâ€”I told a gentleman, and a police
man took the prisoner in custody.

WILLIAM HOBSON (City-policeman, 522). I was on duty on London-bridge, received information, and took the prisonerâ€”the last witness said, "That man stole 7s. of me some weeks ago"â€”I said, "Are you sure he is the man?"â€”he said, "I am, and my brother knows him as well as me"â€”I said, "Where is your brother?"â€”he said, "In Vine-street, Bermondsey"â€”I took the prisoner there, and the brother said, "Yes, that is the mail," before the last witness had communicated anything to him.

Prisonr's Defence. I was going towards Camberwell-gate to see if I could see an apprentice who was working over there, and in getting out of the way of a drunken man, 1 knocked against this boy, who said, "You are the man who robbed me of 7s." I never accosted him or spoke to him at all. I said, "You must be mistaken. I saw a person I knew, on the other side of the road in a cart, so I went across to him, and the boy came to me with a policeman and gave me in charge; the inspector said at the station that most likely there would be another charge against me. The girl said that I had light hair and grey whiskers, and was about thirty-six years of age. On the Monday I was placed between several policemen all much taller than me, and all had hats on, and they picked me out at once. About the time this" boy speaks of, I was confined to my bed with a swelling of my thigh, which is not thoroughly cured yet.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

115.
JOHN LINDON (20)
, Stealing I watch, value 3l., the property of
Henry Syer Bristow, from his person.

HENRY SYER BRISTOW . I am a collector, living at 52, Marlborough-road, Peckhamâ€”on 9th December, about half-past 7 in the evening, I was in King William-streetâ€”I had a watch with meâ€”I was very ill indeed, and was walking with some difficulty by Mr. Deane's shopâ€”I felt for my watch and missed itâ€”I cannot say who took it.

JOHN NUGENT . I am assistant to a grocer of 4, Crown-row, Walworth-roadâ€”on the evening of 9th December I was near Mr. Deane's shop in King William-street, going home, and saw the old gentleman, Mr. Bristow, going towards London-bridgeâ€”he was very feeble, and was supporting him
self

by the sash of Mr. Dane's windowâ€”a crowd gathered round him, and the prisoner and another man passed as it were over the bridge, and came backâ€”the man who it not in custody spoke to the old gentleman, who was leaning backâ€”he leaned over him, but I did not hear whatpassedâ€”while he was speaking to the old gentleman, the prisoner was close to his side; he had a cape onâ€”he had his hand raised, and his cape over itâ€”I did not see a watch, but I saw the prisoner's hand move and then he let it down and went away as quick as he could towards Arthur-streetâ€”I told a policeman what had occurred, and saw the prisoner go round King William-street; he was going between two wagons in Pudding-lane with his cape on his armâ€”he looked back, and the policeman caught him by the collar and said something to himâ€”he was taken back to the old gentleman in my presence, who said that he could not say whether he was the man or not.

Cross-examined by MR. LEWIS, Q. flow many people were around the old gentleman? A. I should think there were about forty before the pri
soner and the other man came upâ€”they passed through the crowd partly, at that timeâ€”they passed the prosecutor, looked at him, and came back againâ€”the prisoner then had a cape onâ€”this lasted about two minutes, and then they walked away together.
COURT. Q. How near was he to the prosecutor when his hand was lifted up? A. Quite close to him, standing on his right side.
COURT to H. S. BRISTOW. Q. In which pocket did you wear your watch, on your right-hand side? A. Yea, in my waistcoat pocket.

THOMAS JOSEPH OKILL . I am office-boy at 44, Lime street on 9th December, about half-past seven in the evening, I was in King William-street, and saw a crowd by Messrs. Deane'a shopâ€”I saw the prisoner thereâ€”thought the old man was run overâ€”he was leaning against the wallâ€”and as I was going up my attention was drawn to the prisoner by something glittering in his handâ€”I saw that it was a watch, and he was trying to get out of the crowdâ€”I kept sight of him, and a policeman came up and took himâ€”I followed to the station.

MORRISS WALSH . (City-policeman, 530). I was on duty in King William-street, near the statue, on 9th December, and saw a crowd opposite Mr. Deane's shopâ€”I received information, went across into Eastcheap and saw the prisoner with a cape on. his armâ€”he. turned down Padding-lane, and went between two wagons.â€”I went over, laid hold of him, and told him he was charged with stealing a watch in King William-street, from an old gentleman, and to hand it out to meâ€”he said, "So help me Christ, I did not have it"â€”I said, "If you have not got it, your companion has"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”I took him back, and asked the old gentleman if he had lost his watchâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”I said, "Did you see this person?"â€”he said that he had no recollection, he was quite unconsciousâ€”he seemed very feeble and nervousâ€”I told the prisoner that Nugent would charge himâ€”he said that he should not go to the station; he would kick my brains outâ€”he struggled violently with me: he put his foot before me and tried to throw me down, I had to force him into the passage of a house till I could get assistanceâ€”he said that he was a travelling tailor.

Cross-examined. Q. Had anybody charge of him when you went up to him? A. No. I seized him by the collar, with my fist insideâ€”my knuckles were not running into his throatâ€”I am quite sure he said that his companion had the watchâ€”when I asked him, he said, "Yes"â€”I will swear he did not say "Oh, yes"

GUILTY .**â€ â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

116.
EDWARD JONES (28)
, Stealing I holland table-cover, value 10s., the property of
John Compton and another, the
churchwardens of the parish of Saint George-in-the-East.

SARAH THICKER . I am the wife of Christian Thicket, and am pew
opener at the pariah church of Saint George's-in-the-Eastâ€”the church
wardens are, John Compton and John Corrieâ€”on a Friday in the month of May I was cleaning the church, and missed the cover of the communion table, which I had placed there on the Wednesdayâ€”this is it (produced)â€”I can swear to it.

Prisoner. Q. By what means? A. Because I never saw one made like itâ€”it has a large piece fastened up behindâ€”I have tried it on, and it fits exactlyâ€”our's is a larger table than any in Londonâ€”I hate had the care of the cover for a year and a halfâ€”it is made straight, and the corners are rounded at the ends like the cloth which it has to coverâ€”they are usually made straightâ€”the man made this one as he made the red cover, which is un
usual, and it has been unpicked in two places.

AMILIA FIFE . I am the wife of Alfred Fife, of 3, Crown-streetâ€”the prisoner lodged in our house from 17th May to 8th June, when he left on Saturday without notice and never returnedâ€”I pointed out his rooms to Inspector Allisonâ€”nobody had occupied them in the mean time.

GEORGE ALLISON (Police-inspector). In consequence of information I received in the beginning of July, I went to Mrs. Fife'sâ€”she pointed out certain rooms to me, in which I found this table-cover, thirty-five dupli
cates, several parts of surplices, a font, and an alms' dishâ€”I afterwards found the prisoner at Maidstone, and told him I took him for robbing St. Ann's, Limehouse, and Saint George's-in-the-East of prayer-books and other thingsâ€”he said, "I suppose they call it a simple larceny."
Prisoner's Defence. I do not see that the evidence shows that I was near the church. The table-cloth is a difficult thing to swear to, and it is very unsatisfactory to do so.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

p.hi: There was another indictment against the prisoner.

div1.p:
117.
WILLIAM WARD (18), and
WILLIAM RIDDINGTON (23)
, Stealing 54 lbs. of beef, value 50s., the property of
John Edward Bannister and another, in their dwelling-house; and
WILLIAM WILLIS (23), and
JOHN HUMPHREYS (36),
feloniously receiving the same; to which

WARD
PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

JAMES HAND (City-policeman, 360). I am often employed in plain clothesâ€”I have known Humphreys some years, and I knew Ward before this matterâ€”in consequence of information, I watched Humphreys to Pleydell-street, which turns out of Bouverie-street, Fleet-streetâ€”I saw him come out of a house there about 5 o'clock on Monday morning, 2d December; he went down Fleet-street, Ludgate-hill and St Paul's church-yard, into Cheapside, where he joined Willis at the end of King-streetâ€”they both went to the end of Iron monger-lane, remained in conversation a few minutes; Willis then left Humphreys, and went down the lane, to the back entrance in Iron
monger-lane, of Mr. Bannister's premises, 2, King-streetâ€”he remained two or three minutes, then left, joined Humphreys, and went to King-street, where he took some coffee of a man who stood there, and I left him in St Paul's churchyardâ€”next morning, about 5 o'clock, I saw Willis and Hum
phreys come out of Pleydell-street, from the direction of Humphre's house; they went to Cheapside, stopped at the corner of Ironmonger-lane, and con
versed

for two or three minutes; Willis left Humphreys at the end of the lane, and went to the back entrance of Mr. Bannister's premises; he knocked at the door, it was opened, and almost immediately two hind-quarters of mutton were handed out to him by some one, who I did not see; he put it on his back and walked away with it, joined Humphreys, and they walked up Cheapside together, I crossed over the street, and saw Riddington at a little distance from the door in Ironmonger-laneâ€”he turned into Cheapside, and went on to the right side, carrying two basketsâ€”this is one of them (pro
duced)â€”they appeared very heavy, and when he got about twenty yards from the top of Cheapside, near St. Paul's, he crossed over to the left side,. to Humphreys and Willis, and gave Humphreys one of the baskets he was carryingâ€”Humphreys then left Willis and Riddington, and went down Pateruoster-rowâ€”I followed Riddington and Willis into Fleet-street, and with the assistance of another constable, stopped them and asked them where they were going with that meat; Riddington said, "It belongs to a man named Humphreys, who lives in Pleydell-street"â€”I said that I knew where they had got the meat, for I saw them take it from Mr. Bannister's premisesâ€”I said "I saw you at the door"â€”he said "Yes, I did; but I have never done so before"â€”I returned to Mr. Bannister's about 8 o'clock, and saw Wardâ€”I found a silver side of salt beef weighing 27 lbs.â€”I also took possession of the hind quarters of mutton.

Cross-examined by MR. LAWRENCE. Q. Did Willis tell you that he did not know that the meat was stolen? A. I do not recollect itâ€”he did not say that he had been sent for the meat, and did not know there was anything wrong about itâ€”he did not give me to understand that he did not know that the meat had been improperly taken, nothing to that effectâ€”he said that he had never done so beforeâ€”he is not in Messrs. Bannister's employ
mentâ€”he is, I believe, a butcherâ€”he said nothing to me about Humphreys sending him; Riddington said thatâ€”Willis did not mention Humphreys' name.

Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. Was Humphreys a jobber in Newgate
market? A. I never knew him in any work for some years.

JOHN EDWARD BANNISTER . I am the junior partner in the firm of Ban
nister and Sonâ€”Ward was in our employment; he slept on the premisesâ€”it was his duty to get up early and let the men inâ€”I have seen the meat and identified itâ€”neither of the prisoners were in our employment.

Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. I believe you know something of butchers, and their course of life. A. Yes; they are compelled to be called up early on certain mornings, for Smithfield-marketâ€”meat is brought into the market very early every morningâ€”they do not call one anotherâ€”the police generally call them.

JOHN MORGAN . I am in the prosecutor's serviceâ€”I mined a silver side of salted beef, and a pair of hind-quarters of muttonâ€”I saw them afterwards at the police-courtâ€”I had seen Humphreys and Ward together recently, before this transaction, near the shopâ€”Humphreys was employed there frequently.

ALFRED GREEN (Policeman). I took Humphreys at his lodging in Pleydell-streetâ€”I told him I charged him with being concerned with Mr. Bannister's lad of King-street, Cheapside, and two others in custody, of robbing Mr. Bannister of a quantity of meat on Wednesday morningâ€”I afterwards said, "Yesterday morning, Tuesday morning"â€”he said, "I was not in Cheap
side at all"â€”he afterwards said to me, "Is Mr. Bannister's man in custody?"â€”I said, "Yes"â€”he said, "Has he said anything?"â€”I said, "I cannot

answer you that question"â€”I had seen Humphreys and Ward togetherâ€”I watched, and saw Humphreys give Bannister's boy money on one occasionâ€”I think it was in Septemberâ€”I have been watching Humphreys at intervals for three months.
Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. Whether it was 1d. or 2d. you cannot say? A. I think it was silverâ€”I will not swear that it was not copper.

Riddington's Defence. On Tuesday morning I met Humphreys at the end of Cheapside; he asked me if I wanted a job, and I went with him to Mr. Bannister's door: a young man was at the door; I asked him for two baskets for Mr. Humphreys. He said, "Come in." I went in, the gas was alight; he gave me two baskets. Coming out, at the top of Ironmonger-lane, I saw Willis, and a little further on I saw Humphreys, who said, "Have you got them?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Go on ahead, I will catch you." I went on, turned round, and saw Humphreys and Willis together; Willis had the hind-quarter of a sheep on his back; he said to Humphreys, "Are you tired of them? if you are, give them to me," I went with Willis to Fleet-street; the policeman stopped me; I told him what it was, and who employed me. The young man never gave me anything. I know nothing more about it.

RIDDINGTONâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

WILLISâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

HUMPHREYSâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Four Year's Penal Servitude.

p.hi: The prisoner Ward stated that he acted under Humphrey's persuasion.

div1.p:
118.
JAMES AVIS (25), and
EDWARD TALLING (35)
Stealing 1 oil can and 5 gallons of oil, value 1l. 19s. 6d., the property of
Ralph Charles Price, their master.

WILLIAM MCNKIL . I live at Erith, and am manager to Messrs. Ralph Charles Price & Co., oil merchantsâ€”Talling has been employed there several years, and Avis two or three yearsâ€”Avis has always been carmanâ€”Talling's employment was to draw oil into casks to go out in wagonsâ€”from information I received, I went to the wagon on 7th December, about ten minutes past 9 o'clock, it was standing in King Edward-street, just drawn out from our premisesâ€”Avis was thereâ€”I asked him where he was goingâ€”he said, "To Wapping and the wharves"â€”I asked him if he was going any where else but to the places mentioned on the ticketsâ€”he said, "No"â€”I then asked him for his tickets, which he handed meâ€”after looking at them and seeing that there was no small parcel represented by that, I desired him to get into the van and give me out that drum of oil from under the tarpaulinâ€”it was not labelled or directedâ€”it is worth about 2l.â€”he said, "Talling gave it to me to dispose of"â€”I sent for a policeman and gave him in chargeâ€”each ticket mentions the place he is to go to, and the name of the wharf in so many ticketsâ€”it is sperm oilâ€”I cannot say whether it is mixed, because he had the command of all the cisternsâ€”it is the same kind as we had in the warehouseâ€”we have large quantities of drums about the premisesâ€”we have a town foreman and a country foremanâ€”Avis was the country carman to take out goods to country customers, to wharves, railways, and the likeâ€”if we are pressed, we may send country goods by the other carmanâ€”Talling's duty was to draw off the oil into casks or drums, and to give out both the country and town goodsâ€”Thompson, was the foreman for that serviceâ€”besides orders from Thompson, Talling would have orders from the town foreman, but that would be a separate wagonâ€”

Talling had not authority to give out goods to Avis unless the principal told himâ€”Talling had no authority to give Avis goods to dispose of in townâ€”I do not know of Avis having authority from anybody.

Cross-examined by MR. COOPER Q. Do you say that the tarpaulin was on the good's? A. Partiallyâ€”we have a tarpaulin with our wagons, and use it when the weather is badâ€”the goods in the wagon were oils; they would not take harm from dampâ€”Avis has been in our employ two or three yearsâ€”this is sperm oil, the best that can be burnt; the drums are common.

Cross-examined by MR. LEWIS. Q. If Thompson had really sent Avis for the oil, I suppose he would have been justified in giving it to Avis? A. Yes; if Avis told him that Thompson sent him for itâ€”it is the carman's business to see that he has a ticket for every place he is going to.

COURT. Q. Supposing Avis had said to Talling, that Thompson had sent him for oil, would he be justified in giving it? A. I should think not; it would be very irregular, for he ought to hive seen his van loaded before he left.

THOMAS JONES ANSELL . I live at Messrs. Price & Co.'s factory, Black
friars, and am a messenger in their employmentâ€”on 7th December, from information I received, I went and searched the van about half-past 8â€”it was in the yard; I found in it a five gallon drum of oil, at the fore part, rolled up in the tarpaulinâ€”there was no mark, number, or address on itâ€”Avis was the driver, bat he had not started with itâ€”I followed him out of the yard, hailed him, and told him to stay, as Mr. McNeil wished to speak to himâ€”he stayed, and Mr. McNeil went to him.

Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. Before you searched the wagon did you see Talling? A. Yes; at his warehouse doorâ€”the wagon was about twenty yards from that place when I first saw itâ€”the end of the tarpaulin was pulled in under the casks, and the drum of oil lay under the end of itâ€”the van was not quite fullâ€”the tarpaulin so placed would not preventthe things from falling out.
Cross-examined by MR. GIFPARD. Q. Was there room in the van for the drum behind? A. There was not; but there was in the fore part, without rolling it up in the tarpaulin.

PETER THOMPSON . I live at 10, Princes-street, Stamford-street, Black
friars, and am foreman in the country department of Messrs. Price'sâ€”it is part of my duty to tee the wagons loadedâ€”on the morning of 7th December, I superintended the loading of the goods in the van driven by Avis, from half-past 7 to 8 o'clockâ€”Avis was in the van, receiving the goods as raised by the crane I placed the direction on the various things as they were put inâ€”I did not see any drum of oilâ€”I gave no orders to put one in, nor was one put in in my presenceâ€”I know that there were one or two empty drums in Tailing's warehouseâ€”Talling had no right to fill any bottles or drams without personal authority from meâ€”if Avis went to him and said, "Mr. Thompson says I am to have a drum of oil, give me one," that would be irregular; he ought to have come and asked me firstâ€”I give delivery tickets to Avisâ€”I have got them with me; but there is no ticket for this drum of oilâ€”I have tickets for every article that he ought to deliverâ€”I put down the weight of the different articles put into the wagon in my rough book, and there is no mention of it at allâ€”Talling was assisting in putting the goods inâ€”I saw the loading of the wagon completed.
Cross-examined by MR. LEWI. Q. Have you never sent men for drums of oil? A. Yes; but not without his previous knowledge that I required such a thing.
MR. GIFFARD. Q. Had Avis authority to dispose of things in town? A. No; and he had no right to receive money without having an invoice.

JOHN BLACK (City-policeman, 427). Avis was given into my custody on Saturday morning, December 7th, about a quarter-past 9â€”I took him to the station, searched him, and found on him 17s. 5 3/4 d. in money, and two papersâ€”he said twice that Talling put the drum of oil into the wagon, and told him to dispose of itâ€”I went the same morning to the prosecutor's premises, saw Talling, and took him to the stationâ€”the sergeant told him the charge and pointed to the drum of oil that was standing thereâ€”he said that Avis had come to him and asked for the drum of oil for Mr. Thompson, and that he had given it to him, but did not know anything about itâ€”I searched him, but only found 4 1/2 d. on him.

(Avis received a good character.)â€”
GUILTY .â€”Recommended to mercy by the Jury and prosecutor.â€”
Confined Nine Months Each.

119.
GEORGE MC'GREGOR (34)
, Unlawfully obtaining of
Joseph Martin 3 account-books, value 10s. 6d.; also, 19 gross of flower boxes of
William Filmer; also, 126 yards of cocoa. matting of
Maria Bennett;also, 500 cards and I ream of note paper of
Joseph Dee, by false pretenees; to all of which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

120.
ALFRED LUCAS (22)
, Stealing 1 chest and 100 pounds' weight of tea, the property of
Joseph Hornby Baxendale, and others, his masters.

ALEXANDER MUIBHEAD . I am in the service of Joseph Hornby Baxen
dale, and others, of Haydon-squareâ€”the prisoner was a carman in their serviceâ€”he was with his van at the platform where I was loading on 27th November, at the west side of the premisesâ€”he took an odd line from thereâ€”that means all the lines except the North Westernâ€”I checked his load, and took an account of the goodsâ€”there was no chest of tea thereâ€”I have a copy of the bills that were given to himâ€”I took them in duplicate with a press.

MR. RIBTON. Q. When was it made? A. On the same day, and at the same time I make the originalâ€”it is sent to the railwayâ€”it is given to the carman to take to Whitechapelâ€”one was given to the prisoner, I belive it has gone to the railwayâ€”I do not know who made this copy.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Do you know, independentlv of this, whether a chest of tea, was put on that load? A. There was no chest of tea after taking the accountâ€”I took it up to the shipping office, the boy followed me thereâ€”it was the carman's duty to get the hillâ€”I had to check the goods before he drives awayâ€”I came down a few minutes afterwards and the van had then gone away from our platformâ€”that was before the bill was ready.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Were you present when the van was loading? A. Yes; I saw everythingâ€”there was fifteen articlesâ€”there were seven bags of tobacco, two paper parcels, an empty box, and a box of instru
ments from the Towerâ€”I saw them all put on.

HENRY COLE . I am a porter at Pickford's, and live at 4, Hereford-terraceâ€”it is my duty to pass the goods to Muirhead for the purpose of putting them on the vanâ€”I passed them to the prisoner's van on 27th November, to the carmanâ€”he did not put in a chest of teaâ€”I do not know whether he went before he got the bill or afterâ€”there was no chest of tea when the van came back.
JAMES METCALFE . I live at 9, Moon-street, Islington, and am a porter at

Messrs. Pickford'sâ€”on 27th November, about 4 o'clock, I was loading a truck for Huddlesfieldâ€”where I was loading was right round, you have to go right round, to get three or four hundred yardsâ€”the prisoner came on to my bank, and asked me if I had Birkenhead goodsâ€”I said, "Yes"â€”he said, "I do not mean Birkenhead, I mean Wigton"â€”I said, "No; that belongs to Old Marsh"â€”his van was round at the backâ€”he left a minute or two afterwards, and I missed a chest of tea, within two minutes, which I had seen at the time he was on the bankâ€”the number of it was 2,290â€”it was about a yard or a yard and a half from the place where he wasâ€”I saw no one with himâ€”he had no business at all thereâ€”I communicated with Mr. Robinson.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see his van, at the time he came round to you? A. Yes; he was in the habit of coming round to me if he had a note for meâ€”his van was loading about three hundred yards from me the way he had to come round with itâ€”he has come round before when he has had a case for Liverpool, but he had no business there unless he had anything to deliver to meâ€”he had no business there on that occasionâ€”I am always on duty thereâ€”he has never come and asked me the same thing beforeâ€”I have never given him anything to put into his vanâ€”I never load vans thereâ€”they do not deliver thereâ€”they have no business there, unless they bring a case from Liverpool to deliver to me in the course of their dutyâ€”I never delivered anything to the vans, nor does anybody from my branchâ€”when he said, "I mean Wigton," I said, "That goes to Jack Marsh"â€”he did not go to him; he could not without my seeing himâ€”I did not say, "What business have you come here about?"â€”I did not think there was anything strange about itâ€”he was in his van when he asked me if I had got Birkenheadâ€”I saw him leave the bank and go to the van, and he was in the van when be spoke to meâ€”I did not see him drive off or leaveâ€”there was something in the van, I cannot say whatâ€”I have been there eight yearsâ€”he was there as a boy when I went there.

COURT. Q. Did you see him leave your bank? A. I saw him get into his van at my bank, but did not see him leaveâ€”he came on to my bank, and while he was there I saw the chest of teaâ€”I missed it two minutes afterwardsâ€”when I say I saw him leave my bank, I mean on to the van.

JOHN ROBINSON . I live at 28, Basinghall-street, and am foreman to Messrs. Pickfordâ€”about half-past 4 on this day, Metcalfe called my attention to a tea chest, in consequence of which I followed the prisoner's van to our establishment in White Swan-yard, Whitechapel, where he had to take the goodsâ€”when I got there I saw a chest of tea covered up in his van, with a sheet over itâ€”I communicated to Mr. Lane that I thought there was some
thing wrongâ€”the other goods were exposedâ€”the chest was marked 2290â€”the prisoner had his bill with himâ€”Mr. Lane asked him how the chest came thereâ€”he first said that he had loaded it at the Liverpool bank, where he had been to look for a delivery-bookâ€”I then left him in Mr. Lane's hands, and had no more to do with itâ€”I had seen the van near the Liverpool platform a few minutes previous to the chest of tea being missedâ€”to get by the van to where Metcalfe was loading, he had to go 300 or 400 yards roundâ€”the van was close alongside the Liverpool bank, where the chest of tea was missed fromâ€”he had no business there whateverâ€”he afterwards, brought back a chest of tea by my direction.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he not say that the tea must have been put there by mistake? A. Yesâ€”he said that he had stopped at the Liverpool bank to look for a book, that he must have pulled the tea in by mistake and

loaded itâ€”I only knew of it being missed, from Metcalfeâ€”I had not seen it thereâ€”four or five men work on the Liverpool bankâ€”the men who drive the vans sometimes go round to that bank to unloadâ€”they have no busi
ness there, but I should never know itâ€”it is much out of their way.

THOMAS LANE . I am clerk at the Swan-yard, Whitechapelâ€”I saw the prisoner there with his loadâ€”Mr. Robinson came to me and spoke to me, and the prisoner was asked how he came into possession of the chest of teaâ€”he said that he must have taken it in mistake from the Liverpool bankâ€”he said that he went there to unload part of his goods, because he thought there was something wrong with his loadâ€”I asked him what made him think there was something wrong; he became very confused, and denied having said soâ€”he afterwards said that it was to find a delivery-bookâ€”the load was then unloaded, and when he got the things out I asked him where the delivery-book wasâ€”he said, "Here," and after raking in the straw at the bottom of the van he found it.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he say that he had been looking for the book? A. He said that that was the reason he unloaded part of his goods on the Liverpool bank, to find the bookâ€”that was his second explanationâ€”I have known him there five or six years.

WILLIAM DUGGAN . I am the boy who goes with the prisoner's vanâ€”I was present when the van was loaded on 27th Novemberâ€”he told me to draw round to the top of Church-streetâ€”that was before we got the billâ€”when I got to the top of Church-street the prisoner would not let me stand, and then I drew down the hill and drew inside the station, and my mate, the prisoner, came to me and asked me where the book wasâ€”I told him it was in the bottom of the vanâ€”he told me to go and get the bill, and he remained with the vanâ€”when I came back, after getting the bill, I did not find the bill where I had placed itâ€”I went up and down, and then went to our place at Whitechapel, and found him inside.

Cross-examined. Q. Then it was you who drove the van to the Liverpool bank? A. No; I could not get so far, because the road was upâ€”I was about thirty yards from itâ€”the police would not let me stand in the Minories, and never will, so I drove to the Liverpool bankâ€”I got the bill and gave it to himâ€”I did not put the book in the bottom of the van, but I had it on the seat and it dropped offâ€”I was not away more than half an hour getting the billâ€”Alexander Muirhead was about as far from me as the other side of this Court.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Are you speaking of the way you could walk, or the way you could drive the van? A. The way I could drive the vanâ€”that is the distance I was from the Liverpool bankâ€”I drove it as near to Metcalfe's bank as from here to the other end of the Courtâ€”the road was up, and there was a pair-horse van thereâ€”I could not get round till it movedâ€”in order to get up to Whitechapel I had to go opposite Metcalfe's placeâ€”it was just as near to go right by him, and to go out into Aldgate; or I could turn back and go the way I came.

JOHN GALE . I am private constable at Messrs. Pickford's, and goods' managerâ€”I told the prisoner he had better go down with me to the station-houseâ€”he said that he did not steal the chest of tea,â€”I said that I did not know anything about it except that it was missed from the island; that is the Liverpool bankâ€”he told me that he unloaded his van there to look for his bookâ€”I told him that it was impossible, that he could not do so, because the bank was blocked up with goodsâ€”I went and saw the bank directly afterwardsâ€”to get to the place that Metcalfe speaks of the prisoner must
have got over the goods, say two chests of tea, one on top of the other, perhaps.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know how long he has been in the service? A. About ten or eleven years.
NOT GUILTY .

121.
JOHN SANDERSON (27)
, Stealing 1 watch, value 2l. 10s. the property of
Robert Fletcher Kedgely, from his person; having been before convicted in the name of
Thomas Martin , in September, 1860; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .**â€ â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

122.
WILLIAM STOKES (19)
, Stealing 1 handkerchief, value 3s. the property of
William Jordan, from his person; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .*â€ â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

div0.p:
PRESENTâ€”SIR
HENRY MUGGERIDGE , Knt. Ald.; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

div1.p:
123.
JOHN LONG (24)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

FRANCES INCS . I live at No. 2, Church-place, with my motherâ€”one day last month, I was in Playhouse-court, in Bouverie-streetâ€”the prisoner came up to me and asked me to go and get him a quartern of ginâ€”he told me to go to the public-house at the bottom of the streetâ€”that is the Welsh Harpâ€”he gave me a half-crown and a bottleâ€”I went and asked for a quartern of ginâ€”I gave the half-crown, and received some money wrapped in paper, and the bottleâ€”I then came out and stood on the step of the door where I had been before; not the door of the Welsh Harpâ€”in a few minutes the prisoner came up to me and asked me where the gin wasâ€”I gave him the bottleâ€”he asked me where the change was, and I gave it to himâ€”he undid the paper, and said, "You have not brought the right change"â€”he asked me to go backâ€”I did not like to; and he said he would give me a pennyâ€”Mr. Eyre then came up and took him.

CHARLES SUTTERBY . I keep the Welsh Harp public-house, in Essex-street, Whitefriarsâ€”the last witness came to my house on the evening of 12th November lastâ€”she brought a bottle and asked for a quartern of gin, and tendered a half-crownâ€”I saw it was badâ€”instead of giving her a quartern of gin I put a quartern of water in the bottle; and wrapped a halfpenny in paper and gave herâ€”the right change would have been 2s. 1d.â€”I told her to take the gin and the changeâ€”she then went outâ€”I spoke to a person named Eyre, who was in my parlour at the time, and he went out after the girl.

Prisoner. Q. Did you receive the half-crown from the little girl, or from your daughter? A. I received it from my barmaid in the presence of the little girlâ€”she said, "Here is a bad half-crown that this little girl has brought"â€”I asked the little girl who had sent herâ€”she said she was playing at the top of the street, and a stranger had asked her to get him a quartern of gin.

WILLIAM EYRE . I am an attorney's clerkâ€”my place of business is at 3, Temple-lane, White friarsâ€”on 12th November last I was at the house of the last witnessâ€”I saw the little girlâ€”in consequence of some conversation

with the last witness I followed herâ€”I saw a half-crown in the landlord's handâ€”I heard the little girl say outside that a man had sent herâ€”I followed her to the top of a court, and she sat on the step of a doorway and I waited opposite; and about ten minutes afterwards the prisoner came up, passed the child, and went towards Fleet-street; looked about, and then returned, and went to the little girlâ€”I crossed over and stood behind him, within a yard of himâ€”I heard what he saidâ€”he said to the child, "Have you got the gin?"â€”she said, "Yes, sir," and gave it to himâ€”he put it in his left hand, and said, "Give me the change"â€”she gave him the change, wrapped in paperâ€”he opened it, found it was a halfpenny, and said, "You have not brought me back the right change; go back and fetch it, I will give you a halfpenny"â€”the girl did not like to go, and he asked her sister to goâ€”I went up, and said, "You shall go back yourself," and caught hold of himâ€”going along the road I asked him to give me the bottle; he said, "Yes; there it is," and threw it down on the pavement.

PATRICK CAULFIELD (City-policeman, 325). I took the prisoner in custodyâ€”I searched him, and found on him a sixpence, and fourpence in copper, good moneyâ€”I asked him his addressâ€”he refused itâ€”I received this half-crown from Mr. Sutterby.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This is a bad half-crown.

Prisoner's Defence. I was passing up Temple-lane, when the little girl asked me if I had sent her for the gin. I said, "What gin?" and took the bottle out of her hand, when Mr. Eyre came up and took me by the collar.

GUILTY â€”
Confined Nine Months.

124.
WILLIAM MAYHEAD (21) was indicted
for a like offence.

WILLIAM WOODRRSON . I am a shoemaker, at 1, Bond-street, Chelseaâ€”on 1st December, the prisoner was at my shop between 1 and 2 in the afternoonâ€”I had been out, and when I came in he was bargaining with my wife, and was putting on shoes, and I asked him whether those shoes would suit him better; that was a strong pairâ€”he purchased a pair, and tendered four half-crowns and a sixpenceâ€”I put the half-crowns in my pocketâ€”there were no others thereâ€”he went away then and took the boots with himâ€”sometime afterwards he came back and brought another customer, who, he said, required a better article than he had had; so I showed him a pair of my best bootsâ€”the prisoner said he wanted them for his friendâ€”his friend gave me six half-crowns, a shilling, and a sixpence for the pair which he agreed to take, and I stood a pot of beerâ€”I put the half-crowns in my pocketâ€”the two men went out with the bootsâ€”in, I should say, a quarter of an hour the prisoner returned again and purchased another pair of boots, which were 10s.â€”I came down sixpence for those, he being a good customerâ€”he paid four half-crowns, which I put in my pocketâ€”all the half-crowns were then in my pocketâ€”I paid two of them and a shilling away that evening to a Mr. Stephens, who came the next day and gave me one backâ€”I cannot say that I knew that one to be one that I had paid himâ€”in consequence of what took place with him, I looked at the other half-crownsâ€”I had previously given them to my wife, and she put them in a basin by themselvesâ€”afterwards the whole of this money was taken outâ€”I cannot. exactly say how many there were taken out, but the whole that were taken on the Sunday were taken outâ€”I gave them up to the policeman, Suttonâ€”I have no doubt about the prisoner being the person who came on the Sundayâ€”I had some doubt about him when I saw him again, because he was sitting down.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Did not you tell the police that you thought they had got the wrong man? A. I didâ€”I told them so emphaticallyâ€”I was not selling up to 2 o'clockâ€”it was between one and 2 that he calledâ€”my place was shut upâ€”he got in by knocking at the doorâ€”we sell whether our door is closed or not; when we can get a good customerâ€”I got fourteen half-crowns altogether on the three different occasions, from the prisoner and the other manâ€”on the second occasion it was the other man who paid the moneyâ€”he paid six half-crowns, so that from the prisoner himself I must have got eight on the different occasionsâ€”I cannot say how many good half-crowns there were among themâ€”I had also about 10l. odd in the house; 4l. odd was in silverâ€”I cannot say how many half-crowns there were amongst that, because it was all tied up in a little linen bag, which was put in the basinâ€”the basin was kept by my wifeâ€”when I received the half-crowns from these men, I put them in my pocketâ€”I put the first four in my pocket, where there was about 3s. 6d. in loose silver, but no half-crownsâ€”I cannot exactly say in what coin the 3s. 6d. was, shillings and sixpencesâ€”I am confident I had no half-crown among themâ€”I swear itâ€”when the friend came in, I put those six half-crowns in my pocket, and the four on the third occasion also, in the same pocketâ€”when I had the whole fourteen, I gave them to my wifeâ€”I did not give her any directions about themâ€”I left her to put them where she likedâ€”she did not put them into the bagâ€”I did not find that the bag had been opened when I went to it the next time; I am confident of thatâ€”I did not find that the string had been interfered withâ€”when I next saw the half-crowns they were on the top of the bag of money, in the basinâ€”it was at half-past 2 that I paid away two half-crownsâ€”I had to pay 3l. 6s., and I paid two of those half-crowns, a shilling, and three sovereigns awayâ€”I did not take the sovereigns out of that bag, but out of a leather purse which was also in the basinâ€”there was no silver in that purseâ€”it was after I gave the money to my wife that I paid the 3l. 6s.â€”there had been about 5l. in the basin, all tied upâ€”there was none looseâ€”I paid the two half-crowns to Mr. Stephensâ€”when I paid them I felt quite confident that they were goodâ€”the shutters of my shop were closed on that Sundayâ€”it was not as light as on other daysâ€”the prisoner was there I should say about ten minutes on each occasionâ€”he sat down and tried the boots onâ€”I had a little conversation with him, and that makes me more confident that he is the manâ€”I recognise him by his faceâ€”I asked him where he came from, and he said, "From Westminster"â€”one of them had hare skinsâ€”I said it was a most extraordinary thing for him to be about with hare skinsâ€”I know him, because he said he came from Westminster, and by other things; I know him by his features and heightâ€”his conversation is not one way by which I know him, but by his featuresâ€”I do not know him by his conversationâ€”I looked full in the man's faceâ€”I have not found out that he comes from Westminsterâ€”I identify him because I took particular notice of his features while I was talking to himâ€”I was looking at his face, not at his feet, while I was talking to himâ€”his face was down, so that I should have seen the top of his headâ€”I said at the station, "I am very much afraid you have taken the wrong man"â€”I said also to the policeman, I thought the man was bigger and dirtier than the prisonerâ€”the man said to me, "Are you sure he is the man?" and I said, "Well, I think he is bigger and dirtier"

â€”I said it twiceâ€”I had no notion that the half-crowns which I paid away were badâ€”they were brought back to me on the Monday morning, and I then went to the basinâ€”I did not find the bag tied up and the other half-crowns in itâ€”these half-crowns were left loose in the basinâ€”I am sure there was no money except the half-crowns that I received on the Sunday, in the basinâ€”I examined them.

MR. CRAWFORD. Q. Did any other half-crowns come into your shop on the Sunday? A. Noâ€”I was sitting on one side at the station-house, and t he prisoner was on the opposite side, and it being dark I really could not recognise himâ€”he did not afterwards get upâ€”when we were taken before the inspector I knew him in a moment, when he was in the lightâ€”that was when he was standing upâ€”I am not a little near-sightedâ€”I bad no doubt about him the moment he was standing up.
COURT. Q. What day was it that you saw him at the station? A. On the Tuesday.

MARY WOODERSON . I am the wife of the last witnessâ€”on Sunday, 1st December, I was in the shop and saw the prisoner come in between 1 and 2 o'clockâ€”there was no one but myself and my little grand-daughter in the shop thenâ€”he asked if I had got a pair of shoes to suit himâ€”I showed him someâ€”I said I had but one pair of strong boots that I thought would suit him, but they were a customer's pair of boots, and I expected a young man from Marylebone for themâ€”he tried on some of our shoes and found a pair that fitted him at lastâ€”I cannot say how long he was before he made a bargain; but a goodish bitâ€”while bargaining with him my husband came inâ€”we agreed on the price, and the prisoner paid my husband four half-crowns and a sixpence, and then went awayâ€”he was gone but a very short time when he returned with a friendâ€”I was in the shop thenâ€”the prisoner said he had brought a friend who wanted a pair of light bootsâ€”a pair was chosen, and he paid six half-crowns, a shilling, and a sixpenceâ€”I think the young man that had them, paidâ€”the prisoner was standing by all the timeâ€”he went away, and in a very short time returned again alone, and bought another pair for which he paid my husband four half-crownsâ€”I was in the shop at the timeâ€”I am certain the prisoner is the manâ€”my husband gave me the money that eveningâ€”I held the basin, and he put the money in itâ€”he gave me 1l. 17s.â€”there was a shilling and two sixpences; the rest was all in half-crownsâ€”there were fourteen half-crownsâ€”this is the basin (produced) that I put the money inâ€”there was nothing else in it at the time I put the money in it, no moneyâ€”my husband put the silver in this bag (produced) on the Saturday night, and the gold in this purse, and it was put awayâ€”the bag was tied up, and the prisoner's money was put in the basin looseâ€”the bag was not in the basin when I put the prisoner's money in looseâ€”the basin was quite emptyâ€”I did not afterwards put the bag into the basin; it was put in the drawerâ€”the basin had those half-crowns, and the shilling, and two sixpencesâ€”I gave him back that money the next morning, Mondayâ€”the money I received from that young man was the same that I gave my husband.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean to say you received the money on the Sunday from the young man? A. No; my husband received itâ€”the money was all tied up on the Saturday night when we had done business; the puree containing the goldâ€”we had no loose money in the house, none lying aboutâ€”what we had on Saturday was put in the bag altogetherâ€”the purse con
taining the gold was put in the bagâ€”the bag containing the purse with the gold, and containing the silver received on Saturday, was put in the drawer

â€”when I put the silver in the basin there was nothing at all in the basinâ€”it was just after breakfast time on the Monday, when I gave it to my hus
band; I should say about 9 o'clock in the morningâ€”I know there was some returned to himâ€”I don't know what time that wasâ€”I did not take particular noticeâ€”it was after I had given him back the half-crownsâ€”it was in the course of the morningâ€”I went to the police-station to identify the prisonerâ€”I did not hear my husband say that he was afraid they had got the wrong manâ€”I was fetched to know if that was the young manâ€”my husband was there before meâ€”I am certain the prisoner is the manâ€”my husband never said to me that he thought it was the wrong manâ€”I think I heard him say something about the man being bigger and dirtierâ€”I can-not remember where he said itâ€”I cannot say whether it was at our own placeâ€”I won't swear that it was not at our place, but I am certain that is the young man that cameâ€”I could not speak to the other man who came in.
MR. CRAWFORD. Q. You only saw the other man once? A. Yes; I saw this man three times.
RICHARD SILLIPAUT (Police-sergeant, B 14). I received these nine half-half-crowns (produced) from Mr. Wooderson, on Monday morning, 2d December, about nine o'clock.

JAMES CALEY . I remember seeing the prisoner on 2d December, Mon
day afternoonâ€”I was out selling fish at a public-houseâ€”I went in to have half a pint of beer and the prisoner came in thereâ€”he said, "I got a pair of boots that hurt my feet, and I bought the ticket of them from a man of the name of Copley; I wish you would go over and pawn them, because I want to buy a ticket of another man of a pair that will fit"â€”I pawned them for 6s. at Mr. Sowerby's, in Queen's-road, in the name of Mayhead, and I brought him back the money and the ticket.
Cross-examined. Q. What time of day was this? A. About 4 o'clock in the afternoon.

WILLIAM TRUEMAN . I am assistant to Mr. Sowerby, pawnbroker, of 3, Grosvenor-roadâ€”on 2d December last, this pair of boots (produced) was pledged at our place, in the name of William Mayhead, the last witnessâ€”I took them in, and lent 6s. on them.
WILLIAM WOODERSON (re-examined). These are my boots which I sold on the Sundayâ€”they are the first of those we sold.

MR. RIBTON. Q. I suppose you sell a great many pairs like those? A. I doâ€”I distinguish these from any others by their not being long worn, and also by their being a pair of bespoke shoesâ€”they were made for a man that came out of Londonâ€”I have sold hundreds of pairs like thatâ€”in that very week I had sold a great many like them, and on the Saturday.
COURT. Q. Then how do you know they are the pair you sold on the Sunday? A. I am confident they are; these are bespoke shoes.

MR. RIBTON. Q. What size do you call them? A. Sixesâ€”I had sold a great many sixes that week, like them in every respect, except the nails hereâ€”they are bespokeâ€”I do not put them into sloes unless they are bespokeâ€”I put them into all my bespoke shoes, it is my mark that distinguishes bespoke shoes from the ready-madeâ€”I had sold some on the Saturdayâ€”I am confident these are the boots.
COURT. Q. Is there any difference between these and the other bespoke shoes? A. No; I know they are my make.

CHARLES SUTTON (Policeman). In consequence of instructions, I looked after the prisoner and took him into custody on Tuesday, 3d December, about 4 o'clock in the afternoonâ€”Caley and Jabber Lewis were present

when I took himâ€”I told the prisoner he was concerned with another in passing nine half-crowns at the shop of Mr. Wooderson, Bond-street, Chelsea, on Sunday the 1stâ€”he said he had not been thereâ€”Caley said, "Bill, I pawned a pair of boots for you yesterday afternoon"â€”the prisoner said, "I bought the ticket of a man named Copley, in the Coach and Horses public-house"â€”I asked who Copley wasâ€”he said he did not know, nor where he lived, he only knew him by sightâ€”he was taken next day, the 4th, before the Magistrateâ€”the prisoner stated on that occasion that be paid for these boots, which were produced at the time, with eight shillings, and one half-crownâ€”he said he had bought them at the shop of Mr. Woodersonâ€”my first deposition was taken on the 4th, the second was on the 9thâ€”he was talking to Wooderson at the timeâ€”he said, "I paid you eight shillings and a half-crown at the time"â€”the Magistrate asked him if he wanted to put any questions to Mr. Wooderson, and he said he did, and then he said, "I paid you eight shillings and a half-crown."

p.hi: The witness's deposition being read, did not contain any mention of the name of Wooderson.

div1.p: WILLIAM WOODERSON (re-examined). I was before the magistrate on the 4thâ€”the prisoner told me I had made a mistake; that he gave me 8s. and one half-crown for the boots he had purchasedâ€”the boots were thereâ€”that was said aloud to the magistrateâ€”I swear that.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These half-crowns are all badâ€”three from one mould, and six from another.

GUILTY .*â€ â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

125.
SARAH RICHARDS (42)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin, having other counterfeit coin in her possession.

THOMAS MORRELL . I am a chemist, of 1, South-street, New North-roadâ€”on 25th November last, between seven and eight o'clock, the pri
soner came to my shop and asked for a pennyworth of antibilious pillsâ€”she tendered at first a good half-crown, and immediately said, "Oh! wait, I have got some smaller change in my pocket"â€”she then put down a bad shilling, and instantly took up the half-crownâ€”I took the shilling behind, tried it in the tester, and found it badâ€”I walked to the front of the counter, told her it was bad, and asked her how she came by itâ€”she said her husband was a hawker and had taken it by mistakeâ€”I said I thought hawkers were better judges than that; that I did not believe she had got it that wayâ€”I asked her if she had any more in her possessionâ€”she said dis
tinctly that she had notâ€”I watched her the whole of the time, and as I was looking out for a policeman I saw her drop another shilling on the cocoa-nut mattingâ€”I was going to pick it up, but she was too quick for meâ€”she picked it up herself and declared it was the good half-crownâ€”I sent for a constable and gave her in charge with the shillingâ€”in the pri
soner's presence the policeman cautioned me to walk behind her, as she would no doubt drop the other one on the wayâ€”as we were crossing from one street to the other, in a soft part of the road, she dropped a bad shillingâ€”I picked it upâ€”I was close behind her then, watching her very closelyâ€”I halloed out to the policeman, "I have found a bad shilling; and she said, "Oh! no"â€”I gave it to the inspector at the station.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not say, "I have had a great many in my shop, and I made a vow that the next one that comes in should suffer?" A. I had reason to believe you had been at my shop before, and had been successful in passing a bad shilling, and that was the reason I gave you in charge.

WILLIAM LEATHER (Policeman, N 168). The prisoner was given in custody by Mr. Morrellâ€”he charged her with uttering a bad shilling, and said, "She has another shilling concealed about her, I saw her drop it on the cocoa-nut matting"â€”the prisoner said, "No, it was not a shilling that I dropped, it was this good half-crown"â€”I took her into custody, caution
ing Mr. Morrell to keep an eye on her as we were going to the stationâ€”she could hear me make that statementâ€”she was searchedâ€”a good half-crown and four keys were found on herâ€”these (produced) are the two shillings.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you search me as far as you could in the doctor's shop; did not you turn my shawl up and my cuffs? A. No, certainly notâ€”I received the two shillings.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These are both bad, and from the same mould.

Prisoner's Defence. I only had the one in my possession, not knowing it was badâ€”I dropped the half-crown on the mat and picked it upâ€”I had no more about meâ€”that shilling has been picked up now, and I know nothing about itâ€”I have worked for one person eighteen years.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

126.
ANN JONES (26)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

CATHERINE SCHOONER . On 25th November last I was in Jerusalem-court; the prisoner came up and said to me, "I say, little girl, if you will go and get me a pint of six ale, I will give you a penny"â€”she gave me a half-crown and a jug, and told me to go to Mr. Wright's oppo
siteâ€”that is the Earl of Warwick public-houseâ€”I went there and asked for the beer and put down the half-crownâ€”Mr. Wright gave me the ale and I gave him the half-crownâ€”he did not give me the change, but said it was a bad half-crown, and told me to go out at one door and to go to her, and he would go out at the otherâ€”I told him that I had been sent by the prisonerâ€”I took the ale to herâ€”she was standing at the top of the court opposite the public-houseâ€”I took the ale across to herâ€”Mr. Wright came out, and directly she saw him come out in his shirt sleeves she began to run awayâ€”she had not taken the ale.
Prisoner. Q. What do you know me by? A. I know you by your faceâ€”Mr. Wright ran after you and caught you by the arm.

SAMUEL WRIGHT . On 21st November the last witness came into my house for a pint of ale, which was threepence, and tendered a bad half-crownâ€”I asked her where she got itâ€”she said she got it from a womanâ€”I gave her the aleâ€”I said, "Where is the woman?"â€”she said, "She is outside waiting"â€”I told her to go out at one door, and I went out at the other; she went to the prisoner, and was in the act of giving her the ale, when the prisoner saw me, and ran awayâ€”I ran after her and took her in chargeâ€”I asked her how she came to send the child in with the bad half-crownâ€”she said she had never seen the child beforeâ€”I gave her in charge to the first policeman that came upâ€”I gave the half-crown to the policeman.

JOSEPH LACY (Policeman, G 263). I received the prisoner into custody from Mr. Wrightâ€”she said she was innocentâ€”he gave me this counterfeit half-crown (produced)â€”I searched her, and found a shilling and threepence halfpenny in copper, good money.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This is a bad half-crown.
Prisoner's Defence. I am perfectly innocent. I told no untruth from the beginning; I said I was an unfortunate woman. I told the child I sent her
for no ale at all when she came up; I said, "You have made a mistake." I did not see Mr. Wright until he caught me by the arm.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

127.
FANNY WYLD (21), was indicted
for a like offence.

HENRY NAHRGANG . On Saturday, 16th November, I saw the prisoner at my shop, 47, Sooth Andley-street, a confectioner'sâ€”she asked me for two plain buns, which I had not gotâ€”she took two Bath buns, which came to fourpence, and gave me a half-crown, which I put in the tillâ€”there were no other half-crowns thereâ€”I gave her a two shilling piece and twopence in changeâ€”a few minutes afterwards my porter came for the beer for the men, and I gave him the half-crownâ€”he gave it me back and said, "I think that is a bad one"â€”I examined it, and it was bad, so I put it away by itselfâ€”on the 7th, I think, of this month, the prisoner came againâ€”I was sitting behind the counter reading the paperâ€”I recognised her immediately she came inâ€”I waited for my young woman to serve her, and the prisoner gave her a half-crownâ€”I said, "Let me see the half-crown," she gave it into my handâ€”I went round the counter and said, "I must detain you, you passed a bad half-crown to me some little time ago; this is a bad one also"â€”I sent for a constable, and gave her into custody with the two half-crowns.
COURT. Q. Are you sure she was there on the 17th? A. Yes; I know by reference to a bill which I paid for some coals on that day.
Prisoner. On the 27th I was in his shop, but not on the 17th.

SUSAN STRONG . I am assistant to Mr. Nahrgang, of 47, South Audley-streetâ€”on 17th December the prisoner came there for a pot of currant jelly, and paid me with a half-crownâ€”I was in the act of giving change, when my employer took it from meâ€”I gave her into custody.
Prisoner. Q. Did not your master say, I have taken bad money before, and I will make an example of you"? A. I did not hear anything of that.

WILLIAM SEAWARD (Policeman, B 288). I took the prisoner in charge on 7th December, from Mr. Nahrgang, who gave me these two half-crowns (pro
duced)â€”I searched the prisoner at the stationâ€”she had got two good half-Crowns, a penny, and a halfpenny, and the pot of jellyâ€”I asked her for her address, and she refused it.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . The half-crowns are bad, and from the same mould.
Prisoner's Defence. I was not in the shop on the 16th. I was there on two other occasions.

GUILTY â€”
Confined Six Months.

128.
JANE McMANUS (18), and
ELIZABETH CALEY (17), were indicted for
a like offence.

ANN BATH . I am the wife of John Bath, who keeps a chandler's stop at 21, Ecoleston-street, Eastâ€”on Friday, 29th November, the two prisoners came to my shop, and McManus asked for some tea, sugar, and butter, with which I served herâ€”they came to 4 1/2 d. and she gave me a half-crownâ€”I gave her 2s. 1 1/2 d. in change, and put the half-crown in my pocketâ€”I had no other silver loose in my pocketâ€”they turned away from the counter, and McManus said, "I forgot, I want a half-quartern loaf"â€”I served her with it, and she offered a shillingâ€”the loaf was 3 3/4 d.â€”I gave he 8 1/4 d., and put the shilling in the tillâ€”there was no other shilling thereâ€”it was no one of the shillings that I had given her previouslyâ€”I gave her the 2s. out of my pocket, and am sure they were goodâ€”the two prisoners went away together

â€”about 10 minutes afterwards I looked at the shilling and found it was badâ€”in consequence of that I looked at the half-crown, and found it was badâ€”I put the half-crown and the shilling by themselves in a purseâ€”I gave the prisoners in charge on Saturday night in Grosvenor-roadâ€”I gave informa
tion, and they were taken by constable A 249â€”I gave the coins up at the police-court.
McManus. Q. Did you not take a shilling in the morning for a penny-worth of hair oil? A. I served no hair oil that morning.
Caley. Q. Did I ask for any article? A. Noâ€”you took no article.

COURT. Q. Did they come in together? A. Yes, and went out togetherâ€”I did not hear what they said to one another, but I know they were togetherâ€”I have known them for years as companionsâ€”that is the only reason I did not seek them before, because I knew where to find them.

WILLIAM HISCOCK (Policeman, A 249). The last witness gave me a description; in consequence of which I pointed out the prisoners to herâ€”I took them into custody on 30th November lastâ€”I told them they were charged with passing a counterfeit half-crown and a shilling to the last wit
ness, who was standing at my side at the timeâ€”McManus said she knew nothing about it, she had not passed any bad moneyâ€”Caley said she was not near the placeâ€”I received this half-crown and shilling (produced) from last witnessâ€”the prisoners were searched by the last witnessâ€”2s. 6d. and 2 1/2 d.; good money, was found on Caley, and a penny and a key on McManusâ€”I asked McManus her addressâ€”she gave 29, Jones-road, Pimlicoâ€”I went there and saw the mother, who lives there; but the daughter had not been there for a fortnightâ€”Caley lives at the address she gave, Dove-court.
Caley. When I said I had not been there, I meant that I was never there before.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . The half-crown and shilling are both bad.

McManus' Defence. I did not know it was bad; It was given to me on the Thursday night; I went away from my mother's on account of having no work to go toâ€”Mrs. Bath put the half-crown between her teeth and tried it when I gave it her.

Caley's Defence. I was coming home from market and my father and I met McManus, who said she was coming my way home if I would wait a moment, she was going to get some tea and sugar; I went in with her While she got them; she then asked for half a quartern loaf, and then I went home; on the Saturday, I was going to get some tea and sugar for my mother and the policeman came and took me. I did not know it was bad.

MRS. CALEY. Caley had been to Covent-Garden Market with her father on the day she was taken up; I saw her start; I did not go with them; at night I sent her to get some tea and sugar for me, and then she was locked up; she is a very good girl and works very hard; she has brought up her other sisters.

Cross-examined by MR. CRAWFORD. Q. Has your daughter never been in trouble before? A. Not for anything of this sortâ€”she has had fourteen days and sevenâ€”she has never been charged with uttering counterfeit coin beforeâ€”she was punished once for being saucy to the police, or something of that sortâ€”she has never been in this Court before.
COURT to ANN BATH. Q. Which took the change? A. McManus.

CALEYâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

MCMANUSâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

129.
JAMES BROWN (58), was indicted
for a like offence.

MARY KERLER . My son keeps a baker's shop at 5, Old Compton-street, and I attend in the shopâ€”on 9th of this month the prisoner came to my shop and asked for a half-quartern loaf, which came to 3 3/4 d.â€”I gave it him, and he tendered in payment a 2s. pieceâ€”I gave him 1s. 6d. and 2 1/4 d. changeâ€”I tried the florin, and it bentâ€”I found it was badâ€”I said, "Man, coma back; this is bad"â€”he was not out of the door at the time; he was just going outâ€”I pursued him, and caught him by the shoulderâ€”when I told him it was bad, he said he would give me half a sovereign, and I said, u will not take that, it may be bad likewise"â€”he then threw down the loaf and said, "Take the loaf," and laid down 2 1/4 d. to give me the changeâ€”he did not give me the 1s. 6d.â€”he then went awayâ€”Mr. Taylor heard me calling out, and he came over and asked me what it was, and I told himâ€”my son-in-law, Mr. Barrow, was there alsoâ€”I gave the bad 2s. piece to Mr. Taylor, and I saw him give it to Mr. Barrow.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you ring the money? A. No; I did not take it up till I had given you the change, and you were going awayâ€”I put it in the detector.

WILLIAM TAYLOR . I am a shoemaker, and live in Compton-street, oppo
site last witnessâ€”I heard her call out, and saw her take the prisoner backâ€”I went over, and heard her charge him with giving her bad moneyâ€”I saw the prisoner offer her a half-sovereign, and she declined taking it, as it might be badâ€”I went across the road, and gave it to her son-in-law, Mr. Barrow.

GEORGE WILLIAM BARROW . I am the son-in-law of Mrs. Keeler, and am an engraverâ€”on 9th of this month, from information I received from Mr. Taylor, I went after the prisonerâ€”I went up Greek-street without my hat and coatâ€”he was walking very sharp out of the shop when I came upâ€”I did not succeed in catching himâ€”he was brought by a policemanâ€”I received a counterfeit florin from the last witness, which I gave to the con
stableâ€”I gave the prisoner in charge.

JAMES CROSBY (Policeman, E 160). Mr. Barrow gave the prisoner into my charge, with this florin (produced)â€”the prisoner said he would goâ€”going down Dudley-street he said I was very flash; I had not got him to rights yetâ€”I searched him in the shop, and in his. trouser's pocket I found 14s. 9d. good moneyâ€”I made a further search when I got to the station, and under his waistcoat I found this bad shilling (produced)â€”he said he did not know it was bad, he changed some money at Barnet, and must have got it there.

Primmer. Q. Where did you find me? A. At a public houseâ€”the landlord or barman did not say anything to me thenâ€”I went back and he said you had changed half-a-sovereign, and said that you owed two parties 5s. eachâ€”that was a good half-sovereign.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This florin and shilling are bad.

Prisoner's Defence. I will tell you the truth. I gave that lady the 2s. piece, and she gave me that bad shilling in my change. She looked at my money when I put it down, and I had got twenty yards away from the shop when she called me back. I could have nun away if I liked. I went to the public-house and had two glasses of ale.
COURT to GEORGE BARROW. Q. How long was it after you saw him go out of the shop that the policeman brought him back? A. About five or ten minutes.

GUILTY .*â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

130.
