JAMES WILSON (51), was indicted
for a like offence.

ROBERT HEATHER . I am landlord of the Queen's Head public-house, Brook-greenâ€”on 7th December last the prisoner came to my house and called for a pint of beerâ€”he offered in payment a shillingâ€”I did not take particular notice of it, and put it in the tillâ€”I then thought he drank the beer rather hastily, and went and looked at the shilling again, and found it was badâ€”I gave him sixpence, and a fourpenny bit in change, and he went awayâ€”I followed him, in company with another person named Lapland, and saw him go into Mr. Fase's at Kenningtonâ€”he came out again, and I went in and spoke to them, and they followed the prisoner again to the Holland Armsâ€”we went in there, and I asked the barmaid, in his presence, whether he had laid anything downâ€”she said, yes, he had; it was a bad sixpenceâ€”the prisoner had his thumb on itâ€”it was doubled up on the counterâ€”I did not see what became of itâ€”a constable was then sent for, and he was given into custodyâ€”I gkve the shilling that I had received from the prisoner to the constable at the station.

Prisoner. Q. You say I had a pint of porter in your place; how long was I there in the tap-room? A. Not more than two or three minutesâ€”you did not smoke a pipe thereâ€”you lit your pipe and went out.

MR. CRAWFORD. Q. Have you any doubt that the shilling you received from the prisoner was the one you gave to the constable? A. Noâ€”the prisoner went into Mr. Fase's shop about half-past 3â€”I spoke to Mr. Fase.

MARY ANN DORCAS KELLY . I keep the post-office and stationer's shop at Mr. Fane's, Edwarde's-terrace, Kenningtonâ€”I remember a man coming to the shop one Saturday afternoon, between 3 and 4â€”I don't know whether it was the prisonerâ€”he bought two shillings' worth of postage stamps, and paid me with a shilling and two sixpencesâ€”I put the money he gave me in the tillâ€”I had other shillings there at the timeâ€”the prisoner then left, and I heard some one come in and call out somethingâ€”a policeman came in that evening and said something to me, and I looked in the till in consequenceâ€”I found a bad shilling there, which I gave to him.

COURT. Q. You say that you cannot say the prisoner is the man? A. I believe the man who had the two shillings' worth of stamps of me was pock-markedâ€”he may or may not be the manâ€”I cannot say one way or the other.

CATHERINE JONES . I am barmaid at the Holland Armsâ€”on 7tb of this month the prisoner came to our house and asked for a glass of porterâ€”I served him, and he tendered in payment a bad sixpenceâ€”I found it out the very moment, I tried it in my teeth, bent it double, and threw it on the counter againâ€”I told him it was badâ€”Mr. Heather then came in, and he was given into custodyâ€”the prisoner gave me a second sixpence, and I gave him change out of that.

GEORGE ROWE (Policeman, T 301). I took the prisoner into custody at the Holland Arms, about half-past 4, on 7th of this monthâ€”Mr. Heather charged him with tendering him a bad shillingâ€”Mr. Heather handed me this shilling (produced)â€”Miss Jones said that he attempted to pass a bad sixpence thereâ€”I afterwards went to Mr. Fase's, and got a shilling from Mitt Kellyâ€”she took it from the tillâ€”this is it (produced)â€”I searched for the sixpence that Miss Jones said had been passed, but could not find itâ€”I found on the prisoner 3s. 10d. in silver, and 4d. in copper, and two shillings' worth of postage stampsâ€”he refused to give his address.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These shillings are both bad, and from the same mould.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. JUSTICE BLACKBURN; Mr. Ald. PHILLIPS; Mr. Ald. CONDER; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

div1.p:
131.
WILLIAM SMITH (17), was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Richard Crouch, and stealing 4 counter
panes and other goods, his property.

DANIEL DAVID (Policeman, H 169). On the morning of 28th November last, about half-past 1 o'clock, I was on duty in High-street, Whitechapelâ€”I saw the prisoner at the corner of the street In company with three other personsâ€”I watched themâ€”they had with them this empty basket (produced)â€”I placed myself in a doorwayâ€”whilst there I saw the prisoner in company with another one, the other carrying this basket with a small quantity of straw in it, go up to No. 1, Commercial-street, Whitechapel, or 110, High-streetâ€”they went up to the shutters, and they pulled a bar out with their two hands, and the prisoner held it while the other got the shutter down and pushed the shutter back on one sideâ€”I then saw them pull out something which appeared to me to be whiteâ€”I did not hear the window breakâ€”I saw these drapery goods pulled out and placed in the basket by the prisonerâ€”I then rushed out from where I was and apprehended the prisonerâ€”he ran away for about twenty yards before I caugnt himâ€”on the way to the, station he said, "For God's sake let me go, for I only had 2s. to come and look out lor the others"â€”I afterwards examined the shop window, and found it broken, and called up the prosecutor.

RICHARD CBOUOH . I am a draper, of 1, Commercial-street, and 110, High-street, Whitechapelâ€”it is two houses, but the one is connected with the other by an opening, an archway cut in the wall insideâ€”I sleep in the upper part of 110â€”on the night of 27th November I went to bed about 11 o'clockâ€”I was aroused by the constable between 1 aud 2â€”I found one of the shutters to the shop, No. 1, Commercial-street, drawn on one side, and a square of plate-glass brokenâ€”when I went to bed the shutter and glass was perfectly secureâ€”I missed the articles statedâ€”this (produced) is part of itâ€”it was safe in the window when I went to bed.

Prisoner's Defence. I was coming down Whitechapel-road about 12 o'clock, and met three young chaps, who said they would give me 2s. if I would stand at the corner and look out for them, and I did, and the policeman came and took me.
GUILTY .
The prisoner was further charged with having been before convicted at the Police-court, Worthip-striet, in September, 1860, when he was sentenced to Four Months' imprisonment;

p.hi:
to which he pleaded guilty.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

div1.p:
132.
CHARLES LE CLERC (43)
, Feloniously assaulting
Rene Moupion, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

JOSEPH CALLE . I am a stick manufacturer, and five at 1, Rutland-street, Kingsland-roadâ€”I am acquainted with the prosecutorâ€”on Monday evening, 25th November, I went with the prisoner to an eating-house at the West-end, where there was some little altercation between the prisoner and the prose
cutor

â€”next day I went into a beer-shop in the City-road with the prosecutorâ€”the prisoner came in perhaps two or three minutes afterwards, and sat not far from usâ€”words passed between him and Monpion, but I did not notice what they saidâ€”Monpion was not very soberâ€”the prisoner did not look tipsy, but I could not say that he was soberâ€”they continued talking a minute or two, and a few minutes afterwards I saw them on the floor; the prisoner had a penknife in his handâ€”I took it from him, and put it in my pocketâ€”I did not notice whether there was any blood upon itâ€”the men got up, and we went into a public-house opposite, where we remained perhaps half an hour, till 7 or past 7â€”we had two quarts of drink between four of usâ€”my home is twenty minutes' walk from thereâ€”we all four left togetherâ€”the fourth man came with the prisoner into the first beer shopâ€”the prosecutor got home first; I found him in my place when I got thereâ€”he had fallen down on the floorâ€”my wife told me something, and I saw blood on his trousersâ€”they were taken off, and I saw two wounds on his thighs, with a great quantity of blood coming from themâ€”I stopped the blood, and then sent for a doctor, and had the prosecutor conveyed home in a cabâ€”when they were on the ground, I heard the prisoner say in French, "What for did you insult me last night?" and afterwards he struck himâ€”I did not notice what reply the prosecutor made; I do not understand per
fectlyâ€”three or four minutes after that I saw him on the floorâ€”I gave the knife to the policeman.

Cross-examined by MR. TAYLOR. Q. Who was the fourth person, Jean Bonnersbach? A. He was called Jean; I do not know his other nameâ€”we were all four togetherâ€”it was before 12 o'clock when I got home and found Monpion bleedingâ€”he was not locked in his own room; he was in my roomâ€”he does not lodge in the same house as meâ€”there was not a door broken open after I got homeâ€”I do not say that the prosecutor was very drunk at that time, and I do not say that he was soberâ€”it was between 5 and 6 in the afternoon when they were on the floorâ€”I never took notice of what the time was when I went homeâ€”I went straight home from the second public-houseâ€”I left there with the prosecutor; but he went before me, and when I got home I found him in my placeâ€”I do not know the name of the first public-house, where they were on the ground togetherâ€”they quarreled again at the second public-house; I do not know whether there was any falling down thereâ€”they went outside, and I stopped insideâ€”the prosecutor did not get very drunk at the second public-house, and say that he had a 100l. note with himâ€”I did not notice what he said, because he was half tipsyâ€”they made up their quarrel each time, and after they had the last quarrel they parted good friendsâ€”the prosecutor did not complain of being stabbed; he said that it was only a kick or a scratchâ€”a person named Balle did not come into the public-house; I saw him along time before at the pro
secutor's placeâ€”they quarrelled about their businessâ€”they did not have a scuffle togetherâ€”he did not touch him, but he said that he would if he did not go away.

RENE MONPION . (Through an interpreter). I am a wheelwright, and live at Murray-street, New North-roadâ€”I work for an employerâ€”I am a French
manâ€”I knew the prisoner before this occurredâ€”I was with him in a French house at the West End, and he attacked me with wordsâ€”on the next day, Tuesday the 26th, I went to a beer-shop in the City-road with the last witness, about half-past 5 or 6, and the prisoner came there with his lodgerâ€”I do not know his nameâ€”I asked the prisoner why he had insulted me the day before at the West End; he said, "Yesterday, when we had that

tussle I might have hurt you if I liked, but I did not wish it"â€”I said, "That is true; I took it very cool, the inault yesterday;" he said, "That is very true"â€”we had a slight quarrel, and then we had a pot in the tap-roomâ€”a few minutes afterwards I went to the bar of the beer shop, and then went out to make waterâ€”as I came in the prisoner had his back against the bar, and caught hold of me and gave me some blowsâ€”I continued to stand, but I threw him to the ground and fell on top of himâ€”I was over him, and directly I got up he got upâ€”nothing more occurred there, but we went to another beer shop opposite and had something to drink altogetherâ€”an Englishman there showed me that there was some blood on my trousersâ€”I stayed there a quarter of an hour, twenty minutes, or half an hour, and then went to my homeâ€”I did not go anywhere firstâ€”from my home I went to Calle'a, to get one of my children who was being taken care of; and Calle came home ten minutes or a quarter of an hour afterwardsâ€”I then found myself bleeding, and gave Mrs. Calle half-a-crown to send for some camphor, as I was faintingâ€”my clothes were removed; I was taken to a doctor, and sent home in a cabâ€”I am not well yet, but my wounds are not quite so badâ€”I never said anything to irritate or provoke the prisoner before the blows were struck.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you live in the same house with Calle? A. No; I went to my own home firstâ€”I had a few words about business with a man named Balle, an explanationâ€”it was au explanation and a quarrel; that was before going to the beer-shop, about a quarter past iâ€”I did not then go to the beer-shop; I wrote a letter first, took it to the post, and then walked to the beer-shopâ€”it was then that I had the quarrel with the prisoner when he came in, which was at half-past 5 or 6 o'clockâ€”it was not 12 o'clock when I got to Callers, it was not half-past 8â€”I do not know how soon after I got there, Call 6 came home, because I lost my sensesâ€”I fell on the boards through loss of blood; I was not drunk; they went and fetched the first doctor, and afterwards anotherâ€”we did not part friends in the public-house where we last drank; we went outside and had a struggle, and the prisoner tried to kick me in the chest, and his wife took him home one way, and I went anotherâ€”Bonnersbach went above twenty yards with meâ€”I have said besides to-day, and before the Magistrate, that I felt blows; but I did not know that they were with a knife.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. During that evening, had you any quarrel or tussle with any person except the prisoner? A. Yes, with a man named Balle from 4 to half-past 4â€”that was before 1 went to the public-houseâ€”from that time till I discovered the blood I had no tussle with any other human being.

JOHN GRIFFITHS . I am a surgeonâ€”on Wednesday morning, 27th Novem
ber, about 1 o'clock, I was called to Callers house to see the prosecutorâ€”I found him with four incised wounds; one on his left groin, one on bit left thigh, one on his right thigh, and one on the lower part of the left side of the chestâ€”they might have been produced by a knife like thisâ€”that in the groin was about half an inch long; I did not think it judicious to probe it; that on the upper part of the left thigh was three inches long and half an inch deep; that on the right thigh an inch and a half long and half an much deep; that on the chest was about a quarter of an inch long and down to the boneâ€”there was not very considerable haemorrhageâ€”the wounds are comparatively well now he is out of dangerâ€”the most dangerous wound was the one in the groin, as it might have entered the abdomen.
Cross-examined. Q. At what time were you sent for? A. Between 12 and 1; I got there about a quarter to I, and I went at once.

COURT. Q. Did you notice anything to indicate how long the wounds had been made? A. Some little timeâ€”the blood was thoroughly coagulated; they were not very recentâ€”a person in a passion might receive such wounds without knowing it; but he could not be ignorant of it for an hour or two when his blood cooled, unless he was in a state of insensibility from intoxi
cationâ€”I was not the first medical man who saw himâ€”I was fetched by the police.
MR. SLEIGH. Q. Did you understand that some other medical man had seen him first? A. I saw a bottle from a man who keeps a surgery, but he had not attended to the case, so I took it in hand.

MR. SLEIGH to JOSEPH CALLE Q. You saw the surgeon who has just been examined; did you send for him or for anybody else? A. I sent my son and went myself; that was directly I came homeâ€”I went to Kingsland-road; the gentleman came to my place, and I went with him to fetch the medicineâ€”I did not notice what time it was, perhaps half past 9, and perhaps 10â€”that gentleman who I brought examined him.

MR. TAYLOR. Q. What time was it when you went home? A. Eight or half-past 8â€”I was certainly at home an hour before I went for the doctor, because I stopped the blood myself, and then went to Pearson-street and then to Kingsland-roadâ€”If I knew how long it was after I got home before Dr. Griffiths came, I would have told you beforeâ€”I did not take notice of the time.

WILLIAM HOPPER (Policeman, N 358). In consequence of information I went to the prisoner's house, and found him in bed at 12 o'clock on Tuesday night, or half-pastâ€”I told him he was charged with wounding a manâ€”he talked to his wife in French I suppose it wasâ€”I had to make him understand as well as I could that I should take him to the stationâ€”I did so, and then went to our divisional doctor, as I had seen the prosecutor before at a quarter to 12, and seen his wounds all openâ€”I took the doctor in a cabâ€”Call 6 gave me this knifeâ€”I showed it to the prisoner, and he said, "Yes, that is the knife; I know it is mine."

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. REOORDER; Mr. Ald. CONDER; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

div1.p:
133.
JOHN BROWN (28)
, Stealing, on 31st October, 1 gelding of
James Robert Truss, and 1 gelding of
William Waite; also, on 4th December, I mare of
John Facey; to both which he

PLEADED GUILTY .**â€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

134.
WILLIAM FARR (26)
, Feloniously forging and uttering a request for the delivery of 13 yards of silk, with intent to defraud.

JOSEPH MICHAEL BEANE . I am manager of Calverly Hotel at Tunbridge Wellsâ€”Mr. Churchill is the proprietor, and the prisoner was his clerkâ€”this order (produced) is in the prisoner's writingâ€”if we wanted goods I should give him directions, or write myselfâ€”that was the course of business thereâ€”the prisoner had no authority from me to write this orderâ€”he was

not in our employ at that time; he left on the 18th or 19th of Octoberâ€”(Order read: "Tunbridge Wells, November 30th, 1861. Gentlemen,â€”Please send me by bearer fourteen yards of good blue glace, at 4s. 9d. Have the goodness to let an invoice come with it Yours respectfully, J. Churchill, pet W. H. Brooks")â€”there was no person named Brooks in our employ.
COURT. Q. Did Mr. Churchill take any part in the management of the hotel? A. Noâ€”he calls occasionallyâ€”he is not here.

HENRY HELMORE . I am assistant to Mr. Attenborough, a pawnbroker of Fleet-streetâ€”the prisoner pawned this glace at his shop, on 2d December, for 1l. 5s.â€”this (produced) is the duplicate I gave himâ€”I have got the other part here (produced)â€”I did not know the prisoner before.
JOSEPH MARSHALL (City policeman, 84). I took the prisoner in custody on another matter, not connected with thisâ€”I searched him and found this duplicate upon him.

ROBERT ELLIOTT . I am warehouseman to Messrs. White, carpet and general warehousemen at 78, Watling-streetâ€”I know Mr. Churchill, the proprietor of the Calverly hotel, in business, not personallyâ€”the prisoner came to our place on 2d December, about mid day, and brought this orderâ€”on his producing it I supplied him with thirteen yards of silkâ€”I believed the order to be genuineâ€”the memorandum at the bottom is not the prisoner's writing; it was written by our firm afterwardsâ€”this is the same sort of silk that I let the prisoner have, and I believe it to be the same.
COURT. Q. That order is to send it down to the Calverly hotel, how came you to give it to him? A. He said he would take it downâ€”I did not know him before.

Prisoner's Defence. I plead guilty to obtaining goods under false pretences, but I most distinctly repudiate the charge of forgery. The name from whom that purports to come; has not been forged, it is an assumed name. I do not attempt to deny that I obtained the silk and pledged it, but I am not guilty of forgery. I left my situation and wandered about London to get something to do: hunger pressed me, and, in a moment of desperation, scarcely knowing what I did, I committed the act for which I stand before you; and even then I swear I did not intend to defraud Messrs. White; I trusted in the hope of obtaining a situation, and should have gone home and received from my friends the money to liquidate that claim, before Mr. Churchill could have known.

GUILTY .*â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

p.hi: There was another indictment against the prisoner.

div1.p:
135.
JOHN GODDARD (43)
, Stealing 1 mare, 1 cart, 1 set of harness, and 36 trusses of clover, the property of
James Chivins.

JAMES CHIVINS . I live at Furnish Pelham, in Hertfordshireâ€”on Tuesday, 3d December, I came to London with my mare and cart, with a load of clover to the Curtain-road, Shoreditch, at a little before 12 o'clockâ€”I there saw the prisoner with another man, and asked him to mind my horse while I went and fetched a paroelâ€”I went into a public-house with the other manâ€”the prisoner said, "Give me the whip"â€”I gave it to him, and said I should be gone five or six minutesâ€”I returned to the spot in about six minutes and he was gone, and the mare, can, and clover, tooâ€”I had not given him any authority to take it awayâ€”I ran down the street to look after itâ€”about 7 o'clock in the same evening I saw my brother-in-law, Lewis King, and he showed me the hone, cart, and clover, somewhere in Islingtonâ€”it was the same that I had lost.

Cross-examined by MR. LLOYD. Q. Whereabouts in Islington? A. Against Mr. Wright's, the corn-dealer's, just before you get to the gateâ€”I went into the King's Head public-house in the Kingsland-road, and met my brother there, by accidentâ€”he took me to the cart that nightâ€”he said he had found the horde and cart, and he took me to where it wasâ€”when I met the prisoner and the other man, the other man did not say to me, "You stay here with the cart and I will go and fetch the parcel"â€”I had only had one half-pint of beer that morning; this was 12 o'clockâ€”I was going to Crab and Williams's with the cloverâ€”it was my cart and horse, but not my cloverâ€”my brother-in-law was not expecting me; he did not know where I wasâ€”the prisoner had not been drinking.

LEWIS KING . I live at Sawbridgeworth, Hertfordshireâ€”the last witness is my brother-in-lawâ€”on Tuesday, 3d December last, about half-past 1 in the afternoon, I was in Tottenham-court-roadâ€”I there saw the prisoner with my brother-in-law's horse and cart with another manâ€”I knew by the way the clover was tied, that it came from our placeâ€”I thought my brother-in-law was with it, and went up and spoke to the menâ€”the man who was with the prisoner said, "If you have more right to this horse and cart than I have take it," and be threw down the whip and ran awayâ€”I have known the prisoner all my life under the name of John Morrell of Whitfordâ€”I said, "You stole this horse and cart, and load of clover"â€”a corn-chandler was looking at it at the timeâ€”I think his name was Swindlerâ€”the prisoner wanted to run away with the other one, and I said, "No, I shall keep you"â€”I then took the horse and cart to the station-house, and then led it to Wright's place in Islingtonâ€”I then went to look for my brother-in-law, and found him in the Kingsland-road.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know the other man? A. No; I should know him again if I saw himâ€”I have known the prisoner ever since I was a little boy, when be used to drive a cart from Whitfordâ€”he does not live down there nowâ€”I have heard him say he lives at Somers-townâ€”I do not know whether my brother-in-law knew him; he must have seen him beforeâ€”when I saw the cart, they were going to sell the load of clover to Mr. Swindler, and I told him not to buy it because it was stolen, and he said, "Stick to that man," and I didâ€”I could not hold bothâ€”I took hold of this man's collar, and kept him till I found a policeman.

JAMES CHIVINS (re-examined). I knew the prisoner beforeâ€”I had seen him a great many timesâ€”I have known him ever since I was a little boy as John Morrell, of Whitfordâ€”he knew I was going to the Kingsland-road with the clover.

THOMAS ROWE (Policeman, A 337). On Saturday afternoon, 3d December, I was in Tottenham-court-road, and was called to a cart and some clover which was standing in front of Hibberdine's, a corn-chandler's shopâ€”the prisoner was given into my custody about thirty yards from the shopâ€”I told him he was charged with stealing the mare, cart, and load of cloverâ€”he said he had not seen it till he saw it in Tottenham-court-road, and then some man who was with it, asked him to go into the corn-chandler's shop to sell it; as he was doing so Lewis King came up and took him, and the other man ran away.
GUILTY .

p.hi: He was further charged with having been before convicted.

div1.p:
THOMAS LEVI (Policeman, V 116). I produce a certificate. (Read: "Central Criminal Court, February, 1853. John Morrelly convicted of stealing I gelding, 2 mares, a set of harness, and a whip, of
John Ruff.â€”Transported for ten years")â€”I was present at the trialâ€”I gave evidence against him and his brother,
who is now doing seven yearsâ€”the prisoner is the man who was then convictedâ€”I do not know how long he has been back.

GUILTY.â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

136.
JOHN KIRBY (39)
, Unlawfully conspiring (with
Louis Billaud who did not surrender to his bail), to obtain a situation as butler in the service of
Sir John Norton Knatchbull, by a false certificate of character.

SIR JOHN NORTON KNATCHBULL . I am the prosecutor in this case, and live at 3, Cheeham-place, Belgrade square, and at Masham-hatch, near Ash
fordâ€”in the beginning of October I inserted an advertisement in the Times for a butler, in conseqnence of which I received this letter (produced)â€”I know the writing; it is the prisoner'sâ€”(This was partially read; it was signed John Kirby, and dated 4th October, 1861. stating the names of several noblemen and gentlemen with whom he had lied, that he had been groom of the chamber to his Grace the Duke of Somerset, at the Admiralty, and referring for his character to Louis Billaud, in his Grace's service there.)â€”I consequence of that letter I appointed an interview with Kirby in Chesham-place, on 8th October, when I produced the letter which he had written to me, and asked him if he wrote itâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”I asked him where his last place wasâ€”he said, "Groom of the chamber to the Duke of Somerset," that he had left of his own ac
cord, and a person named Louis Billaud, who was house steward, had authority to give him a characterâ€”I addressed a letter to Louis Billaud and posted it, and three days afterwards received this answerâ€”(Read: "October 18th, 1861.â€”I beg to inform Sir Norton Knatchbull, in reply to his letter res
pecting the character of John Kirby, that he lived in the service of the Duke of Somerset thirteen months and some days. I always found him attentive, sober, and trustworthy; he left by-his own desire. Your obedient servant, Louie Billaud, house steward.")â€”in consequence of that I wrote the letter and engaged the defendant as my butlerâ€”he afterwards returned it to meâ€”(This was dated October 11th, to John Kirby, engaging him as butler at 45l. a yeart and 5l. for beer, arranging as to the repayment of his travelling expenes, and requesting him to come down to the Smeeth station by the 10.30 train, and to write his answer on the other side. On the other side was an acceptance of the above terms, signed u John Kirby")â€”he entered my service on 18th October, and conducted himself very well for a few days, but on 7th Novem
ber he was in a state of drunkenness and I was forced to send him out of the house, and in consequence of inquiries I made, I proceeded against him under the statute of George III.â€”he called Billand as his witness, and in consequence of the evidence that Billaud gave they were both committed for conspiracyâ€”I afterwards received a letter from Billand.

HER GRACE THE DUCHESS OF SOMERSET. I reside at the Admiraltyâ€”Bil
laud was in my service as butler, and in no other capacity at any timeâ€”he left on 10th August this yearâ€”as butler, he had no authority to engage or dismiss servants, or to give them charactersâ€”I have particular reason to know that he was aware of thatâ€”I know Billand's writingâ€”I do not think this letter is his' it is very like it, but there is a difference, and I cannot help thinking it is Kirbv's, though I cannot say that it is not Billaud'sâ€”if it is Billaud's he had no authority to write itâ€”the prisoner was in my service thirteen months as valet and groom of the chamberâ€”I think he was dis
charged on 9th Mayâ€”it was because he would not keep himself sober, and he had been forgiven twiceâ€”at the time of his discharge, Billaud was in my serviceâ€”Kirby wrote me several letters about his drunkennessâ€”this is

one of themâ€”(This was dated June 6th, 1861, from the prisoner, informing His Grace that his drunkenness was caused by his drinking bad spirits when in a state of excitement, caused by distress in his family, begging pardon for his con
duct and promising to abandon drink for ever).
COURT. Q. Are you able to say whether or not Kirby knew whether Billaud had authority to give a character? A. I did not trust Billaud with anything; he was a mere butler.

HARIETTE KNOWLES I am housekeeper to the Duke of Somerset, at the Admiralty, and know Kirby and Billaudâ€”they were in the Duke's service some timeâ€”Billaud left on 10th Augustâ€”I have seen Kirby in a state of drunkenness in Billaud's presenceâ€”Billaud knew why Kirby was dismissed; We had talk about it many timesâ€”Billaud knew that it was for drunkenness.

Prisoner. Q. Have you ever observed any one else intoxicated in the Duke's household? A. It was always looked overâ€”I do not remember that Other servants were discharged for drinkingâ€”I do not remember the under butler and the hall butler being discharged, and two gentlemen coming for their characters and seeing Billaudâ€”I recollect George, the under butler, and Robert Coombe, the hall porterâ€”I never heard of a gentleman calling three times to see the under butler at the time George was leaving, not wishing to trouble the Duchess, or that the under butler got a situation through Billaud's recommendationâ€”I do not know that the hall porter got a situation through Billaudâ€”I always understood from the Duchess that the butler had no power.
COURT. Q. Was that perfectly known throughout the household? A. Yes; I have been there some years now.

JOHN MUNDAY . I am coachman to the Hon. Robert Lowe, of 34, Lowndes-squareâ€”Kirby was a fellow servant of mine at the latter end of June this yearâ€”he left some time in Julyâ€”he left before Augustâ€”I do not know what he left for.

HENRY SMITH (Police-sergeant). On 25th November, about half-past 9 in the morning, I saw Billaud in Dartmouth-street, Westminsterâ€”he went to 25, Dartmouth-street, knocked at the door, and Kirby opened itâ€”Billaud showed Kirby a letterâ€”they talked together for a few minutes, and Billaud left and went up Dartmouth-street into Birdcage-walk, where he walked about for half an hour, occasionally reading a letter; Kirby joined him thereâ€”they continued together, and went to 31, St. Martin-street, Leicester-squareâ€”Billaud knocked at the doorâ€”they both went in, and remained there for half an hourâ€”they then went to Clark's public-house in Whit worth-street, then to another public-house, where they remained some time, came out, shook hands, and partedâ€”I followed Kirby to the Charing Cross Post-officeâ€”he went and got a stamp put on a letter, and posted itâ€”I said to him in Trafalgar-square," Good morning, Kirby"â€”he said, "Good morning"â€”I said, "You are looking better"â€”he said, "Yes; I have been in the country; where do you know me?"â€”I said, "At the Duke of Somerset's"â€”I then told him who I was, and that I had a warrant for his apprehension for obtaining a situation, in Sir Thomas Knatchbull's service, by means of a false characterâ€”he said, "It was not false, it was given to me by Bilaud"â€”I asked him when he had seen Billaudâ€”he said that he met him about three weeks ago, in the streetâ€”I asked him where Billaud livedâ€”he said that he did not knowâ€”I took him to the office in Scotland-yard, and while there he wrote in this book (produced)â€”I searched him after he was remanded, and it was found upon himâ€”(Read: "Mr. Billaud must state that I did not know he had left the Duke's, and that he had received a letter from Sir Norton

Knatchbull, who wrote for my character about a month ago, and that he called at the Admiralty; let him swear that, and certify to you that it is all right; he lodges at 8, Palace-street; he was authorised to give characters, and I served under him; he can swear to the handwriting").

Prisoner. Q. When I went to Scotland-yard, I asked you when you were going to take me from there? A. Yes; I do not recollect you telling me that you were going on business for your wife; that you had a com
mission to executeâ€”you asked me whether you could call on your wife, seeing she lived on the way, and I said, "Yes;" but I took you by the next streetâ€”you did not write this as an instruction to your wife to find Billaud out.

SOMERS HIGGINS . I am one of the clerks to the Magistrates at Westminster police-courtâ€”I was there when Kirby was charged, and took the notesâ€”he called as his witness a person named Billaudâ€”I took notes of what Billaud saidâ€”he said, "I lodge at 8, Palace-street, Westminsterâ€”I was butler at the Duke of Somerset'sâ€”I left on 10th Augustâ€”I am now out of placeâ€”I left for no faultâ€”while I was there, the prisoner was there alsoâ€”I was there when the prisoner was dischargedâ€”I sometimes hired and discharged servants, and sometimes the Dnkeâ€”I do not know why the prisoner leftâ€”I remained after the prisoner leftâ€”I never saw the prisoner drunkâ€”he applied to me six weeks ago for a character"â€”he was asked a question by the Magistrate, and said, "I met the prisoner in the park; I had left the Duke'sâ€”he said he had applied for a situation, and asked me to give him a referenceâ€”I asked him to write me a copy of what I should say, and after that day I received from the prisoner a letter addressed to me from Sir Johnâ€”I had sent the prisoner to the Admiralty for my letterâ€”he gave it me in an envelope and I was to copy itâ€”I put the copy into the post instead of copying it, as I was' busy"â€”the document was then produced, this is itâ€”" it was not sealed when given to meâ€”I sealed itâ€”I saw nothing but the truth in itâ€”he did not know I had leftâ€”I offered myself for the same situation, 1 did not know that the prisoner had appliedâ€”I saw the advertisement in the Times"â€”he was then ordered into custody.

Prisoner's Defence. I beg to explain as far as I can respecting the facts. In the early part of October, I was reading an advertisement in the Times to apply by initials in Bond-street for the situation of a butler; I went home and wrote a letter, and next day took it and asked the shopman if he knew who it was for; he said that he had no instructions to say, but the letter would be sent; in a few days I received a letter from Sir Norton Knatchbull, but did not know who he was, because there was no name; it was to meet a gentleman and lady at Chesham-place on a certain day. In two or three days I went to see them, and saw this gentleman; I presented this letter, he asked me some questions, went up stairs, and afterwards called me up, and I saw a lady, who said, "Oh! you are the tall man who wrote to Sir Norton, you have lived with the Duchess of Somerset as groom of the chamber." I said, "Yes;" she said, "After living in such a distinguished family, would you like to live in a quiet gentleman's family in the country, in a very large house and a great deal of plate, but not much company?" I said that I would live wherever I was comfortable; she said, "Who shall I apply to for your character?" I said, "The Duke, from his official capacity as first Lord of the Admiralty, seldom troubles himself with, characters, and the Duchess I do not wish to trouble, but Mr. Billaud, the steward, knows enough of me to speak of me." I thought, I do not know who you are, and I will not trouble the Duchess until I know what family

I am going into. Sir Norton took me down stairs, took pen and ink, and asked me who he was to write to; I said, "Mr. Billaud, the head steward;" He said, "Is he in town?" I said, "I do not know;" he wrote and gave me the note to put in the post; going home I saw Mr. Billaud and ran over the way to him; he said that he was in a very great hurry indeed. I said, "I want to speak to you. I have been after a situation. I do not think the place will suit me. I have taken the liberty of referring the gentleman to you, but I shall write to the Duke or the Duchess." he said, "I do not know what I can say; I cannot stop now; you write me a letter." I said, "I believe the gentleman is going to write this evening;" he said, "You had better call at the Admiralty, and see if there is any letter, and take it to your house." I went home. My wife advised me not to write the copy, but I did, and left it, saying, "If you see him you can give it to him." He called in the morning, when I was dressed to go out, and said, "Here is a letter from this gentleman." Mr. Billaud took the letter away, and I did not see him afterwards. I went to Woolwich next day, and on my return to town there were two letters; one from Sir Norton, saying that he was satisfied with the character Billaud had sent, and another saying that I had not answered. I wrote to say that I had been out of town, which was the cause of my delay. My friends pressed me not to disappoint the gentleman, as he might be having company, so I went down to see how I liked the situation. All went well for eight days, as Lady Knatchbull was away, but when she came home she led me a life which these walls for ever would be nothing to; a dog's life. I afterwards received an unfortunate letter from my wife, which caused me to take some beer. I got muddled, and Sir Norton discharged me.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

div0.p: PRESENT. Mr. Ald. SALOMONS, M.P.; Mr. Ald. FINNIS; Mr. Ald. CONDER; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

div1.p:
137.
JOHN EAST (50), and
JAMES MACKIN (40)
, Stealing 1 basket and 100 dead herrings, the property of
Arthur McNamara, the master of East.

ROBERT SINGLETON . I am watchman to Mr. Arthur McNamara, carrier, of Castle street, Finsburyâ€”I watched the two prisoners on the morning of 28th Novemberâ€”Mackin was in a dark dressâ€”I first saw him about five minutes past 6â€”he was following two loaded vans of Mr. McNamara's down St Dunstan's-hill, which leads to Billingsgateâ€”he then returned up the hill, and met the third van, which was loaded with herringsâ€”East was driving that van, and I saw him remove himself sideways and shove off the padâ€”that is a basket of herrings, containing about a hundred or soâ€”Mackin picked it up, and ran alongside of the church, up the steps into Cross-laneâ€”I was following himâ€”he turned round, saw me running after him, and dropped the padâ€”I picked it up, and lost sight of himâ€”I went to McNa
mara's office, and gave information to the foremanâ€”Mackin was taken in custody by constable 520, about two hours afterwardsâ€”I do not know what Mackin is at the market, but I have been engaged to watch him and othersâ€”I am quite certain he is the man I saw that morning.

Cross-examined by MR. LLOYD (for Mackin) Q. How long bate you known him? A. About a couple of months, but I have been watching him about two or three weeksâ€”It was Mr. McNamara's foreman who pointed him out to me first, some days previousâ€”that was not the first time my attention had been drawn to this matter, Mr. Arthur McNamara first drew itâ€”this is the first time of my knowing anything wrong of himâ€”I had known him personally, by seeing him as I might see him now, about a couple of months, passing through the market, going to McNamara's officeâ€”I have seen him more than two or three times; several times; say half-a-dosen timesâ€”it was a dark morning on 28th Novemberâ€”I do not know what he is, further than seeing him in the dress he is in nowâ€”when I first saw him that morning I was standing against the round posts on St. Dunstan's-hill, in company with McNamara's foremanâ€”we both followed him downâ€”I was just across the street, about six or seven yards from him.
East. What he has been saying of me is false.
MR. LEWIS. Q. Are you a liveryman of the City of London? A. No.

CHARLES JECKS . I am traffic manager to Mr. Arthur McNamaraâ€”I was with the last witness on the morning of 28th November, and saw Mackin, about five minutes past 6, in Thames-street, at the corner of St. Dunstan's-hillâ€”I did not see him do anythingâ€”I saw him pass away, and I went and communicated with Singletonâ€”I recollect East's van driving upâ€”I found one short out of Novemberâ€”I do not know what he fifteenâ€”there ought to have been fifteen pads of herrings in the lot, and there were only fourteen.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known Mackin? A. Well; I think, these three or four yearsâ€”I cannot tell how long it is since the other man knew himâ€”it is about two or three weeks ago that his attention was directed to him by our firmâ€”I do not know whether Mackin is a liverymanâ€”he kept a shop once, and he jobs about the marketâ€”I do not know anything about himâ€”I only know him by seeing him aboutâ€”I do not know that Mackin has worked for Mr. Reid forten yearsâ€”I cannot say whether he has or not.
COURT. Q. Who is Reid? A. A fish salesman in the market.
WILLIAM GALE (City-policeman, 520). I took the prisoners into custodyâ€”they both said they knew nothing about it.
East's Defence. I am not guilty. I never turned the herrings off; and did not know they were off.

MR. LLOYD to WILLIAM GALE Q. Do you know anything against the man's character? A. No; except that he is a suspicious characterâ€”I have seen him about themarketâ€”I say that, because our attention has been drawn to him this last two or three weeksâ€”I knew nothing against him before that.
GUILTY .

MR. LEWIS stated that the depredations for some weeks past, had amounted to 20l. a week; that the day before, a pad of fish, value 30s. was lost from East's van; and that complaints had been made several times, of losses from his vans.

EASTâ€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

MACKINâ€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

138.
JOHN CROCKET (22)
, Robbery, with a man unknown, on
Edmund Parker, and stealing from his person I hat, 2 handkerchiefs, and 15s. in money, his property.

EDMUND PARKER . I live at 2, Denmark-street, Soho; and am a leather ease makerâ€”on morning of 5th December, about 2 o'clock, I was on my way home, going through Broad-street, St. Gilesâ€”two men came up to me; the prisoner was one of themâ€”they rushed upon me, and knocked me downâ€”I thin'k I must have received the blow in my chest; I felt pain there afterwardsâ€”it was so sudden I believe it was with the fistâ€”it must have been hard; it knocked me downâ€”my hat was lost in the affrayâ€”it fell off the instant I was downâ€”there were two pocket handkerchiefs in itâ€”I had about 15s. in my right-hand waistcoat pocket before this happenedâ€”when I was on the ground, the prisoner seized me by the throat instantly, and asked me if I had any money; I said, "No"â€”the other man was feeling about my waistcoat pocket in which I had the moneyâ€”I struggled, and called "Police!" as well as I was ableâ€”the hard pressure on my throat by the prisoner, prevented me from calling out loudlyâ€”the handkerchiefs and hat were taken away as well as the 15s.â€”as soon as the policeman came up, they made off, and ran away in different directionsâ€”I was on my back when they ran awayâ€”the handkerchiefs were cotton ones; worth about 18d. the two.

Cross-examined by MR. SHARPE. Q. I believe on this morning you had been out for a spree, had you not? A. I had notâ€”I had been drinking a little, not so much but what I could recognise the prisonerâ€”I had been to a meeting at my clubâ€”I was not soberâ€”I had been at my club the whole of the evening, from about 9 I thinkâ€”I had not been drinking before I went to my clubâ€”I dined at 1 o'clockâ€”I had a pint of weak ale at dinner, nothing elseâ€”I had half a pint of ale about 7â€”that was all I had between dinner and supperâ€”I had supper about 8 or 9 o'clockâ€”that was not at the clubâ€”I had not any gin or spiritsâ€”I cannot say whether I had any more beer besides that half-pintâ€”I had half a pint of ale to drink for supper, no spirits or wineâ€”it was a benefit clubâ€”we amused ourselves with arguments and different alterations of the rules, we smoked then, and moistened our clayâ€”I might have had a pint or a pint and a half at the club, I might have had a little moreâ€”I did not notice what I tookâ€”I had some spirits, I had no wine; spirits and ale principallyâ€”I might have tasted porterâ€”when I was knocked down, my hat fell off, and I did not see it afterwardsâ€”I got up directly the policeman came up, and followed in the direction he went, and very soon afterwards I met him with the prisoner in his custodyâ€”when I was examined before, I had no doubt that it was the prisoner who was pressing upon my throatâ€”I knew which man it was when I was examined before the Magis
trateâ€”I am quite sure of what the prisoner said to meâ€”I am sure he asked me if I had any moneyâ€”I did not remember that when I was examined before the Magistrateâ€”it did not occur to meâ€”I remember it nowâ€”my memory is very badâ€”it improved afcer I got sober, there is no question about thatâ€”the money I had was not far short of 15s.â€”I last saw my money when I was coming home, after I left the clubâ€”I did not take it out of my waistcoat pocketâ€”it is about a quarter of an hour's walk from the club where I met these menâ€”the club is in Rathbone-placeâ€”between my leaving the club and seeing these two men, I did not take out my moneyâ€”I know it was in my pocketâ€”I had no occasion to look at it after leaving the clubâ€”I paid for what I had to drink at the clubâ€”that might have been about an hour before I leftâ€”I did not change any money in paying thatâ€”I paid it in silverâ€”I had eighteen shillings in my pocket when I left my home, shortly before 9â€”I knew what I had spentâ€”I knew I had that money in my pocket, I could feel itâ€”I cannot swear that I put my hand to my pocketâ€”I know the money

was in my pocket when I was at the clubâ€”I had eighteen shillings before I went in thereâ€”I might have spent three shillings at the club; we put togetherâ€”I might have paid for half a gallon of ale or moreâ€”the whole of the members were there, about eightyâ€”in the first instance, at the station-house, I said that I had lost my hat, and two handkerchiefs, and did not say any
thing about losing my money, for the moment, till I discovered what I had lostâ€”I mentioned it directly afterwardsâ€”when these two persons came up, there was not a woman with them, that I sawâ€”I did not run up against themâ€”I did not run against a woman, and they strike me for itâ€”I was not near enoughâ€”I am quite certain I did notâ€”I saw no woman, it was very dark, and raining very fast.

MR. PLATT. Q. When you saw the prisoner coming along in custody of the policeman, did you say to him anything about what you had lost? A. Yes; 1 told him I was knocked down and robbed of 15s., and my hat, and handkerchiefâ€”that was immediately after the robberyâ€”I was so terrified that I hardly know what I did sayâ€”I don't remember what I said; I paid for what I drank as I had itâ€”I put my hand in my waistcoat pocket when I did that and took a coin outâ€”I had 18s. before I came out.
COURT. Q. The last time you made a payment, did you feel money in your waistcoat pocket? A. Yes; I was alone when I was knocked down.

WILLIAM WHEELER (Policeman, F 18). I was on duty about 3 o'clock, on the morning of the 5th, in Broad-street, and heard a cry of "Police"â€”I stepped lightly across the roadâ€”I stooped down first and saw two men busily engaged in something; the prisoner was one of themâ€”he was holding the prosecutor downâ€”I am sure he is the manâ€”I did not lose sight of him for a second, till I took him into custodyâ€”the other man was rifling the prose
cutor's pocketsâ€”I saw his hand in the right-hand pocket of his waistcoatâ€”I got within four yards of them before they saw me; they then turned and saw me, and ran awayâ€”the other man went up George-street, and got awayâ€”the prisoner went up High-streetâ€”I called out, "Stop thief!" and sprang my rattleâ€”I saw another constable coming towards me from the opposite side of the street, the prisoner was then going up High-streetâ€”I kept him in view; he ran into the passage of a house, previous to that he tell, which enabled me to gain upon him within a yardâ€”I got up to him and almost put my hand upon himâ€”when he got into a passage I turned my light on, and saw him trying to force a door openâ€”I took him into custody thereâ€”I never lost sight of him for a single momentâ€”on my way back, I saw the prosecutor coming towards me, with both hands upon his throat as if suffering, from painâ€”I had then got the prisoner with meâ€”the prosecutor instantly recognised the prisoner, and said he had robbed him of a hat, two handkerchiefs, and 15s.â€”I do not think the prisoner said anything at that timeâ€”when I had him in the dock and the charge was read, he said that the prosecutor had struck him first, and that he knocked him downâ€”he also mentioned a womanâ€”I saw no woman thereâ€”the prosecutor was drunk; he could stand; he walked with me to the stationâ€”we always understand when a man is worse for drink that he is drunkâ€”he could walk alone.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose when you stepped lightly across the street, you did it in order that they might not hear you? A. Yes; I was not exactly behind' themâ€”I was more on the rightâ€”they were close to the kerbstoneâ€”I was about six yards from the kerb-stone at the time, in the road, and they were about two yards from itâ€”I was more behind than in frontâ€”supposing there was a line drawn across the street, through the men who were struggling, I was about half a yard behind itâ€”I was about four yards
from themâ€”I was not a couple of yards behind the lineâ€”they turned round and looked at me and then ran awayâ€”I did not turn my bull's-eye on them.

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows: "The gentleman was in company with another gentleman and a female; he knocked against me and I struck him; they were singing as they came along; we fell down and the gentleman halloed out' Police!' as to robbing him I never did it; if 1 had been quite sober, I should not have taken any notice of it; I was not drunk."
MR. SHARFB to WILLIAM WHEELER. Q. Do you know anything against this man? A. No.
COURT. Q. Do you know him at all? A. Yes; I have known him for about six weeksâ€”I never knew him in custody for felonyâ€”he is known in the division, from when he was born.
MR. PLATT. Q. I ask you whether he has not been in the habit of constantly associating with thieves? A. Yes.
MR. SHARPE. Q. Do you mean to say that of your own knowledge? A. From the fact of persons knowing him in the divisionâ€”I have myself Seen him with persons who are notorious thieves.

p.hi: The prisoner's landlady gave him a good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

139.
JOHN CONNELLY (20)
, Feloniously assaulting
John Athey, and stealing from his person 1 watch and guard, his property.

JOHN ATHEY . I reside at 76, Jermyn-street, and am clerk of some works now being carried on, Turkish-baths buildingâ€”on the morning of the 7th Decem
ber, about 5 o'clock, I was in Cockspur-street, and a man, whom I suppose to be the prisoner, suddenly ran against me with such violence, as to knock me into the road on my backâ€”before I had time to recover myself, I felt a sudden tug at my watch-guard, which was round my neckâ€”the guard brokeâ€”I called out "Police," and "Stop thief!"â€”I then got up and saw the man who had started from me, from fifteen to twenty yards from me, running in the direction of Dorset-placeâ€”I gave chase, calling out" Police!"â€”I followed him to Dorset-place, and then into Whitcomb-street, and in a small street there I found in custody of a police-constableâ€”I only lost sight of him just as he went round the cornerâ€”I charged him with knocking me down and robbing meâ€”at the moment of the assault, I did not see the man sufficiently to recognise himâ€”I saw him, with sufficient distinctness immediately afterâ€”I recognised him by having a light jacket onâ€”he was the party I followedâ€”I am quite satisfied that the prisoner is the man I then sawâ€”I saw no other man.

Cross-examined by MR. ABRAM Q. What works are these that you are occupied on? A. Some new works in Jermyn-streetâ€”I generally leave off work about half-past 5â€”I left home about 8 o'clockâ€”I was with some friends, whose names I will mention if you likeâ€”I do not desire to say where we wentâ€”we were in several places of amusement, and I had had something to drink, perhaps six or seven glasses of gin and waterâ€”I was not quite sober, but I was so that I understood that I was assaulted and robbedâ€”I did not recognise the prisoner as the man who knocked me down, but he is the person I saw running away from me immediately I got upâ€”I have all along believed he is the man.
MR. KIDD. Q. Were you sufficiently in possession of all your senses, to distinguish objects and to know a man? A. I was.

JOHN WATKINS (Policeman, C 154). At 5 o'clock, in the morning of 7th December, I was in Whitcomb-street, Pall-mall-eastâ€”I heard a cry of "Stop thief," and immediately after that I met the prisonerâ€”he came running up as fast as he couldâ€”I stopped him, and he said, "For God's sake, don't stop me, I am going to work at the Exhibition"â€”I took him back and met the prosecutor coming in the direction he ranâ€”the prosecutor said, "That is the man I believe; I believe that to be the man."

Cross-examined. Q. Are you quite sure he said, "For God's sake?" A. I amâ€”I did not address anything to him before he said thatâ€”I had been standing there some ten minutesâ€”I did not see any one else aboutâ€”I took the prisoner about twenty yards from the place where the procecutor was robbedâ€”I looked for the watch, but there was a great deal of rain, dirt, and mud in the street.

JOHN CARPENTER (Policeman, A 77). I was on duty near Cockspur-street about 5 o'clock on the morning of 7th December, and heard a cry of "Stop thief!"â€”I saw Mr. Athey, the prosecutor, in Cockspur-streetâ€”he made a statememt to meâ€”I met the constable Watkins bringing the prisoner backâ€”I saw him before the other constable didâ€”we both took the prisoner up to the prosecutorâ€”he said he believed the prisoner was the man.

Cross-examined. Q. You saw some other working men about, did you not? A. I met one working man; he was dressed like the prisonerâ€”he had a light jacket on like the prisonerâ€”he had a can in his hand, appeamg to me as if he was going to work.

COURT. Q. Was that after you heard the cry of "Stop thief?" A. It was; he was coming in the direction of the National Galleryâ€”he was walking, and coming in the direction opposite from that the prosecutor came.

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows: "At half-past 4 o'clock on this Saturday morning I left my brother's house to see if I could get a day's work. I went along the Strand, and stood at the end of Trafalgar-street I was going to see a man in Whitcomb-street; the morning being cold I ran, and the constable stopped meâ€”I said to him, that I was going towards the Exhibition, not to it."
COURT to JOHN ATHEY. Q. Did you lose your watch? A. Yes, and a silver-guard.

The prisoner received a good charaeter.â€”
GUILTY .â€”
Nine Months.

140.
FREDERICK JOHN ABBOTT (15), Was indicted
for feloniouaiy assaulting
George Wigg, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.

GEORGE WIGG . I am a shoemaker, at Ilfordâ€”on the afternoon of 12th December, about 4 o'clock, there was a dispute between me and Charles Spallâ€”the prisoner was presentâ€”I told Spall that if he did not leave off I would get up and set him downâ€”I got up to set him down, and as I did so I felt something touch me in my sideâ€”I looked behind me and saw the prisoner going backwards to his seat, with a knife in his handâ€”I went back to sit down in my seat, and found the blood running down my legâ€”I went out into the garden, undid my clothes, and examined my leg, and found blood flowing from my right buttockâ€”I went back to the shop where I had

been working when this occurred, and showed the wound to Spall and the prisoner, and all of them in the shopâ€”Spall advised me to go to the doctor, and he told the prisoner he would give him a good hidingâ€”he said, "I saw him thrust the knife at your side, but I did not know that he had stabbed you"â€”I went over to Mr. Sullivan's, the doctor'sâ€”this (produced) is the knifeâ€”I had had no quarrel with him on that dayâ€”I had some time back.

Cross-examined by MR. F. H. LEWIS. Q. You were on very good terms with the prisoner, were you not? A. I was very friendly with him, but he did not seem to be so with meâ€”I had had no quarrel with him for some time previouslyâ€”this is a kuife which he uses in his workâ€”it is A shoemaker's knife.
MR. HORRY. Q. Have you seen it in his hand before? A. Yes; he had threatened to stab me several times before this.
MR. LEWIS. Q. You know that was only in fun, don't you? A. I don't know; he seemed enraged, and I took the knife from himâ€”I was not doing anything to him at the timeâ€”his seat was next to mine.

HENRY WOODS (Policeman, K 388). I received this knife from the last witnessâ€”he brought it to me at the station, on the evening of 12th Decem
berâ€”in consequence of what he said I apprehended the prisonerâ€”I told him he was charged with stabbing George Wiggâ€”he made no answer.

FREDERICK SMITH . I am errand-boy, in the service of Mr. Spall, the shoe-makerâ€”I was in the shop on Thursday, 12th December, between 4 and 5 o'clock, and saw the prisoner and young Spall, and heard some words between Wigg and Spallâ€”the prisoner stabbed Wigg with this knifeâ€”he was at work at the time, sitting on his seatâ€”I afterwards saw the wound; there was blood flowing from it very fast.

Cross-examined. Q. Was the prosecutor stooping down at the time? A. The prisoner partly got up from his seat and thurst the knife at himâ€”I can't recollect which hand he bad the knifeinâ€”Wigg was holding young Bpali down at the time the wound was inflicted.

EDWARD SULLIVAN . I am a surgeon at Ilfordâ€”between 7 and 8 o'clock on the evening of 12th December, Wigg came to meâ€”I found a small in
cised wound on the right buttock, which had bled pretty freelyâ€”it was of a very trivial character indeed.

Cross-examined. Q. If a knife had been thrust against so tender a part of the body, would you not have expected a much greater wound? A. Decidedly; the wound was not three lines in depth, nothing more than through the cuticleâ€”it was a very slight wound indeed.

p.hi:
of unlawfully wounding.â€”Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury and prosecutor.â€”
Confined One Month.

div1.p:
141.
SAMUEL KELLY (25)
, Stealing 4 copper boilers, value 3l. 10s. the property of
William Kibbey.

WILLIAM KIBBIY . lam an ironmonger, at 22, Broadway, Stratfordâ€”on the evening of 6th November, 1 put these four coppers (produced) out before my shop, by the side of the doorâ€”they were safe at a quarter-past 7â€”they are worth about 3l. 10s.â€”I missed them about a quarter to 8, I should thinkâ€”I did not see them again until the prisoner was taken into custodyâ€”I knew they were sent to the police-station the same evening.

WILLIAM AUSTIN . 1 live with my father and mother in Chapel-street, King-street, Stratfordâ€”I am just upon 15 years oldâ€”on 6th November, about 7 or 8 o'clock, 1 was in Wood's yard, sitting on a gate, and two men

came in with some coppers on their shoulders, and put them down; I think the prisoner was one of themâ€”I had seen him before driving a donkey in Stratfordâ€”I knew him by sight previouslyâ€”the other man said to the prisoner, "You take and put it down and go away, and I will stop here"â€”the prisoner then left, and the other man went and leant over the palingsâ€”I then saw two policemen come running by, and then he ran awayâ€”I saw the prisoner come back afterwards, look at the coppers, and then go away againâ€”I then took the coppers, and carried them to Mr. Bradley, an ironmonger in Stratfordâ€”he told me they were not his, and I brought them back and put them in the same placeâ€”the police came up, and I told them about itâ€”they asked me to carry the coppers down to the station, and I did so.
Prisoner. Q. Are you sure it was me? A. I think it was you; seeing you before, I thought it was youâ€”you have not got the same clothes on as you had then.

THOMAS SIMPSON . I am a bootmaker at 1, High-street, Stratfordâ€”on the night of 6th November, about quarter to 8, I saw the prisoner come out of Wood's yardâ€”I am quite certain it was himâ€”he went in the direction of London.

Prisoner. Q. Have you never seen me come out of Wood's yard before; is there not a skittle-ground there? A. Yes, there is a beer-shop, with a skittle-ground; there is a way down Wood's yard into the skittle-groundâ€”it is not a thoroughfare.

COURT. Q. Where did you see him coming out, coming the way they would come from the skittle-ground? A. They all come through that gateâ€”whether he was coming from Wood's yard, or the skittle-ground, he would come through that gate.

JAMES KNIGHT (Policeman, K 400). On the night of 6th November, I was on duty in High-street, Stratfordâ€”I saw the little boy Austin there, and he gave me a description of some one who had stolen coppersâ€”I searched for some one, but I could not find himâ€”the boy took the coppers to the station.

GEORGE HUNTER (Policeman, N 357). On 7th November I had a description of some one given me, and I was in search of the prisonerâ€”I took him in custody on 27th November, in Whitechapelâ€”I told him I should take himâ€”he said, "What for?"â€”I said, "For stealing four copper boilers from Stratford"â€”he made no replyâ€”I conveyed him to West Ham stationâ€”the boy was sent for, and when be came there, he identified the prisoner.

COURT. Q. He came, and was asked whether that was the person? A. He was brought into the police-station, and as soon as he saw the prisoner he said he was the manâ€”there were other constables there, one in plain clothes.
Prisoner's Defence. I went to live along with my mother, who lives at Stepney.
NOT GUILTY .

142.
ELIJAH RIBBINS (22)
, Stealing 6 lbs. of pork and 13s. in money, the property of
Elijah Bland, his master; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

143.
JAMES ASHTON (34)
, Stealing 40 lbs., of gun-metal, 19 brass tools, value 10l. 15s. and 31 lbs. of leaden bullets, value 7s. 6d., the property of
Our Lady the Queen, his mistress, after a previous conviction in February, 1855; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

144.
THOMAS DUNMORE (28)
, Feloniously uttering counterfeit coin.

EDWARD HILL . I am barman at the King's Arms public-house, Church-street, Deptford. On 6th December, about a quarter-past 11 o'clock, the prisoner came for a pint of porter, for which he paid 2dâ€”he then had a second pint, and gave me a florinâ€”I gave him 1s. 10d. change, and put it on top of the silver in the bowlâ€”there was only one other florin there, and that was at the bottomâ€”I had some conversation with my mistressthree minutes afterwards, took out the florin, which was in the same position, and gave it to her.

THOMAS STOCKS . I am landlord of the King's Arms public-house, Dept
ford. On 6th December I saw the prisoner there for a minuteâ€”a constable came to the side doorâ€”I had some conversation with himâ€”I then spoke to my wife; she spoke to the barman in my presence, who went to the till, took out a florin, and gave it to my wife in my presence, and I marked it, and gave it to the constableâ€”this is it (produced).

WILLIAM BOLL . I am in the service of my father, a coffee-shop keeper at Deptford. On 7th December, about 1 o'clock, the prisoner came for some coffee, and tendered a florinâ€”I tried it with my teeth, bent it a little, told him it was bad, and asked him where be got itâ€”he snatched it out of my hand, and gave me a good sixpenceâ€”a constable came to the door and spoke to me, and then took the prisoner.

CAROLINE GIPLHAM . I am a widow, of 62, Douglas-street, Deptfordâ€”I have been in the habit of buying watercresses of the prisonerâ€”on 19th No
vember he called and asked me to lend him a shilling to buy watercressesâ€”in the evening he repaid me, and I told him that I had a waistcoat of my son's which I would give him, but I saw no more of himâ€”when I took the shilling to the light I found it was badâ€”I marked it, and gave it to the constable.

JAMES RUSSELL (Policeman, R 282). On Friday night, 6th December, I saw the prisoner outside the King's Arms, Deptfordâ€”I called the landlord, and he went in and found a bad florin in the tillâ€”I then went in search of the prisoner, and found him at Mr. Bull's coffee-shopâ€”I had some conversa
tion with one of the witnesses who was there, in consequence of which I told the prisoner I wanted him to go to the police-station with me for passing bad moneyâ€”he said that he was ready to goâ€”I took him to the station, searched him, and found on him this bad florin, two sixpences, and 5 3/4 d. in copperâ€”this other florin was given me at the police-station by Mr. Stocksâ€”this shilling was given me by Mrs. Gillham at the station.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These are all bad, and the florins are from the same mould.
GUILTY .â€”He was further charged with having been before convicted at this Court, in July, 1860;to which he
PLEADED GUILTY>,** and the Jury then found him

GUILTY of a felonious uttering.â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

145.
JOHN ROBINSON (25)
, Stealing 4 lbs. of pork, value 3s., the pro
perty of
William Selmes, after a previous conviction of felony, in April, 1859; to which he
PLEADED GUILTY .**

p.hi:
Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.â€”
Confined Six Mouths.

div1.p:
146.
ELIZABETH JONES (38)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

MRS. GOSLING. I am the wife of John Gosling, and keep a tobac
conist's shop at Blackheath. On the evening of 5th December, between 7 and 8, the prisoner came and asked for half an ounce of tobaccoâ€”she tendered me a two shilling piece in payment, and I gave her 1s. 10 1/2 d. changeâ€”I threw the two shilling piece into the tillâ€”there were no others thereâ€”the prisoner went away, taking the tobacco with herâ€”a few minutes afterwards a police-constable, named Margetson, came in, and in consequence of what he said, I looked at the florin in the till, found it to be bad, and gave it to himâ€”no one had been to the till after I put the florin there.

MARY ANN WHITTLE . I am barmaid at the Crown public-house, Black
heath. On the evening of 5th December, between 7 and 8, the prisoner came there and asked for a halfâ€”quartern of ginâ€”she tendered a two-shilling piece in payment; and while I was giving her change the officer came inâ€”he asked me, in the prisoner's hearing, what she had given meâ€”I said, "A twoâ€”shilling piece"â€”he asked me if it was goodâ€”I said I would see, I thought soâ€”I tried it in the tester, and found it to be badâ€”I had laid the change downâ€”the prisoner was taken by the policeman, and I gave him the bad florin.

ANNE GEARSTEN . I keep a chandler's shop at Deptfordâ€”on 21st November, last, the prisoner came to my shop and purchased some dripping, which came to 4d.â€”she gave me a two shilling pieceâ€”I gave her 1s. 8d. change, and she went awayâ€”I did not put the florin out of my hand till after she was goneâ€”I then looked at it and said, "Oh, I have taken a bad two-shilling piece"â€”I put it by itself on a shelfâ€”on 5th December a policeman named Turner came to my shop, and I gave him the twoâ€”shilling pieceâ€”I have no doubt about the prisoner.
Prisoner. The other two pieces of money I must confess to. but this I do not know anything about.

JAMBS MARGETSON (Policeman, R 122). On 5th December I saw the prisonerâ€”she was being followed by a policeman named Turnerâ€”I followed also in his companyâ€”I went to the shop of Mrs. Gosling, and had some con
versation with her, and she gave me this two-shilling piece (produced)â€”I then followed the prisoner to the Crown public-houseâ€”I saw her go in, and directly after she entered the door, I followedâ€”the prisoner was just in the act of taking up a quartern of gin in a glass to drink, and I said, "Put that down"â€”the barmaid then put down change on the counter, and I asked her what coin the prisoner had tenderedâ€”she said, "A two-shilling piece;" I asked her if it was a good oneâ€”she said, "I will see"â€”she then opened the till, put the florin in the tester, and said it was badâ€”she marked it, and gave it to meâ€”I also marked it, and put it in my pocketâ€”the prisoner was in the act of taking up the change, I prevented her, and the barmaid took the change backâ€”my brother constable then came in, and we took hold of the prisoner's handsâ€”I said, "Where is the change you got at Mrs. Gosling's, the cigar shop?"â€”she said, "Feel in my pocket"â€”I felt in her pocket, and pulled out 2dâ€”going to Blackheath she said, "Hold up your hand, and I will give you the other changeâ€”I said, "Where?"â€”she said, "In my mouth"â€”I put up my hand, and she gave me 1s. 6d. out of her mouthâ€”this is the other florin (produced).

JOSIAH TURNER (Policeman, R 237). On 5th December I followed the prisoner from Deptford-broadway to Blackheath-hill, where I fell in with the. last witnessâ€”I went in oonsequenoe of information I received at Mrs. Gearsten's shopâ€”I received this bad florin (produced) from her.
WM. WEBSTER . All these are bad, and two of them are from one mould.
Prisoner's Defence. I deny the third chargeâ€”I gave up all that I had to the police-constable, and told him how I came by it.

GUILTY .*â€”
Confined Fifteen Months.

147.
WILLIAM CONNOLLY (64)
, Stealing 84 lbs. of lead, the property of
Frank Clark Hills and another.

JAMES MARGETSON (Policeman, R 122). On Wednesday, 20th November, about 7 o'clock in the evening, I was on duty in South-street, Greenwich, and saw the prisoner go into a marine-store dealer's shop, kept by a Mr. White, in Southâ€”streetâ€”he had a bag under his arm, containing something apparently heavyâ€”I followed him in, and saw him put some lead piping into the scaleâ€”there was threeâ€”quarters of a cwt., it was weighed by the marineâ€”store dealerâ€”I asked the prisoner where he got itâ€”he said, "I brought it from a house in London-street, Greenwich"â€”I said, "Where did you bring it from?"â€”he refused to give me any further accountâ€”he said, You know me; you know where I live"â€”I said, "If you don't give a satisfactory account of this lead I shall take you to the station"â€”he then said, "I found it in my yard on some litter, covered over with a sackâ€”I said, "You have told two different tales; unless you give a satisfactory account I shall take you to the police-station"â€”I took him and the lead to the police-stationâ€”there were eleven pieces of leaden pipe, of different lengthsâ€”that which has been identified by Mr. Hills' servant is hereâ€”I really cannot tell the lengths of themâ€”I have two or three pieces hereâ€”they are most of them that length.

Cross-examined by MR. PALMER. Q. Were you near the marine-store dealer's shop? A. I wasâ€”I know it very wellâ€”we are friendly as far as I know himâ€”we speakâ€”I reside close to the prisoner, in the same streetâ€”I have resided in Greenwich just upon seven yearsâ€”I have known this man during that time, and have always believed him to be a respectable man up to the present timeâ€”that is the character he has borne in the neighbour
hoodâ€”he did not say that he bought the lead in London-street; he said, "I brought it from a respectable house in London-street"â€”he repeated that two or three timesâ€”he would not have to pass through London-street to get into South-streetâ€”he did not come that wayâ€”leaving his home, of course, he could go down into London-street to do so, but it would be a very long wayâ€”I am quite positive about his saying London-streetâ€”he was telling the marine-store dealer when I went in, that he brought it down London-street; and the marine-store dealer said, "He told me he brought it from London-street, and I allowed my boy to go down with a truck"â€”I did not tell the Magistrate about what the marine-store dealer saidâ€”this is the property of Mr. Hillsâ€”I told the Magistrate all thisâ€”that was the defence the prisoner set up to the Magistrateâ€”he did not say that the sack was Mr. Hills,' I afterwards found that outâ€”there is nocharge for stealing the sackâ€”I know the man's premises well from residing in the neighbourhoodâ€”he is a fly-ownerâ€”he does his work himself, I believeâ€”he has two sons, and I believe the prisoner was a sort of horse-keeper to his sons till very recently; now I believe he goes out with the cabsâ€”he has lost several horses, and now goes out with the cabs himself, I believeâ€”his premises are half a mile or more, from Mr. Hills' worksâ€”there is a contract work going on there now between his house and Mr. Hills' works, what they call the low levelâ€”you can go in which way you please to the prosecutor's premises

â€”there is one way down the Greenwich-road, down Church-streetâ€”that would be more than half a mile; and there is another way by the creek, by paying a pennyâ€”that would be more than a quarter of a mileâ€”I cannot say what is the breadth of the creek; there is sufficient room for two barges to pass, or two brigs; two fullâ€”sized brigs can pass each otherâ€”I believe there is a cofferdam across the creekâ€”a short plank would not take a man across itâ€”it is as wide as across this Court, I supposeâ€”they would not be able to place a plank at allâ€”there is sufficient room for a brig to pass along between this place and the creekâ€”they are only allowed to block up half the creekâ€”only one vessel can pass at a time, and that only at high waterâ€”there are little boats belonging to the cofferdamâ€”I never saw men cross there, going to these works, in the dayâ€”the cofferdam does not, I think, join Mr. Hills' premises; I would not say positivelyâ€”I never saw but one boat there, and that belongs to the company, to go up or down the riverâ€”I believe there are barges constantly unloading all dayâ€”I have seen them there night and day, constantly at work in their ordinary way of businessâ€”the prisoner's premises do not open on a public laneâ€”the gates do not open on the Norman-roadâ€”oh, yes! his premises are enclosed with some high board-fence, and the cabs pass in and out through two large wooden gates, which are always kept looked or closedâ€”you cannot see through themâ€”they are not broken down, they are newly put upâ€”the place has been lately repairedâ€”it belongs to Mr. Peck hamâ€”there is a respectable tradesman close to Mr. White, who has a donkey and cart, which I believe are placed in that yard, and there is another man who has a barrow, and his things, I believe, are put in that yardâ€”I am never on night dutyâ€”I pass in and out all day, and all hours of the nightâ€”I must pass his premises to go homeâ€”I have no appointed time for going home; perhaps I go home generally at 10 o'clock, perhaps 1 or 2 o'clock in the day, or perhaps 6 o'clockâ€”I have seen the gates locked up and securely fastened up, when the cabs come home, and I have seen the sons go direct to the door and get the key, and go and unlock the premises and put their cab inâ€”I believe they have cabs that are out all night, and that come home at all hoursâ€”I believe the prisoner has three childrenâ€”his wife is very near-sighted, but she isâ€”not blindâ€”she came and opened the door when I went to the prisoner's house, and took me into the front room, and I know the woman very wellâ€”I know she is not stone blind.

JOHN SCALES . I live at 72, st. james-place Churchâ€”street, Deptford, and am a plumberâ€”I have been in the service of Mr. Frank Clark Hills, chemical works, Deptford, ever since 1834â€”the prisoner has been employed in removing straw and stuff from near those premisesâ€”he has been employed by the man, not by Mr. Hillsâ€”I should say that the rubbish and waste which he removed was between fifty and sixty feet from where he got this pipeâ€”this piece of lead (produced) is three-quarter pipeâ€”there are some of various lengthsâ€”it had been applied to the vitriol pans, for drawing off; applied as a syphonâ€”the length of this piece is, as near as I can guess, about 3ft. 6in.â€”there is some 4ft 6in. and some 10 ftâ€”the lengths I have mentioned apply to the various lengths of lead which were lying within fifty feet of the waste removed.

COURT. Q Were there any as much as 10 ft.? A. No, not in this lotâ€”the pieces in this lot were about this lengthâ€”the constable produced eleven pieces of lead to meâ€”I did not measure all of themâ€”there was very little difference in their lengthsâ€”the length was 3ft 6in. as near as can beâ€”I did not observe what the length of the other pieces wasâ€”there was

one piece about 18 in. and one piece was lessâ€”I firmly believe that this is Mr. Hills' property by the use that these things are made for, and the work that it is used inâ€”I do not know the date on which the constable came to meâ€”I believe it was towards the end of Novemberâ€”after the police-constable came to me I looked at the large heap which was thereâ€”I did not miss any from itâ€”I cannot say whether it had been pulled about or not, for the foreman has the looking over the warehouseâ€”I believe this to be Mr. Hills' property, which formed part of the heapâ€”this lead is the same size and weight as that on the heapâ€”by the weight, I mean so much to a foot.

Cross-examined. Q. You did not weigh it, or compare it with the heap? A. Yes; I took a piece and compared it before the Magistrate with this off the new rollâ€”I firmly believe that it is Mr. Hills' property, on account of its being similar in length, and the purpose for which it is usedâ€”the use is passing vitriol through itâ€”it is used as a syphonâ€”according to the depth of the pans, they cut the pipe.

COURT to JAMES MARGETSON. Q. When you found the lead, what shape was it in? A. Almost the same shape as nowâ€”when I brought it into Court it was precisely the same, bus during the time I was in the witness-box I suppose the witness bent it out straightâ€”I found it to when I went back, and I bent it back as near as I could.
COURT to JOHN SCALES. Q. Did you straighten it? A. Not here; I did at home.

MR. PALMER. Q. This is a common thickness for lead of this sort?
