A Yes, for our purposesâ€”they do not use such stout lead for water-worksâ€”we buy new lead for our chemical worksâ€”there is a stock taken of our lead every six monthsâ€”I cannot tell what day we did it lastâ€”it has nothing to do with meâ€”there are other stocks besides this in the yard, more than two or three times the quantityâ€”the acid that is passed through this pipe makes it smell, and it turns the leadâ€”the lead here is quite a different colourâ€”the acid turns the colour of the inside of the pipeâ€”there is no smell to thisâ€”it has been well washedâ€”I am used to the smell, and I know it also by the taste of itâ€”I did not wash itâ€”if it had been just taken out of the pans it would bum my clothesâ€”the policemannever told me that it had been well washedâ€”the distance I have Spoken of is 50 or 60 feetâ€”I have never measured itâ€”there are not several other lots of leadâ€”of this kind within 60 or 60 yards, unless it is down at the warehouse, and that if about 150 feet from the place, or nearly soâ€”there if some of the same size in the warehouse; that is under lock and keyâ€”I cannot say where this was taken fromâ€”I do not know that my only reason for saying it was taken from the heap is because that is the nearest placeâ€”I do not know the prisoner's yardâ€”I know where the men are at work in the creekâ€”the men do not go to and from Mr. Hills' works by the creekâ€”Mr. Hills won't suffer itâ€”they have dopeit, and Mr. Hills forbade itâ€”I dare say there are 200 men or more employed there by the Board of Worksâ€”there is a great deal of work going on thereâ€”I know Normanâ€”streetâ€”I don't know whether there is a cab-yard thereâ€”pedlars and hawkers go by there with trucksâ€”there are a great many trucks go up thereâ€”I have not seen trucks put away thereâ€”I have not seen the yardâ€”I know they go along that roadâ€”I cannot read or write; I am no scholar.
COURT. Q. Is this your name? A. yes; I can just make my markâ€”I can just put my name.
MR. PALMER. Q. For five or six years this rubbish has been removed by the prisoner, has it not? A. I cannot say how longâ€”I have been in the

employ of Mr. Hills ever since 1834â€”Mr. Bolger is present when the rubbish is taken awayâ€”I have been in the yard when it has been taken awayâ€”I dare say it may have been taken by this man for as much as five or six yearsâ€”no one else has taken it to my knowledge for the last five or six yearsâ€”I cannot say I have always seen Bolger presentâ€”I have not been presentâ€”I am in different parts of the yardâ€”Mr. Bolger ought to see to thatâ€”I do not know whether the prisoner's wife is blind or notâ€”I am not scholar enough to reckon up the value of the leadâ€”I do not give the value of itâ€”I never had any occasion either to buy or to sell anyâ€”I have not seen my master this weekâ€”Saturday was the last time I saw himâ€”I have not seen him here.

MR. LILLEY. Q. Is that lead, in its present state, suitable for water
pipe? A. Yes; I have tasted it, and taste the remains of vitriolâ€”I have put my finger in some of these pieces, and it tasted acid.

JOHN FRANCIS BOLGER . I am ganger of the vitriol works Where the prisoner wasâ€”it is my duty to see what goes in and out of the worksâ€”I have charge of the whole shopâ€”there are no stacks of lead in my shop; there are several in the yard and at the lead-storesâ€”the stack of pipes Was about sixty yards, I should think, from Where the rubbish was taken; not sixty feetâ€”the lead-stores are above sixty yards.
COURT. Q. Are the lead-stores in the open yard or in a building? A. In a building; there was no heap of old lead in the yard.
JAMES MARGETSON (re-examined). There was a quantity of old lead all round the premises, in the open air, some close handy to where this was taken away from.

J. F. BOLGER (continued). There is no loose lead in the open air at the place where this man comes for the rubbish; there is some at about fifty or sixty feet distanceâ€”it is in all parts, of the yard, and is of different sizesâ€”the particular sizes are not sorted into different stacksâ€”they are of different sizes, sheet lead and pipe leadâ€”there is a store in the warehouse for the leadâ€”we use it in our shops for syphons for vitriolâ€”the vitriol marks the leadâ€”I do not keep an account of the stockâ€”I cannot detect any vitriol marks on this leadâ€”it marks them outsideâ€”the pipes go some way into the pan.

JURY. Q. Do you believe that that is such a syphon as is used in all works? A. Yes; such as that are used in our worksâ€”if this is a syphon, I think there ought to be marks of vitriol on itâ€”there are four used in one set of pans and two in another, six altogether.

COURT. Q. How long do they last? A. I have had them last six months; it is according to the use of themâ€”those that are done with go down into the store-room, and the foreman gives out new onesâ€”if there are any on the heap in the yard, they are done withâ€”they would show very plainly the marks of the vitriol; if this came from that heap, I should expect to see the mark of vitriol on itâ€”I cannot see itâ€”since this matter, I have been down in the warehouse and picked out several that we have had in our use; from the store-room.
JURY. Q. Do you unpack the straw from the old carboys? A. No.

MR. PALMER. Q. Would you, from the comparison you have made of these pipes, and from your knowledge of the trade, swear that that is a syphon that you have had in use? A. No, I could not; I have no belief as to the identity of thisâ€”I have generally been present when the rabbish has been taken away; if I have not been there, one of the men has, from

the same shopâ€”I have seen the prisoner for seven or eight yean, I should think, taking away the rubbishâ€”from where I was in the yard I must have seen if he had taken away three-quarters of a cwt. of lead.

Cross-examined by MR. LANGFORD. Q. How long have you been at the head of the vitriol-house? A. Four years last June, since my father diedâ€”I cannot tell whether this is the same kind of pipe that is used for the syphons in our vitriol-houseâ€”we use three quarter pipe, and an inch and a quarter pipe as wellâ€”this is three-quarter pipeâ€”it is the same sort of pipe that is used in our houseâ€”I know the smell and taste of vitriolâ€”I can-not smell anything of itâ€”we use three-quarter pipes for our syphons.
MR. PALMER. Q. Other people, I believe, use the same size pipe in their chemical works? A. Yes; thousands of tons of this same sort of three-quarter pipe are used for various purposes.

WILLIAM FINCH . I am a large fruit merchant and gardener in the Green
wich roadâ€”I have been there for from twelve to fourteen yeanâ€”I pay the prisoner one shilling a week for a portion of the yardâ€”we can always go in there when we like, and my boy has been there sometimes as early as 6 o'clock in the morning, and as late as 11 at nightâ€”there is a cart standing there sometimes; sometimes moreâ€”I think there is hardly any fastening at all to the place, I really do not knowâ€”I do not go there myselfâ€”he can always get inâ€”you can easily climb over, it is not very highâ€”I have known the prisoner about seven or eight years, I should say, during which time I have found him honest; I have now and then lent him a trifle of money, and he has always repaid meâ€”I never knew anything against himâ€”I know his wife, she is blind, and has been so for, I think, about six monthsâ€”I cannot say exactlyâ€”she can walk about the house.

BENJAMIN ANDREWS . I am a baker, and have resided in Greenwich about forty yearsâ€”I have known the prisoner near upon twenty yeanâ€”I never heard anything against his honestyâ€”I have served him with bread for the last twelve years.

THOMAS BLACKNOW . I reside at Deptford, and am a gardenerâ€”the prisoner is my tenant, and has been so between eleven and twelve yearsâ€”I never heard anything against himâ€”I have always found him a hard-working in
dustrious manâ€”I live about a quarter of a mile offâ€”the prisoner's house faces the gates of the worksâ€”that is my house.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows: "I never stole the lead."
COURT to J. F. BOLGER. Q. How often did he go to remove the rubbish? A. Sometimes once a month, sometimes once in two months.
COURT to JOHN SCALES. Q. Do you know how often he went? A. No, I cannot tell you.
GUILTY â€”Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury on account of his age.

148.
JAMES JOHNSON (38),
RICHARD ROWLANDS (24), and
EDWARD BALDWIN (23)
, Breaking and entering the warehouse of
Morris Harris and others, and stealing 400 lbs., weight of flannel rags, the property of the masters of Johnson and Rowlands.

JACOB MORRIS HARRIS . I am in partnership with my father, Morris Harris, and my brother, Simeon Morris Harris, as rag merchants, in Barron's-place, Waterloo-road, Southwarkâ€”the prisoner Johnson was in our service as fore
man, and Rowlands as carmanâ€”Baldwin had been in our service as a labourer up to within a few days of the robberyâ€”Johnson resides in a house abutting the roof of our warehouseâ€”on Friday, 29th November, I marked a bag con
taining white flannel rags, and saw others marked; one of them contained cloth cuttingsâ€”on the Saturday, I, and my brother, and a police constable concealed ourselves in the warehouse between 5 and 6 in the afternoonâ€”we had not done any business that day, being the Jewish Sabbathâ€”after we had been there about an hour, it must have been about half-past 6, I heard the window of the house adjoining our premises openedâ€”I then heard some steps on the tiles just over our headsâ€”the steps continued along the tiles, and presently I saw some laths, which form a portion of the roof, removed, and the prisoners Baldwin and Rowlands descend from the roof into the ware-houseâ€”the laths extend some fourteen feet, but the opening made was, I should imagine, from six to eight feet, and about four or five feet wideâ€”after that a bag was carried by Baldwin up a ladder which is usually placed there, and put on the tiles; two other bags were then passed through this opening. on to the tiles, by both the prisoners, and they then gotâ€”out on the tiles; but I should have stated that there was a man on the tiles whom I could not distinguish at the timeâ€”I then heard the bags rolled along the tiles, and heard them drop down the wall into the yard at the side of the warehouse, which yard is the fore-court of the prisoner Johnson'sâ€”eâ€”I afterwards went out of the warehouse, and saw Baldwin in the custody of a police-officer, and Johnson and Rowlands running from a van which stood at the door laden with ragsâ€”I went a short distance down the street, and saw Johnson in the custody of my brotherâ€”I then returned and took Rowlands into custody, and handed him over to the police-officer; he had run down an entry which I knew had no thoroughfareâ€”there were some bags in the vanâ€”I did not know who they belonged to, but three of them were our property, and part of those marked on the Fridayâ€”there were five or six other bags of rags in the van.

Cross-examined by MR. LLOYD (for Johnson). Q. Does Johnson deal in rags? A. I do not knowâ€”I do not know that the six bags belonged to himâ€”I believe they did not belong to usâ€”the front of Johnson's house abuts against the roof of our warehouseâ€”the distance from his window to ourâ€”warehouse is scarcely two feetâ€”I suppose that the men got out of that window on to the roofâ€”the van was not standing at the door of Johnson's houseâ€”there is a passage, or fore-court, to the house of about ten or twelve yards, down which the bags must have been carried to be placed in the vanâ€”there was no carman in charge of the vanâ€”the three bags which I identified as ours were in the van with the othersâ€”they were all about the same size, four or five feet long and two or three feet wideâ€”when I saw Johnson run away, I was going towards the van for the purpose of appre
hending himâ€”I did not hear any one call out, "Here comes the governor."

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY (for Rowlands). Q. Was it Rowlands' duty to look after your horses? A. Yesâ€”the stables adjoin the warehouseâ€”I am not aware that at that time one of the horses was lame, not more so than usualâ€”one of them has had a slight splint for some yearsâ€”Rowlands has been in our employ about eight months, always in the same capacityâ€”while I was watching on this occasion, I was on the groundâ€”floor, underneath the tiles; it is a one story warehouseâ€”the loft I speak of is not

next to the roof that I was standing under, it is at the end of the ware-house, and the laths are just in front of it, for the purpose of throwing light into the loftâ€”I was standing in the body of the warehouseâ€”the loft does not extend over the body of the warehouse at all, it only abuts against it.

COURT. Q. What sort of a warehouse is this? A. It is a large ware-house; the portion now in question is one floor only, but at the end there is a building, which some years back was used as a stable and provender loft, and that loft is now converted into a rag storeâ€”the loft is about ten or twelve feet from the floor of the warehouseâ€”rags are stored in the loft and also on the floor of the warehouse; we have some hundreds of tons thereâ€”the warehouse is lighted with gasâ€”the gas was not lighted on this eveningâ€”there are no windows, only about fourteen feet of these lath openings; the laths are about three inches wide, and are placed about four inches apartâ€”that is the only means of lightâ€”the weight of one of these bags would be from about 1 1/2 cwt. to 1 3/4 ewt.; one bag weighed moreâ€”I have not weighed them sinceâ€”that is the average weight of a bag of flannel ragsâ€”the size would be from about four to five feet long and three feet wide.

Cross-examined by MR. TAYLOR (for Baldwin). Q. Do I understand you that after the bags had been taken out the tiles were replaced? A. The laths, not the tiles; no tiles were taken off, some appeared to have been displaced by the feetâ€”the laths were placed on loosely, not nailed onâ€”I can't say whether they had been loose before; I saw them removed by their handsâ€”my brother and the constable were watching with me; we were all standing within a few inches of each other, about four yards from where the entry was madeâ€”the entry was made sixteen or eighteen feet above meâ€”I believe Baldwin came through first, but I would not swear positivelyâ€”the ladder was standing against the wall, where it always stands; it is the means of egress and ingress to the loftâ€”I could see the laths perfectly well from where I stoodâ€”I could see the men come into the premises; they both came down on to the floor of the warehouseâ€”I cannot tell which came on to the floor firstâ€”they were then only about four yards from me, my brother, and the policemanâ€”the prisoners said something relative to there being a large bag; I almost forget the exact words, but I heard the words, "This is a whacker" or something of thatâ€”Baldwin carried up the first bagâ€”one bag was removed from the ground floor, and two from the loft; they were not carried up the ladder, they were lifted up out of the loft on to the roofâ€”Baldwin did not come down into the warehouse again, but I saw him in the loftâ€”I did not see him carry out anything moreâ€”there were some bags lifted up; I did not notice particularly who had them in their arms, but I an satisfied that both lifted the bags from the loft on to the tilesâ€”we all three left the warehouse together; that was after the laths had been replacedâ€”I did not exactly see the laths replaced, I heard them, but I was trying to get out at that time; we had Home distance to go; my brother had then left the policeman and myself and had gone towards the end of the warehouse, towards the doorâ€”he had not gone out; we all went out together.

MR. LEWIS. Q. Was there plenty of light through the eight feet opening? A. Plentyâ€”I will undertake to swear that both Baldwin and Rowlands wore in the warehouse; they were quite as close to me as you are.
COURT. Q. You say the light came through the openings of the laths, what light was there at halfâ€”pant 5 or 6? A. The light of the evening; no more than that.

SIMEON MORRIS HARRIS . I am in partnership with my father and brotherâ€”I was concealed in the warehouse this evening, with my brother and the policemanâ€”I heard the window of the house, belonging to the prisoner Johnson, open, and I saw three persons get out of the window on to the roof of our warehouseâ€”I saw that through the lattice work, which looks on to Johnson's houseâ€”I could not at that time see who the three persons wereâ€”I heard them walk along the roof until they reached the loft; they then removed some palings or laths, and made an opening of some seven or eight feet, or it might be moreâ€”Baldwin and Rowlands then descended into the loftâ€”I saw them get down the ladderâ€”Rowlands then lifted a bag of rags on to the back of Baldwin, and Baldwin earned it up the ladder, and placed it on the tiles, assisted by Rowlandsâ€”Baldwin then stepped on to the ladder again, and from thence into the loft, and took two bags out of the loft, and put on the tilesâ€”they then got on the tiles themselves; but, previous to that, I heard a remark made by Rowlands, "Here is a whacker," that was speaking of the first bag, which was very heavy; and, while in the act of rolling it on to the tiles, it caught the edge of the gutter, and he said, "Hold hard, it catches," or, "it has caught; all right"â€”when they got on the tiles they replaced the laths, and commenced rolling the bags along the tiles, towards the end of the warehouse which looks into the fore-court of Johnson's houseâ€”I then got upon a stack, formed of some bags of rags, and looked through the lattice work into Johnson's yard, and I saw Johnson standing in the yard or foreâ€”court, seven or eight yards up the fore-courtâ€”I saw the bags thrown down to him by those on the tiles; they then passed through the window of the house, and came down and assisted each other to put the bags on each other's backs, and carry them to the vanâ€”they all assisted in thatâ€”we then made the best of our way to the counting-house, and through that into the streetâ€”some noise was made in opening the door, and a remark was made, such as, "There is some one coming"â€”I ran towards the van, and saw Johnson running from the vanâ€”I ran after him, and caught him within a very short distance of the horse's headâ€”Rowlands also ran away, and con
cealed Limself down a little right of way adjoining our warehouseâ€”I did not see where Baldwin was.

Cross-examined by MR. LLOYD. Q. Whose van was this? A. It was a strange vanâ€”I do not know where it was hired fromâ€”there was no one with itâ€”a little boy fetched itâ€”it was not standing in the Waterloo-road, but in Barron's place, a turning out of the road, at the entrance to the fore-court of Johnson's houseâ€”there is a window to Johnson's house, from which they could get on to the roof of our warehouseâ€”it is a large windowâ€”when I first saw Johnson I was only a few yards from him Iâ€”was in the warehouse looking through the lattice-work into the fore-court of Johnson's houseâ€”I could not see the van from where I was thenâ€”I was close to the house, and Johnson was also close to the houseâ€”I saw Johnson go up the fore-court with a bag, and come back without it, so I presume he put it into the vanâ€”there were nine bags in the vanâ€”I could not see the private marks on the, bags when he was carrying themâ€”I could distinguish them from the other bags, because I saw them thrown downâ€”I saw the nine bags carriedâ€”the other six were brought out of Johnson's house, and put down in the yard ready to be taken away with the other threeâ€”I did not see them brought out, but I am certain they were not brought out of the window, because I was there all the timeâ€”from where I was standing by the lattice, I could see the window of Johnson's house; it was almost level with itâ€”I can't say as to the, number of sacks I saw on the groundâ€”I saw three thrown down

â€”the others were not thrown down in the same way; not at that timeâ€”they might have been earlier in the day; but none but the three were thrown down that evening, and they were thrown from our warehouse, not from Johnson's windowâ€”we had commenced watching at 4 o'clockâ€”I don't know that the other six bags were Johnson's; they came from his houseâ€”I don't know that they are not ours; I would sooner say they were than they were not, although we cannot identify themâ€”we dealâ€”in that description of bags.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. You commenced watching about 4, how long had you been there before you heard the footsteps on the roof, and saw the laths removed? A. Very nearly three hours, I should thinkâ€”at the time the laths were removed I was almost underneath, on the floor of the warehouseâ€”I know it was Johnson's window that I heard open, because I saw it as well as heard itâ€”I could not see it from the floor of the ware-house, but I could from another part; and then, during the time the men were walking along the roof, we walked down the warehouse, and reached the bottom of the warehouse about the same time that they removed the laths at the topâ€”the top of Johnson's house is somewhat higher than our warehouseâ€”it is not more than sixteen feet from where we were standing to the roofâ€”at the time Johnson's window opened I was standing on some bags of rags, seven or eight feet high, looking at the window, waiting for it to openâ€”the only light came through the roof, through the lathsâ€”the whole matter took a very short time indeed; they had done it so often they were very perfect in the business.

Cross-examined by MR. TAYLOR. Q. Where did you go to when you left the warehouse? A. Into Barron's-placeâ€”my brother went with meâ€”I believe I got out first, but we all got out close together as fast as we couldâ€”I appre
hended Johnsonâ€”I saw Baldwin afterwards run down the right of way, or foreâ€”court of Johnson's houseâ€”I do not know that he was lodging at John
son'sâ€”I believed he lived with his fatherâ€”I know that he has frequently slept at Johnson's house; but whether he lodged there I do not knowâ€”we were not all three standing together when the men came throughâ€”my brother and the policeman were standing at the bottom of the stack, and I was at the topâ€”that was when the men came through the window of John
son's houseâ€”at the time they came into the warehouse we were all three together, standing under the palingâ€”when the men came to the bottom of the ladder they were so close to us that we might have touched them, had we been so inclinedâ€”I could not see all over the loft from where I stoodâ€”I could see into it, and could see the men there.

HENRY NORTON (Policeman, L 63). I watched with Messrs. Harris on 30th Novemberâ€”the first thing I saw was Rowlands and Baldwin enter the premisesâ€”they came on to the loft, got on to the ladder, and came down to the bottom of the warehouseâ€”Rowlands assisted in putting one bag on Baldwin's backâ€”he carried it up the ladder to a hole which they had made in the roof sufficiently large to get the bag throughâ€”one said it was a thumper, it must be about 2 1/2 cwt.â€”it was then rolled on to the tilesâ€”they then returned to the loft, which is about half-way down, and then they put up two more bags; then went out and secured the place as near as possible as beforeâ€”I afterwards apprehended Baldwin at the side of the warehouse leading from Johnson's house.
Cross-examined by MR. LLOYD. Q. Did he say "a thumper?" A. I believe soâ€”I would not be certain whether it was thumper or whackerâ€”it was one or the other.
Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Had you known Rowlands before?

A. Yes; I had been watching them for nearly a monthâ€”I used to watch them coming up the court talking to each other in the entry to the fore
man's houseâ€”it is a narrow passage between two warehousesâ€”it is no thoroughfare.

Cross-examined by Mr. TAYLOR. Q. Where did you apprehend Baldwin? A. At the side of the warehouse, about twenty or twenty-five yards from Johnson's door, and about ten yards from the streetsâ€”I had seen him run there from the van as I came out of the warehouseâ€”he stopped as soon as I came up to him, and said, "What is it? what is it?â€”I don't know that he lodged at Johnson'sâ€”he did not tell me soâ€”I have seen him backwards and forwards there.

The prisoners' statements before the Magistrate were read as follows: "Bald
win says: I was not in the warehouse at all; the witness must be mistaken. Johnson says: Six of the bags were not Mr. Harris's; the other three were theirs. Rowlands says: Baldwin and Johnson asked me to assist them in puttiug the six bags into the van.

JOHNSONâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Four Years Penal Servitude.

ROWLANDSâ€”
GUILTY .â€”

BALDWINâ€”
GUILTY .â€”

MR. LEWIS stated that, during the last fifteen months, the prosecutor had been robbed to the extent of 1,000l. and they believed Johnson had instigated the other prisoners to join him in the depredations.

149.
DANIEL GARNSEY (22),
Unlawfully taking
Elizabeth Ann Ploughman, aged 14 years, out of the possession of
Alfred Miller; he having lawful charge of her. Second Count, out of the possession of
Mary Louisa Miller, her mother.

ELIZABETH ANN PLOUGHMAN . I was 14 years old last Augustâ€”my mother is married to a gentleman named Miller, and I have lived with them at 10, Church-street, Camberwellâ€”I lived entirely at home, and my employment was fancy needle-workâ€”I had no employment out of doorsâ€”about five weeks ago I became acquainted with the prisonerâ€”I first saw him from my father's windowâ€”he was at work at a house which was being repaired oppositeâ€”I smiled from the window to him, and he smiled back againâ€”afterwards, in the same week, I went over and told him that I had come over to look at the houseâ€”he showed me over itâ€”it lasted about half an hour; I did not hurry myself muchâ€”I had no notion of taking the houseâ€”that was on Saturdayâ€”I met him next day, Sunday, on Camberwell-green, at 6 o'clock in the eveningâ€”that was not accidental; I had arranged with him to meet himâ€”I remained in his company till half-past 8â€”we were walking about all that timeâ€”I got away from him because my parents thought I was going to churchâ€”the prisoner did not know what I had told themâ€”I did not tell him that I had made any excuseâ€”I met him next on Monday evening, and was with him about an hourâ€”I got out because 1 had to go across the green to the grocer'sâ€”between then and the evening when I went away from home, I met him, I suppose, twenty timesâ€”on one of those occasions I told him that I got out to go to Mrs. Sibley's, the lady that employed me; that I had to tell my mother and father soâ€”I met him on Monday evening, 2d December, by Camberwellâ€”green; that was accidentallyâ€”I had told my mother and father that I was going to Mrs. Sibley's again, but I did not intend going; I intended meeting the prisoner,' and I did

meet himâ€”I went with him to the Elephant and Castle, and then he per
suaded me to come back homeâ€”I did not yield to that persuasion; I said that I would not go back homeâ€”nothing had taken place between me and himâ€”I told him that mother and father had been very angry with me at home, because a bill had not been paidâ€”that was trueâ€”when I said that I would not go home, the prisoner took me to his father's house in Drury-laneâ€”we only stayed there a few minutes; we went for a walk, and then we went to Bloomsburyâ€”we first went to a coffee-house in Long-acre, and had some teaâ€”we left there at a little after 8, and went for a walk, and then we went to High-street, Bloomsbury, and did not leave there till next morningâ€”I had never been there beforeâ€”he took a bed there, and I was with himâ€”I slept with himâ€”we went next morning and had coffee at the coffee-shopâ€”I walked about a short time with him, and then I went home with him to his father's, where I met his sister Edith, who went with me to seek for a lodgingâ€”I saw the prisoner again next eveningâ€”I slept with his sister Edith that Tuesday evening, in Bedford-placeâ€”I saw the prisoner on Wednes
day afternoon, and slept with him that night, but not at the same place as we slept on Mondayâ€”on Thursday, the night he was taken in custody, I slept at the lodging, and next morning I went with his father to the police-court, where he was to be examined before the Magistrateâ€”I saw the prisoner yesterday, and spoke to himâ€”he said that he would meet me by the Elephant and Castle, on Sunday evening, if he got off all right.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Did you tell him that your father and mother had been very angry with you? A. Yes; it was about a bill that had not been paid, and father found it out; he had given me the money to pay it, and I gave it to my mother because she asked me for itâ€”I do not know what she did with it, but she did not pay itâ€”she did not spend it; she said that father found it on the shelfâ€”they were frequently angry with me, each of themâ€”mother has hit me several times, sometimes with her hand, and once she hit me with a stick across my head, and it hurt my headâ€”there was no blood at any timeâ€”this has never been in my father's presenceâ€”my father does not go to work, he is in the house all dayâ€”my mother is always soberâ€”I do not know that she has had any
thing to drink when she has beaten me in this wayâ€”I have not told the prisoner of my being badly treated at home, only on the Monday eveningâ€”I told him that I would not return; he tried after that to get me to return; he told me on Wednesday he had promised my father and mother that I should return, but I declined goingâ€”his mother thought it would be best for me to return, and told me so, and I said, "No, I will not go home"â€”after I was taken home I went in search of him again, that was done without any previous communication with him; I had not seen himâ€”I told the prisoner that I was sixteen years oldâ€”I sent some letters home to my motherâ€”I sent the first one on the Tuesday, merely say in g that I was very happy where I was, and did not intend to returnâ€”up to the time that I saw the prisoner on the Monday night that I went away, he did not know that I was going to leave homeâ€”he had not asked me to leave homeâ€”it was simply in consequence of that quarrel at home, and their being angry with me; and when we got to the Elephant and Castle he tried to persuade me to return.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Where did you write these letters, was it at his father's house? A. I wrote one at his father's house, the one in blue inkâ€”he was not present when I wrote it, nor was his father, I was aloneâ€”(Letter read: "Dear Mother and Father, I am quite happy and comfortable, and do not

intend returning home again; I am living with Daniel's sister at present, and do what you will you shall never get me from him, as we have always had regard for each other. I came away of my own accord, so there is no blame attached to him, and I am sure he always meant well towards me. Do not trouble yourselves about me as I shall come and see you soon; your affectionate daughter, Lizzie ")â€”he had not promised to do anything for meâ€”I positively swear that I had not said anything to him before the Monday about my going awayâ€”he always meant well towards me.

ALFRED MILLER . I live at 20, Church-street, Camberwell, and am dis
penser to a medical gentlemenâ€”in August, 1852, I married the last witness' mother, and from that time down to 2d December the child always resided with usâ€”I have behaved towards her with kind
ness ever since I have known herâ€”on Monday, 2d December, she went to Mrs. Sibley's, in Grosvenor-park, who she works for; she was to return in three-quarters of an hour, but did not do so; we did not take notice of it, as she sometimes stopped to finish work thereâ€”I then went to Mrs. Sibley's, but did not find herâ€”her absence that night was not with my consentâ€”on Wednesday, 4th December, about twelve o'clock, I saw the pri
soner with Inspector Frost, of the P division; I asked him where my daughter was, and what he had done with herâ€”he said, "I do not know where she is; I have not seen her since Monday nightâ€”about half an hour afterwards he came over to my houseâ€”I was called in to him, and met him in the passageâ€”he said, "I have told you an untruth, and now I tell you the truth; I did take your daughter away"â€”he went down stairs; Mrs. Miller was there, and Mrs. Osborne; and he said that he took her to his father's house, and she slept there and dined there the following day, Tuesday; and his sister went and took lodgings for her in Bedford-street, but he did not know the numberâ€”Mrs. Miller asked him whether he would produce her, and he said that he would about 5 o'clock that afternoon, solemnly declaring that he had not reduced her, and that he would bring her home a virtuous girlâ€”he did not bring her back at 5 o'clock, nor did she come at all, and I went that night to Bow-streetâ€”on the next day, Thursday, about 9 o'clock in the evening, I saw the prisoner in custodyâ€”he said, "If you will give me time I will produce your daughter"â€”I said, "Where is she?" he said, "I do not know"â€”I gave him in chargeâ€”he is not still working opposite to me; but I have seen him in the neighbourhood of my house since he ceased to work there, as recently as Monday, in this weekâ€”she was then at my house; but was not aware that he was near the placeâ€”I passed him in Church-streetâ€”Saturday was the last day he worked thereâ€”I always treated the girl with the greatest kindnessâ€”there was nothing on my part, or my wife's, that I am aware of, to cause her to leave her home.

Cross-examined. Q. You were angry with her before she left? A. That was all settled, and I forgave herâ€”I was angry with her on Monday after
noon, about 3s. 7d. which I had given to her to pay a billâ€”I asked her why she had not paid it, and she made me no answerâ€”she did not say that she had given it to her motherâ€”her mother said that she had put it on the shelf, and then sent the girl somewhere else, and forgot itâ€”I found it on the shelf on the Mondayâ€”I only said, "You are a naughty girl"â€”her mother then said, "It is my fault;" and it was all settledâ€”I do not know of her mother beating her at any time with a stickâ€”she may have boxed her ears if she has been a bad girl; but I do not believe she ever used a stick to herâ€”I said nothing about sending her away to serviceâ€”my wife is not given to drinking, that I am aware of.

MARY LOUISA MILLER . I was formerly married to a gentleman named Ploughmanâ€”the first witness is my daughterâ€”she was fourteen years old on 11th Augustâ€”when she went away from home. on Monday, 2d Decem
ber, I only knew that she was going out for three-quarters of an hourâ€”her absence during that night, and subsequently, was not with my consentâ€”I have treated her with kindness, and as a mother oughtâ€”I have not beaten her with a stickâ€”I have never corrected her any more than is a mother's dutyâ€”I am never the worse for liquor that I am aware of.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you sent out your daughter for anything to drink? A. No; there are persons on the premises who can vindicate my characterâ€”I have never beaten her with a stickâ€”I have cuffed her ears; but it has been for insolence, and for her misconduct and disobedienceâ€”she would be very impertinent in the way of answering a parentâ€”she did not call me names, but she would not answer me in a proper manner.

MARY OSBORNE . I live at 28, Harvey-road, Camberwellâ€”on Wednesday or Thursday, 4th or 5th December, I heard the prisoner say that he met the girl Ploughman at Camberwell-green on Monday morning, and took her to his father's houseâ€”he was speaking to her father and mother.

JOSEPH KAY (Policeman). I took the prisoner, and told him it was for decoying Elizabeth Anu Ploughman from her parentsâ€”he said that he did not take her away, she went away with him, and she would not go homeâ€”he afterwards called at the prosecutor's house, and said that if they would allow him time, and stay proceedings against him, he would find her.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

150.
ELIAS WHITE (31)
, Feloniously and knowingly receiving 96 collars, the property of
Thomas Welch and others.

MARY ANN BYWATER . I am forewoman to Thomas Welch and others, at their manufactory in Southwark-bridge-roadâ€”I have to receive goods when they are brought into the machine-room, and make an entry of them in this book (produced)â€”I find here an entry in my own writing of a gross of collars, called Oxfords, No, 275, on 29th October, 1860â€”I mark the collars when I enter them, with the number of the grossâ€”I find my mark on these collars (produced) 275â€”all the gross were marked 275â€”they also have on them the stamp of the owner, "W and M," the usual stamp that we place on goodsâ€”after I have entered and stamped them, they are passed over the counter for some of the hands to sewâ€”each of the workpeople has a book in which I enter the goods given to them to work up in the work-roomâ€”this is one of the booksâ€”after they are stitched up they are brought back to me, and are then given back to be tackedâ€”they are then brought to me again, and are again given to another person to stitch again; they are then button
holed, and sent to the laundress to be dressedâ€”I do not find in my book any entry of the receipt of these collars back again after I first gave them outâ€”I did not have them againâ€”this gross has never been finishedâ€”some of the collars produced are Paragon collarsâ€”they also belong to Messrs. Welch and Margetsonâ€”none of these are finished goods a; they areâ€”not in a state to be sold in our establishment.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. I believe you knew nothing of your loss until a few weeks ago? A. We missed the goods in December; that would be about two monthsâ€”after the entry I have spoken ofâ€”we manufac
ture hundreds of thousands of collars in the course of a year, and employ
very many handsâ€”the 275 is a pencil mark on the collar; it is not on each collarâ€”perhaps I should mark five or six in a gross; each gross has a separate number.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Did you take stock in December last? A. Yes; about the middle of December, and we then missed themâ€”we never sell any in this unfinished state.

GEORGE FELTON . I am in the employment of Messrs. Welch and Marget
sonâ€”I remember some collars being missed at the end of last year, No. 275â€”I am manager of the room that Mrs. Bywater speaks ofâ€”I look over the entries she makesâ€”these collars are not finishedâ€”they are never sold in this stateâ€”they have to go through four more operations; they are useless to anybody in this stateâ€”there are no button-holes to them.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe you went to the prisoner in consequence of some information that was given to you? A. I didâ€”I received that in
formation on 17th October, from Ann Vass, and went to the prisoner the same day; he was not at home thenâ€”I called again in about three hours and a half and saw himâ€”I did not ask him whether he had any collars in his possession; I told him he had themâ€”he said, "Yes," and immediately showed these collars to meâ€”he said he had bought them some time previouslyâ€”when I first called I saw his wifeâ€”I told her I came from Welch and Mar
getson's, about some collars, and she told me they were not on the premises.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Did the prisoner say how long back it was that he had bought them? A. About nine or ten months from that timeâ€”I asked him of whom he had bought themâ€”he said he did not know; it was a tall, thin womanâ€”I asked what he gave for themâ€”he said a shilling a dozenâ€”I told him that was not the value of themâ€”he said he did not know the value of themâ€”I told him they were stamped in indelible ink, and unfinished, and he should not have bought themâ€”he said he was a foreigner and could not read, and therefore could not understand our stamp upon themâ€”he keeps a leaving shop; that is an unlicensed pawnbroker'sâ€”he did not produce any book to show that he had bought themâ€”they are worth about 5s. per dozen in the state they are nowâ€”they would have been 7s. when finished.

ANN VASS . I am the wife of Charles Vass, a labourer, at 47, Bickleigh-street, Lambethâ€”I work as a needleâ€”womanâ€”I know the prisonerâ€”I went to his shop in the early part of October; it was the Sunday morning before I went before the Magistrateâ€”I went there for the purpose of leaving a parcel; the shop is termed a leaving shopâ€”he advances money upon thingsâ€”he puts a ticket on the parcel, but does not give any ticketâ€”while I was there a man came in to buy a collar; after he had left, the prisoner asked me if I was not a collar makerâ€”I said "Yes"â€”he said he had got a lot of collars that wanted finishing, would I take them and do them, and I said T would as I was slack of workâ€”he said it was not convenient to show them to me then, would I call againâ€”I did call on the Monday morningâ€”he said he had not got them readyâ€”I called on the Tuesday, and he then showed me the collars; there were five dozen and a half of one kind, two of another, and a dozen and a half of another; they were the same collars that were after
wards shown to me by the officerâ€”two dozen were entirely finished, and the rest were unfinishedâ€”he asked me what I would do them forâ€”I said I would do them for a shilling a dozenâ€”he said he could not afford that, they were not worth that to him, he wanted them to sell in the shopâ€”I told him they were worth 5s. 6d. a dozenâ€”he said if I liked to have them he would self them to me for what he gave for themâ€”I told him I did not want anyâ€”I was going out of the shop and he called me backâ€”I do sot remember what

he said, but I took up the collars and looked at them a second time, and I saw Mr. Welch's mark on themâ€”I looked at a dozen separately, and saw they were all markedâ€”I asked him who he bought them of, and he said of a tall, thin womanâ€”I said, "Do you know they are stolen collars; that Mr. Welch's mark is on them"â€”he did not make any answerâ€”I told him they belonged to the firm I worked for, and I would not have anything to do with themâ€”it was before I found out the mark that he offered them to me at a shilling a dozenâ€”I went directly to the firm, and told them.

ALAXANDER MCLEOD (Policeman, A 457). I accompained Mr. Felton to the prisoner's house on 17th Octoberâ€”eight dozen collars altogether were produced to usâ€”none that I saw were finishedâ€”I took him into custody, I searched, but found no book in which things were enteredâ€”the inspector asked him at the station if he could read or write, he said "Yes"â€”I had asked him at the shop how he took the collars in with a stamp on them, and he said he was a foreigner and could not read or write.

Cross-examined. Q. He is a foreigner, is he not? A. I am not aware of it, except from what he statedâ€”when he was discharged on his own recog
nisances by the Magistrate, I saw that he made a mark for his name.

The prisoner received a good character.â€”
NOT GUILTY .

151.
JOSEPH BARBER (32)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

HENRY HIGGINS . I belong to the King of Prussia public-house, Fair-street, Horseleydownâ€”on 28th November last, the prisoner came to our house for a pint of porter, and tendered me a shilling, which I put in the tillâ€”there was no of her shilling thereâ€”I gave him two fourpenny-pieces and twopence changeâ€”I then had occasion to go to the till to serve another customer, and found the shilling was badâ€”the prisoner had then goneâ€”in consequence of the way he drank the beer and left the house, I thought he knew it was bad and I followed him, and gave him into custodyâ€”he was about twenty yards off when I caught him in conversation with a womanâ€”I gave the shilling to a constable.

Prisoner. Q. Do you recollect that you went and sat down in your inner room and played at dominoes? A. No; you were very quickly goneâ€”you were not out three minutes before I took you in custodyâ€”I have had a great deal of bad money offered meâ€”I know your face wellâ€”you have not offered me any to my knowledgeâ€”I can swear you were in my house beforeâ€”I cannot say how many times, it might be half a dozenâ€”I think I have seen you at other places also.

WILLIAM VICKHAM (Policeman, M 202). On 28th November last, the last witness gave the prisoner into my custody, and, at the same time, gave me a counterfeit shillingâ€”I searched the prisoner and found two sixpences, two fourpennyâ€”pieces, and twopence farthing, good money.

ROSA HAYWARD . I live with my father at the Five Bells public-house, Bermondsey-squareâ€”on 14th November last, the prisoner came to our house for a glass of stout and a biscuitâ€”I served him, and he gave me a two shilling pieceâ€”I tried it between my teeth, and thought it was a bad oneâ€”I gave it to my sister, and she gave it to my fatherâ€”he told the prisoner it was a bad one, and sent for a constable and gave him in charge.
Prisoner. Q. When you gave the two shilling piece to your sister, did not she take it up stairs? A. Yesâ€”I was in the bar.

ROBERT HAYWARD . I am the proprietor of the Five Bella public-houseâ€”on 14th November last, I received a bad florin from my daughter, up stairs, she came up with itâ€”in oonsequence of that I went down into the bar, and found the prisoner there, and told him it was a bad oneâ€”he put his hand in his pocket, and pulled out some farthings, and he was so confused be could not count them, and at last be apologised very much for paying me in farthings I questioned him, and asked him where he got it from he said first he got it fromâ€”his sister, and then he said his sister gave it himâ€”I then said to my man, "Go with him, and see for his sister "he went out, but could not get any satisfactory answers the prisoner was brought back and given into custody my youngest daughter gave the two shilling piece to the constable in my presence.

JAMIS HOLDING (Policeman, M 199). I took the prisoner into custody at the Five Bells, and received this florin (produced)â€”I searched the prisoner, and found a halfpenny upon himâ€”subsequently to that he was brought before the Magistrate, remanded, and discharged.
Prisoner. Q. When you went to Mrs. Hawkins, did she admit she had given me a two shilling piece? A. She did two days afterwards, not at the time.
COURT. Q. Who is this Mrs. Hawkins? A. His sister-in-lawâ€”I went down with Mr. Hayward's boy to Mrs. Hawkins the same nightâ€”it was not on that occasion she admitted it; it was afterwards.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This florin and shilling are both bad.
Prisoner's Defence. They have had every facility offered them of finding out that I had a bad character, and was dealing with bad money, which I never have in my life.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

152.
MARY ANN TIZZARD (17),
CHARLES HENRY CRAWFORD (25), and
SARAH CRAWFORD (27)
, were indicted for a like offence.

MARIA. THORNE . I am the wife of William Thorne, of 1, Bond-street, Vauxhall, Lambeth, corn-dealer, and chandlerâ€”on Wednesday, 27th November, between 1 and 2, Sarah Crawford came to my shop and asked me for an egg, which came to five farthingâ€”she gave me a fourpenny piece, and I gave her 2 3/4 d. change I saw it was bad directly she went out of the shop I went outside, but could not see herâ€”I had not put it into any till, or rais it with any other money I put it away by itselâ€”the next evening, about 8 o'clock, Mary Ann Tiazard came in and asked for a half-penny worth of oatmeal, and gave me a fourpenny piece exactly like the one I had taken the day beforeâ€”it was badâ€”I told my husband and he gave her in charge I gave the foorpenny pieces to policeconstable Lansdale.

Tizzard. Q. When you found it was bad, I said I did not know it was bad, and you said, "Oh! yes, you must have known it was bad? A. No; I sent and called my husband directlyâ€”I did not hear you say so I told my husband you were very much like the person that came in the day beforeyou would not speakâ€”I knew you were not the same.

HENRY LANSDALE (Policeman, V 325). On 28th November last, between 8 and 9 o'clock, I took Tizzard in charge at Mrs. Thome's shop, and received these two fourpenny pieces (produced)â€”I took her to the stationâ€”1s. 9d. in silver and 4d. in copper, good money, was found on herâ€”the sergeant read the charge over to her, and she said, "I know it was bad, I received it from my brother-in-law, who is a soldier of the "12th foot; he is

in the babit of making them, and we all live together at 16, New-street, Walworth, and he and my sister were outside waiting at the time I went into the shop; and if you go to 16, Newâ€”street, where we all live, in a cupboard there you will find a spoon used for the purpose for melting metal, and also some other fourpenny pieces wrapped up in some paper"â€”in consequence of that information, I went to 16, New-street, in company with sergeant Heathâ€”after gaining admittance at the rear of the house, about half an hour after midnight, we proceeded up stairs to the back roomâ€”the door was. lockedâ€”the two Crawfords were no doubt in bedâ€”the sergeant knocked at the door and the male prisoner answered him and came and opened the doorâ€”the two Crawfords were in the roomâ€”we told them they were charged with knowingly passing counterfeit coinâ€”both of them said, "We know nothing of it"â€”we then searched the place, and in a cupboard by the fire
side in the same room, Sergeant Heath found a spoon, some plaster of Paris, two pieces of white metal, and a piece of chalkâ€”the sergeant has the spoonâ€”the male prisoner said he did not know that they were thereâ€”they were undressedâ€”the woman was sitting up in bed, he was only in his shirt.

Charles Crawford. Q. How could you come up and find me in bed if I let you in? A. There is no doubt you were in bed, by the way you answeredâ€”I believe the sergeant has some packages of sweet stuff that were found in your possession.

THOMAS HEATH (Policeâ€”sergeant, V 40). I went, in company with the last witness, to New-street, Walworth, and found the two prisoners thereâ€”there were no other persons in the houseâ€”I found this spoon in a cupboard by the side of the bed, and also two pieces of white metal, some plaster of Paris, and a piece of chalk (produced)â€”I asked the prisoners how they accounted for their being there, and they said they did not know anything of them; they must have been left in the house by other peopleâ€”I also found several small packages of sweet stuff, worth about a halfpenny each, and some apples, and things of that kind.
Sarah Crawford. Those sweets were for the child.

WILLIAM WEBSTER . These are two counterfeit fourpenny-pieces, and from one mould; there is a feint impress of part of a mould on this bit of plasterâ€”a spoon is a very common thing to use in making fourpenny-pieces, so as they can make a few at a timeâ€”there are some gets which are gets of a fourpenny-pieceâ€”these are not electro-plated in the ordinary wayâ€”they are just turned out of the mouldâ€”this piece of chalk is part of the mould, and the white metal is the same metal as the fourpenny-pieces are made of.
Tizzards's Defence. I found the spoon in the house; some people left it there, and I thought it would be useful, and took it up into my sister's room.
THE COURT considered that there was no evidence against Charles Crawford,
NOT GUILTY .

TIZZARD.â€”
GUILTY .*â€”
Confined Nine Months.

153.
JEREMIAH MCCARTHY (22), alias,
CORNELIUS DRISCOLL
was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

ANN ABBOTT . I am the wife of Thomas Abbott, of 58, Blackfriars-road, a licensed dealer in wineâ€”on Monday evening, 25th November last, about 9 o'clock, the prisoner, and a man named Quebeck, came into my shop togetherâ€”the prisoner asked for a pint of half-and-half, which came to 3d.â€”Quebeck

gave a half-a-crown, which I supposed to be goodâ€”I gave him 2s. 3d., changeâ€”I said "Would you like to sit down? we have a room at the back of our premises"â€”there were a great many persons at the barâ€”they said, "No; we have no time now, we are on business; business first, and pleasure after
wards"â€”both spokeâ€”Quebeck said, "Another time," and the prisoner said he was on businessâ€”they drank the half-and-half out of the same pot, and then leftâ€”I put the half-crown in the tillâ€”my suspicion was aroused, when they had left, and I looked into the till immediately they had goneâ€”there was no other half-crown thereâ€”I discovered this one to be counterfeit directly, and threw it into the fireâ€”it melted at onceâ€”by the advice of the policeman I found the remains of it in the ashes, put them in a piece of paper, and ultimately gave them to the policemanâ€”the same evening, about 10 o'clock, or it might be ten minutes after, the prisoner came in again alone and asked for a glass of our best old aleâ€”I. recognized him directlyâ€”he tendered me a shillingâ€”the ale was 2d.â€”I put the shilling in the detector and broke it ia three piecesâ€”he asked me for itâ€”I said, "No; I will keep this one; you can take these two pieces"â€”I said, "You are aware of what you have given me; you are aware it is a bad one?" and it was then that he asked me to let him lookâ€”I told him I was not at all disappointed; I quite expected him back; and told him it was not the first time he was there that eveningâ€”I said, "You and your friend managed to pass me a bad half-crown; you were here about three quarters of an hour ago"â€”he said he had no friend, and had never been in the house beforeâ€”I said, "I knew you the moment you came in; I quite expected what you were going to give me"â€”he put me down a shilling for the bad one that he had given meâ€”just then Quebeck came in and asked for half a pint of porterâ€”I served him, and waited to see what money be would give meâ€”he gave me a shillingâ€”I said to him, "Well, the last time you were in here this evening you managed to pass a bad half-crown on me, and now your friend has brought me a bad shilling"â€”that was spoken so that the prisoner could hear itâ€”I accused them togetherâ€”I put my hand on themâ€”he said he was no friend of hisâ€”they denied all knowledge of each other, and said they never saw each other beforeâ€”the prisoner wanted to leave, and a friend of ours detained him at the bar, and four other young men, strangers to me, kept the other one, and I immediately gave them into custodyâ€”I gave the policeman the bad pieces of the shilling, and the pieces of metal that I had picked up.
Prixmer. Q. When I gave you the shilling, did not you say, "You have been here before and passed me a bad half-crown?" A I accused you directly of the bad half-crownâ€”I said, "Your friend and you."

EMMA EKSTEDT . I am the wife of Thomas Ekstedt, who acts as pianist at this house in the Blackfriars-roadâ€”I was there on 25th November, and saw the prisoner there about 9 o'clock that evening, in company with a short dark man, named Quebeck, whom I have seen sinceâ€”they had a pint of half-and-halfâ€”I did not see it paid forâ€”about an hour, or an hour aid ten minutes afterwards, the prisoner came inâ€”he then appeared very tipsyâ€”he called for something to drink, I do not know whatâ€”Mrs. Abbott said, "I expected you back again," and in the meantime the dark one came inâ€”I am certain they were the same two men whom I saw drinking together about an hour before.

Prisoner. Q. When I gave Mrs. Abbott the money, what did she say to me? A. She said, "I fully expected you backâ€”when you and your friend were here before, you tendered me a bad halfâ€”crown, and now you have tendered a bad shilling, for which I shall lock you up"â€”I did not say that she said you passed the bad half-crown.

(The Witness deposition being read, stated: "I heard Mrs. Abbott say, 'I expected you again, for the last time you were here, you passed a bad half-crown on me, and now you have given a bad shilling.") Witness. They were both together thenâ€”Mrs. Abbott said, "You and your friend passed it"â€”I alluded to two parties when I said, "You"â€”I was at the end of the bar at the time, not behind itâ€”I had been there since half-past 7 in the eveningâ€”I go there every evening, as my husband plays the piano thereâ€”the second time you came in by yourself, and appeared very much intoxicatedâ€”your friend came in about five minutes afterwards.
JURY. Q. Are you sure that the two, when they first came in together, drank out of the same pot? A. Yes, I am certain they did.

SAMUEL BROOKING (Policeman, M 221). I received charge of the prisoners from Mrs. Abbott on 25th November, about a quarter past 10â€”she handed me a part of a bad shilling, and some melted metalâ€”Mrs. Abbott said to the prisoner, "You have passed me a bad shilling now, and you and your friend gave me a bad halfâ€”crown when you were here before"â€”he said he had got no friendâ€”I took them both in custody.
Prisoner. Q. When was it that Mrs. Abbott gave you the metal? A. Next morningâ€”I did not say it was when you were given in custody.

COURT. Q. When did you receive the bad shilling? A. That eveningâ€”I received the melted metal next morning when I went thereâ€”I searched him and found on him a sixpence and fourpence in halfpenceâ€”a shilling and a halfpenny were found on Quebeck.
Prisoner. That was the change I had from the good shilling which I paid with afterwards.

WILLIAM WEBSTER . This is part of a bad shilling, and this is some melted metal which has passed through the fireâ€”it is the same kind of metal as we find coins made of, and judging by its weight, and what it would lose in passing through the fire, I should say it was just the weight used for a half-crownâ€”I have had great experience in coins for many yearsâ€”a good half-crown would not melt if thrown into the fireâ€”some of this would adhere to the cindersâ€”there is too much metal here for a shilling.

Prisoner's Defence. I was the worse for liquor; I went to the theatre. I had a half-crown, and in the burry and excitement of getting in, I did not think of looking at my two shillings change. As I was going home, I went into this woman's house and called for the ale; I gave her the shilling, and she said it was bad. I begged her pardon, and said I did not know it was bad; she gave me the two pieces of a shilling back. I said, "They are no use to me," and laid them on the counter. She sent for a constable and I said I did not know it was bad; she said I must tell the Magistrate that.
GUILTY .

p.hi: He was further charged with having been before convicted.

div1.p: EDMUND COSTELLO (Policeman, V 160). I produce a certificate which I got from the clerk of the Court here (Read: Central Criminal Court, February 25, 1861. Jeremiah Me Carthy and William Fellows were convicted of unlawfully uttering counterfeit coinâ€” Confined Nine Months Each)â€”I was a witness in that caseâ€”I had Mc Carthy in custodyâ€”he is the person who was then tried and convicted.

GUILTY.**â€”
Four Tears' Penal Servitude.

154.
WILLIAM BARNES (21)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Jewel D'Ahemar, and stealing 1 frock and other goods, his property.

JAMES PARKER (Policeman, 126). On Monday, 23d September, I was on duty, and saw a light in the lumber-room of Mr. D'Ahemar's house, over the wallâ€”I went in, and saw Williams, who was convicted here in the October Ses
sionsâ€”(See Vol. LIV. p. 771)â€”I went to the back of the garden, and saw a light burning, which appeared to be a light from a dark lanthorn, as the light occa
sionally shone across Williams' faceâ€”he was apprehended at the timeâ€”I con
sidered that there was more than one, but I did not see more than one at a timeâ€”as I was at a distance from them I found it would be difficult for me to get close to themâ€”I went and got the assistance of two other constables, one of whom I placed at the front of the houseâ€”I and Clarke got over at the backâ€”I assisted Clarke over the wall, and then got over after himâ€”as soon as he had got into the garden he said, "Look out, here they are"â€”I heard a rush of footsteps from the back of Mr. D'Ahemar's houseâ€”he said, "He's gone over the wall; I can't hold him"â€”I followed over the wall as well as I could, and I could see the shadow of some one running awayâ€”I found no one, and then I came back to Clarke, and found-Williams in his custodyâ€”I aroused the inmates, and examined the houseâ€”I found that an entry had been made in the back of the house, in a room termed a lumber-roomâ€”I found the iron bar had been torn out of the socket by forcing the bar of the windowâ€”the entrance was large enough for a man to go throughâ€”I found that a cupboard had been bored through with a centre-bit, and the room was all in disorderâ€”there had been a light in the room, and there was a bedgown on the fireâ€”I found a child's dress in a watercloset outside, and a number of things strewn about, a child's shirt, and a workbox.
Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON (with MR. BESLEY). Q. Was it raining? A. Yes, heavilyâ€”it was a very dark night, with clouds breaking.

MR. HORRY. Q. If the clouds had been away, was there a moon? A. Yesâ€”they were shifting cloudsâ€”there would be a very heavy fall of rain for two or three minutes, and then a shift of the clouds, which would give a very good lightâ€”there was a break of the clouds at the time I was on the garden wall.

JAMES CLARKE (Policeman, V 103). On the morning of Monday, 23d Sep
tember, about 3 o'clock, I got over the wall of 9, Dorset-terrace, with Parkerâ€”I saw two men come from the watercloset of that gardenâ€”they ran and got over the wallâ€”I saw one over the wall, and the other was half overâ€”I went up, and laid my hand on his legâ€”he then turned his face to me, and struck at me with something he had in his handâ€”I had a pretty good sight of his faceâ€”I withdrew from him when he struck me, and when he turned back he made a sudden spring into the gardenâ€”I had a distinct view of his faceâ€”the moon was then shining very brightlyâ€”I could not swear what was in his handâ€”I have since found a knife there, near where we were strugglingâ€”I had seen Barnes-several times before that night.

Cross-examined. Q. You knew his name, I suppose? A. No, I did notâ€”it had been raining very hard, and was then, but not so hardâ€”the moon came out from the clouds just at the momentâ€”I saw the other man just coming out of the window, the one that I took in custodyâ€”the other one made his escape over the wall just as I was coming over the wallâ€”when I had hold of that man's foot the other one was coming out at the windowâ€”I had not then apprehended himâ€”I took him into custody after the transactino at the wallâ€”I saw him come out while I was at the wallâ€”I was three or four yards from himâ€”I heard a rustling noiseâ€”I had my eye on himâ€”I should like to nave apprehended the one on the wallâ€”this passed in a very short time, five or six minutesâ€”it was raining, and continued so when the clouds went away.

COURT. Q. You do not mean to say it took five or six minutes from the time you rushed across and took Williams? A. Well, I daresay it was not so long as that; a short timeâ€”I had hold of the leg of the man that got away, for about a minute, as much as a minuteâ€”I had a good deal of struggling with himâ€”his face was towards the country, to escape, except at the moment he turned round to strike me.

ELIZABETH DOYLE . I am in the service of Mr. D'Ahemar, of 9, Dorset
terrace, Clapham-roadâ€”I was called up on the morning of 23d September, about half-past 3â€”I came down with my master and found it all disorderly and knocked aboutâ€”the things were taken out of the store room into the garden, and a pane of glass was cut out of the store-room window, which was broken openâ€”I always secure that, and had done so the night beforeâ€”I am quite sure that all was fastenedâ€”we go to bed about 11 o'clock, and did so on that night.

ELIZA INNIFER . I live at 1, Porter-street, Newport-market, and am the wife of Thomas Innifer, a farm labourerâ€”on the Thursday night before 23d September, I saw Barnes with my son, at about half-past 10 or a quarter to 11, or perhaps just on 11; I cannot exactly sayâ€”my son is Thomas Inniferâ€”he was convicted of burglary in the house of Mr. D'Ahemar, and had three yearsâ€”I saw him speaking to my son in More-street, Five-dials, opposite the public-houseâ€”it is about five minutes walk from my houseâ€”I went to look for my son and took him away.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose you had seen your son speaking to a great many other people in the Dials on a great many other occasion? A. Yes; but not to that to young man beforeâ€”I had never seen the prisoner before thatâ€”I tried to get my son home.

COURT. Q. Did you hear of your son being taken into custody? A. Yes; on the Monday the police fetched meâ€”I went to the Magistrate at Wands
worth and gave evidenceâ€”Barnes was put into the room with another and I picked him out.

WILLIAM BLACKBURN (Policeman, V 251). On Saturday, 2d November, I apprehended the prisoner at Beckwith's, the champion swimmer, Lucretia-street, New-cut, Lambethâ€”I said, "Barney, I want you for a burglary in the Clapham-road"â€”he said, "Is that all?"â€”I said, "Yes, at present I believe" I think he said, "I don't care much about that"â€”I can hardly recollectâ€”I think those were his wordsâ€”I said, "You must go with me to the station"â€”he said, "All right; you will have to give me a cab for it"â€”I said, "Right, I will"â€”the prosecutor's house is in St Mary's parish, Lambethâ€”it is in the Clapham-road.

MARY PINGRIM . I am a widow, and live at 34, Seacoal-laneâ€”I have two daughtersâ€”the prisoner has lodged at my house about three monthsâ€”I have known him from Julyâ€”I recollect Sunday, 22d September, his father came to our house to breakfast with himâ€”he went to a running match, and dined and had tea with us, and went out with my daughters and Elizabeth and Harry Raw about 7â€”about 10 o'clock my daughters came home without him, and in consequence of something I went up the street with my daughter Rosetta, to Johanna-street, at the comer of the New Cut, and fetched him home to my house to supper, and between 11 and 12 he went to bedâ€”I slept in the front room and he in the backâ€”I got up about 7, knocked at the prisoner's door, and told him to get up as it was breakfast timeâ€”he said that he was getting upâ€”I then went over to Paddington to workâ€”I was not there when they had breakfastâ€”on the Thursday before this Sunday, Rosetta and

I had been washing all day, and when the prisoner came in we had just finished, and I was drying some clothes before the fireâ€”I asked him if he would have some supperâ€”he said, "Yes," and I fetched a pint o! beer, and he went to bed between 11 and 12.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Are you a lodger in the house? A. Yea; there is a landlodyâ€”there were no lodgers in the house but the prisoner and meâ€”the landlady, Mrs. Stephens and her husband, slept on one side, and me and my daughter on the other side, and the prisoner in a little back room; that is where we were when it occurred in the New Cutâ€”I am now living in Seacoal-lane, and lived there when I gave evidence before the Magistrate; that was in November, I suppose, but I cannot sayâ€”Barnes was very likely apprehended at the beginning of November, but I cannot say the day of the monthâ€”it was Monday morning, and on the following Thursday they went to the police-courtâ€”I did not take notice whether it was November or notâ€”the prisoner lodged in our house in Seacoal-lane at the time he was taken; but on 22d September, we were at Short-street, New-cutâ€”we removed from there to Seacoal-lane, on the Wednesday after 22d Septemberâ€”the prisoner lodged with us at both placesâ€”we were at Seacoal-lane when the depositions were takenâ€”I gave evidence, and I believe a gentleman took it downâ€”(The deposition being read, stated: "The prisoner lodged at my house in Seacoal-lane about three months")â€”He lodged with us three months, partly in Seacoal-lane, and partly in the New-outâ€”we removed with us from the Newâ€”out to Seacoal-lane on the Wednesday after 22d Septemberâ€”I never saw him before he came to lodge with usâ€”Elizabeth, my eldest daughter, who is an acquaintance of his, brought him to our houseâ€”she introduced him to me to wash some shirts for himâ€”I did not enquire into his character, but his father cameâ€”he was courting my daughter, and they were' asked in church about a month or six weeks after I knew himâ€”I had to pay for the askingâ€”I went with themâ€”I was going to let my daughter marry him, I never saw anything wrong against the young manâ€”my daughter introduced him to lodge at my house; he said that he wanted a lodgingâ€”that was three or four times after I had seen himâ€”his father came to us in Short-street, and paid for his lodging, saying, that he should not want anything as long as he had got a hand to workâ€”the prisoner did nothing; his father supported him, and was going to put him into a baker's business as soon as he couldâ€”I knew where his father livedâ€”I do not know why he did not live with this kind father; that did not concern meâ€”I recollect Sunday, 2d Septemberâ€”Barnes was with us all dayâ€”he left about 6, and returned at 10â€”my daughters were both with him, and a young man named Raw, who lives in Tower-street, and works in the Cityâ€”he is not hereâ€”he was not before the Magistrateâ€”I did not go to the Spanish Patriots at all; I do not drink anything, and do not frequent public-houses, nor does my daughter, she does not care for drink any more than I doâ€”I mean to say that I did not fetch the prisoner from the Spanish Patriotsâ€”I met him outside the doorâ€”a person named Hillier was not thereâ€”I know nobody of that nameâ€”the prisoner was with us up to the time he was taken; but he was not taken at our houseâ€”I did not miss him for any nights from Seacoal-laneâ€”he never was away all nightâ€”he was safe at home and in bed every night, and he was no more out that night than I wasâ€”I do not know that he fre
quented any of the houses in the Cut, and I know he is as innocent of what he is charged with as I am hereâ€”it might be a little more or a little less than 10 o'clock when I brought him home, but it was 10 when we went

into the roomâ€”I got up about 7 in the morning, and lit the fireâ€”some one slept with him in his roomâ€”we used to lock the street door, and bolt itâ€”the landlady did it if she was up late; and if I was up last I did itâ€”the prisoner was never out late; if he had been he must have knocked us up, as there is only one large key to the doorâ€”I never saw a girl named Hillier, but onceâ€”she did not come to my house and threaten and annoy the pri
soner; but they have met her out.

MR. BESLEY. Q. Did you leave Short-street before quarter-day? A. On the Wednesday after the 22dâ€”I do not know when quarter-day is; but our landlady left, and that was the reason we moved to Seacoal-laneâ€”the prisoner's father told me that, if his son got settled, he would put him into a baker's business, and he could make ginger beer, and get a very good livingâ€”the father came three or four times a week to where his son was lodgingâ€”although it is a mistake to say that the prisoner lodged with me three months in Seacoal-lane; he lodged with me three months, partly in Short-street, and partly in Seacoal-lane.

COURT. Q. Do you know when the prisoner was taken up? A. Yes; it was on a Saturday eveningâ€”I cannot say when, because I did not pay particular attentionâ€”I had no reason before he was taken up, for trying to remember what became of him on Sunday, 22d September; but I recollect that was the day, because his father came that day, and because they went to a running matchâ€”I know the running match was on the 22d., because I recollect it sowellâ€”I had no reason for trying to recollect the day till after he was taken up; but his father came on that day, and we were talking things over, or else I should not have remembered itâ€”I know it was not on the 15thâ€”he and my daughter went out together, and they got into a row at the Bell, in Mason-street.

JAMES JOHN BARNES . I am the prisoner's father, and live at 4, Wandsworth-road, Vauxhallâ€”I am a bootmaker, and also carry on the baking businessâ€”I have lived there twelve months this Christmas, and eleven years in the neigh
bourhoodâ€”on Sunday, 22d September, I went to Mrs. Pingrim's with my sonâ€”that was the first time I had been thereâ€”I met my son at 7 o'clock that morning, and went home to breakfast with himâ€”I do not know how long he had been out when I met himâ€”I was out for a walkâ€”stopped there about an hourâ€”he complained of having a sore foot, his corn troubled himâ€”during the day, I went down the lane with him, and bought a pair of boots, and a pair of shoesâ€”I did not go anywhere else with himâ€”I left him at home when I went outâ€”I was out about an hour and a halfâ€”I dined with him, and stayed there and had teaâ€”I left at a little after 6 in the eveningâ€”Elizabeth and Rosetta Pingrim and Henry Raw went with meâ€”I went as far as the Victoria theatre with my sonâ€”bade him good night and left him at a quarter or twenty minutes after 6â€”that was all I saw of himâ€”I do not know how long he had been living at Mrs. Pingrim'sâ€”that was the first time I had seen herâ€”I knew that he was living somewhere about the Cut, but did not know whereâ€”I told Mrs. Pingrim, whatever she got for him I would pay for, but not before thatâ€”I knew that he was keeping company with her daughterâ€”he brought her to my place a fortnight beforeâ€”I told Mrs. Pingrim that I would put him into business.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you go to any running match? A. No; but that was the cause of my meeting my son over on the other side of the waterâ€”my son's age is about twenty-fiveâ€”he told me that he was going to get marriedâ€”I did not ask him anything about the girl's parentsâ€”that was the cause I went down to breakfast with him to see the familyâ€”I was sup
porting

him, and had done so for three or four monthsâ€”I always have supported himâ€”when he has wanted anything he has come to me, and I have given it to himâ€”he is no particular businessâ€”he has been working at envelope stampingâ€”how do I know what he was doing six months before thisâ€”the baking business is the selling of breadâ€”I retail bread; I do not bakeâ€”somebody else makes itâ€”I am a bootmakerâ€”I was going to give up the bread selling business to himâ€”have paid for his board and lodging while be has been at Mrs. Pingrim'sâ€”I have a family besides himâ€”I have nine altogether; six are at homeâ€”the prisoner is not the eldest.

COURT. Q. How do you know that it was 22d September? A. By making a pair of boots for himâ€”on Thursday, the 19th, I went to get the leather, and he came for the boots on the Fridayâ€”I had them finished for himâ€”that was not the Sunday after I made the bootsâ€”I did not then know where he was lodgingâ€”he told me that he was going to a running match when he called for the bootsâ€”I could prove that it was the 19th that I had bought the leather, by the person where I bought itâ€”the policeman who took the boots off my son's feet came to me and asked me to send him a pair of bootsâ€”I said, "My son has got one pair which I made," and I described them.

COURT. Q. You said that you made them for him, and yet you say you can call the man you bought them of? A. No; those were two pair of girl's boots, but I bought the tops of his boots and made the bottomsâ€”I know that it was on the 19th by looking at the almanackâ€”I went back and saw that the day I bought them was Thursday, 19th September, and it w as the 22d that 1 saw him; Sunday morningâ€”I did not know what my son was charged with until I went to Wands worth.

MR. RIETON. Q. Have you worked for Price's factory? A. For most of the people in the factoryâ€”the evidence was taken down by an attorney before I went before the Magistrateâ€”after my attention was called to the day, I looked at the almanack and found that it was on the 19th I supplied him with boots, and on the Sunday following I had breakfast with him.
MR. HORRY. Q. From whom did you hear that your son was in custody? A. From the policeman.

ELIZABETH PINGRIM . I am the daughter of Mrs. Pingrimâ€”I have known the prisoner some timeâ€”I am engaged to be married to him on Sunday evening, 22d Septemberâ€”I went out with himâ€”I know it was the 22d., by his father being there, and his two sisters came there to teaâ€”I went with them to the Sun public-house, Westminster-road, to hear the bellsâ€”we stayed there about two hoursâ€”I then went home to my mother's with my sister and another young woman, leaving the prisoner there, between 9 and 10 o'clockâ€”about 11 o'clock the prisoner came hack with my mother to our houseâ€”we had returned home without the prisoner because there was a rowâ€”I went home and said, "There is a row in the Sun, will you go and see that he does not get into trouble?" and they went with this young woman, and brought him hack about 11â€”I went to bed at a little past 11, and the prisoner went into the next room to bedâ€”my mother pulled off his boots and threw them under the table, and next morning my mother called himâ€”she said, "Bill, your breakfast is ready"â€”and I heard him answer, "All right"

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known him? A Five months up to the present timeâ€”I first saw him in the Cut in the street, he was a stranger to me up to that timeâ€”I cannot tell you how soon after that I took him home to my mother'sâ€”he was not long in my company the first

night I met him, because I was in service, and was obliged to go to my placeâ€”he did not see me homeâ€”I with him for about an hourâ€”it was weeks after that that I took him to my mother'sâ€”he has only been living there three monthsâ€”I do not know how soon marriage was proposedâ€”I heard of the banns being put up, that was about a month or six weeks after we first met, as near as I can guessâ€”he told me that he could not lodge at home, and asked me if I knew a respectable lodgingâ€”I said, "My mother is taking in respectable lodgers"â€”I will not answer whether I asked him anything about his family, or why he could not lodge at home; why should I be cross questioned when I have come here to speak the truth?

COURT. Q. Do you object to say whether you asked him who his family were? A. I did not ask himâ€”he took me to his father's, and I saw his two youngest sisters, but not his father or his motherâ€”I never saw his father or mother until the father came to my mother's house on the 22d.

MR. HORRY. Q. How soon after you met him was that? A. I cannot tell you, I have not studied into these thingsâ€”I had never been at this public-house beforeâ€”we went there for amusementâ€”there are bells there on Sunday eveningâ€”my sister, and a young man named Harry Raw, and his father and two sisters; we all left my mother's at 6 o'clockâ€”I heard on the Saturday evening that the prisoner was in custodyâ€”I had to meet him at a quarter before 10 that eveningâ€”I heard it from the gentleman at the "Good Intent" public-house, in Lucretia-streetâ€”I do not know the person who brought the news, we went to meet him there, and the gentleman told me.
