MR. RIBTON. Q. Were you asked in church? A. Yes; and my mother told the policeman that it was at Old Lambeth churchâ€”it was about a month afterwards he took me to his father's houseâ€”I was in service at the time, at a gentleman's office, 5, Parliament-street, Westminster-road,â€”when he took me to his father's house he had spoken to me about marrying me three weeks beforeâ€”I did not ask to go to his father's, he offered to take me thereâ€”I only saw his two sistersâ€”I have been there since he was taken up, and seen his father and motherâ€”I am quite sure that the first time I ever saw his father was on Sunday, the 22dâ€”I saw the prisoner go to bed on that night.

COURT. Q. Did you see the father at your mother's house after the 22d? A. Yes; he came afterwards to see his son a great many timesâ€”he came to the lodgings in Short-street about three times before he leftâ€”I cannot tell you when we left Short-streetâ€”I am sure the father came there three times after the 22dâ€”I cannot remember any of the other daysâ€”I cannot remember whether he went to the lodgings in Short-street at all after thatâ€”he came to where we live now, but about the other I am not sureâ€”I fix the 22d and not the 15th, because he went to a running match, and my brother was there.
MR. RIBTON. Q. When he was apprehended I suppose you were spoken to? A. Yes; and went and gave evidence to a solicitor.

ROSETTA PINGRIM . I am the sister of the last witnessâ€”I recollect the Sunday when the prisoner and his father were at our houseâ€”it was the 22d of Septemberâ€”he was there the whole dayâ€”my sister, and I, and the prisoner, left home about 6 o'clock to go to a public-house to hear some bells rungâ€”while we were there, a quarrel took placeâ€”a woman who was there was jealous of my sisterâ€”my sister and I went home, and my mother and I went back to the public-house, and returned home with the prisonerâ€”we got home about 10, or it might be laterâ€”I remember the prisoner going to

bed; I was down stairs talking to a young man: I went back and he was in bedâ€”bed I am not going to be marriedâ€”I saw him next morning about 8 o'clock, when he came and bad his breakfastâ€”I fix the date on 22d because my brother was dining with us, and in the morning he went to a running matchâ€”the prisoner went to the match, and he and his father came home and breakfasted with usâ€”I cannot say how soon we left those lodgingsâ€”I think it is betwen three and four monthsâ€”this happened in Short-streetâ€”we remained there, I think, about three weeks afterwards, we then removed to 34, Seacoal-laneâ€”I cannot tell you exactly whether it was the next week that we leftâ€”I work at Mr. Bramin's, in Whitechapelâ€”I was at home on Sunday, 22dâ€”I had left service about three weeks beforeâ€”I am out of service nowâ€”I do not remember how soon after the 22d we leftâ€”that was the first time I had seen the prisoner's father, but he called at the house in Short-street two or three times afterwards.

Cross-examined. Q. Two or three times in the course of the week or fort
night? A. In the course of the time we were living there, and when we went to Stacoal-lane the prisoner went with us.
NOT GUILTY .

155.
GEORGE REID (35), and
CAROLINE DAVIS (19)
, Feloniously having in their possession a mould impressed with the obverse and reverse sides of a half-crown; to which

REID
PLEADED GUILTY .

JAMES BRANNAN . On 11th December, from information I received, I went about 1 o'clock in the day, to 21, Mint-street, Southwarkâ€”the street-door was openâ€”I proceeded upstairs to the second floor front room, and saw Davis coming out of the roomâ€”I stopped her on the landingâ€”she held in her leftâ€”hand a florin, in this cloth, rubbing it, I snatched them from her hand, and another florin dropped, I believe, from the clothâ€”she was then seized by Sergeant Elliottâ€”the florin was wet and partially covered with sand, and her hands were wet and covered with sandâ€”I went into the room and saw Reid in his shirt sleeves at a tableâ€”he slipped from it, and threw away a large quantity of counterfeit coin, florins, half-crowns, and sixpences, and went towards the windowâ€”I pushed him away from it, and he was seized by Sergeant Brannanâ€”a struggle ensued, and he was thrown on a bed in the room, and a large quantity of counterfeit coin fell from himâ€”I said, "Charcoal, your time has not expired, before you commence your mis
chievous practices again"â€”he said, "All right, Mr. Brannan, you don't know all"â€”I picked Hip fourteen florins, ten half-crowns, sixteen shillings, and, I think, thirteen sixpences, all of which I believe to be counterfeitâ€”I went towards a chair' which stood by the window, and found this galvanic battery in full work, with eight counterfeit shillings on the wire, as they now appear, undergoing the process of electro
platingâ€”there was a saucer on the table containing solution, which I believe to be cyanide of silver; several saucers containing sand and water, and a file with white metal in its teethâ€”in a cupboard was a small portion of plaster of Paris, in powderâ€”we proceeded downstairs, with Inspector More and several officers, searched the cellars and the back kitchen, and in the copper flue I found five plaster of Paris moulds; one treble one, for two shillings and a sixpence; one half-crown one; a double mould for shillings, one for florins, and a double mould for sixpencesâ€”I returned to the room, and placed them on the table before Reid, who said, "You cannot bring them home to me, Mr. Brannan; you cannot prove I put them there"â€”I said, "That will be a matter of inference after they are compared with the
coins "coins"â€”Mr. Webster has compared them in my presence, and they appear to have been made from those moulds.

JAMES BRANNAN , Junior (Police-sergeant, G 21). I accompanied the other officersâ€”Davis had a mug and some florins, and she dropped some from her pocket after she was securedâ€”her hands were wet with sand and water.

ARTHUR ELLIOTT (Police-sergeant, G 13). I went with the other officers to Mint-streetâ€”Davis was at the door when we went upâ€”I pushed her back, and as I was pushing her into the room she put her hand into her dress pocket and a quantity of counterfeit money fellâ€”I picked up eight florins, one half-crown, and four sixpences, which fell from her hand.

WILLIAM WEBSTER . The first of these moulds is a treble one, for making two shillings and a sixpence; but I find no bad money from thatâ€”the next is a double mould for two shillings, one of 1820, George the Thirdâ€”from that mould here are eleven counterfeit shillings, six from that of 1820, and five from that of 1845â€”the next is a mould for half-a-crown of George the Third, 1817â€”it contains the obverse and reverse sidesâ€”here are ten half-crowns cast from itâ€”the next is a mould for a florin of 1853â€”here are twelve counterfeit florins cast from itâ€”the next is a double mould for six-pences of 1839 and 1854â€”here are thirteen sixpences, seven from the 1854 mould, and six from that of 1839â€”here are two florins of 1853, which ware taken from Davisâ€”they are from the same mould as the other twelveâ€”Elliott produced four counterfeit sixpences which the woman droppedâ€”three of those are from the mould of 1834, and the others from that of 1859â€”he also produced eight florins; they are all counterfeit, and from the mould of 1853, the same as the twelve othersâ€”here is a half-crown, which has been struck in brass from a dieâ€”some of these came out a few years ago, but I have not seen any sinceâ€”here is a battery with some of the coins in it, which are undergoing the process of silvering, and here is everything necessary for coining.
Davis' Defence. I had no coins in my hand.

DAVISâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: stated that Reid had been in custody on a former occasion, and sentenced to six years' penal servitude.

div1.p:
REIDâ€”
Fifteen Years' Penal Servitude.

156.
JOHN QUEBECK (30), was indicted (with
JEREMIAH M'CARTHY ,)
(See page 222), for unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

ANN ABBOTT . My husband keeps a public-house in Blackfriars-roadâ€”the prisoner Quebeck is the man who came with M'Carthy on the night of 25th Novemberâ€”a pint of half-and-half was called forâ€”Quebeck gave me a half-crownâ€”I gave him the change, and put the money in the tillâ€”in consequence of something which was said to me, I took it out again and threw it on the fireâ€”it immediately melted through the barsâ€”I had invited the two prisoners to go and sit down in the concert-roomâ€”the prisoner said, "No, we are on business; some other night"â€”they drank the half-and-half and leftâ€”about half an hour afterwards, M'Carthy came in and gave his name at Driscollâ€”he had a glass of ale, and I said, "Your friend came in here about an hour since, and passed me a bad half-crown"â€”while I was talking Quebeck came in, called for half a pint of porter, and gave me a pennyâ€”I said, "The last time you were here this evening you managed to pass me a bad half-crown, and now your friend has come and passed a bad shilling"â€”
M'Carthy said, "I have not been in before, and I have no friend;" and Quebeck said, "He is no friend of mine; I never saw him before"â€”I gave them both in custody.

Quebeck. Q. Who called for the liquor when you took the half-crown? A. You were both togetherâ€”I sent our potman to look after you, and described your appearanceâ€”the half-crown dissolved in the fireâ€”I had cautioned my child to be very careful: I said, "I have taken a bad half-crown, be careful; your father must know nothing of it"â€”the other man gave me the shilling about three quarters of an hour afterwardsâ€”the only other person serving at the bar was my childâ€”I put the half-crown in the fire to avoid words with my husbandâ€”I do not know whether any coals were put onâ€”it was a parlour fire, an open grate with hobsâ€”I found the shilling out quickly, as I quite expected him to give me some moneyâ€”he had a good shilling ready after he dropped the bad shilling on the counterâ€”I produced a bit of metal, the next morning, which I suppose to be the pro
duce of the half-crown, as it melted immediately and ran downâ€”I did not see it run through on to the hearthâ€”my daughter was not there at the timeâ€”she is sixteen or seventeen years of age.

EMMA EKSTEDT . I was at this house on the evening of 25th Novemberâ€”the prisoner is the man I saw with McCarthy that eveningâ€”I swear to himâ€”he is the man who drank the half-and-half, and who was present during the discussion between the prisoner and Mrs. Abbott about the bad shilling.

Prisoner. Q. What time did we come in and give this half-crown? A. About quarter-past 9â€”I cannot say who gave the half-crown, I was four yards off and did not see it at allâ€”I noticed you in that crowd of people, because Mrs. Abbott asked you to walk in, and you said that you were on business, "business first and pleasure afterwards"â€”I recognised you in the dock on Wednesday morning, there can be no mistake about youâ€”I am marriedâ€”I was talking to Mrs. Abbottâ€”she was serving and was rather busy, as there were, perhaps, six or seven persons standing in front of the bar.

SAMUEL BOOKING (Policeman, M 221). I went to Mrs. Abbotts', and the prisoner and McCarthy were given in custody to my brother constableâ€”Mrs. Abbott gave me these broken pieces of a shilling, and on the following morning she gave me some pieces of melted metalâ€”I saw the prisoner searched, and 1s. 0 1/2 d. in copper found on himâ€”when I took him he was charged with having been there before that night, and he said, "I have not been in the house before, and I know nothing of the other man."

WILLIAM WESTER . This is the fragment of a bad shilling, and here is some molten metal, of precisely the same kind as the bad money is made of, and it is the same quantity as you would expect to find if a bad half-crown was thrown into a fire, allowing for what would adhere to the cinders and coalsâ€”it requires a very little time to melt these coins, but you cannot melt a silver coin.
Prisoner. With a little aquafortis upon it a common shilling would melt at once. Witness. Then it must be a very bad one, and there never was such a thing knownâ€”it is a great mistake.

Prisoner's Defence, A little bit of metal might have been in the coals or in a saucepan, or anything else. The woman says I was in her house at 9 o'clock, whereas I can produce a young man from Reading to prove I was in his company from 6 o'clock to 10 o'clock.

WILLIAM READY . I am a gas-lighter, employed by the Enfield Gas Com
pany, and live at 39, Little George street, Hampstead-roadâ€”I know Quebeckâ€”I saw him on Monday evening, 25th November, at the corner of Oakley-street, Lambeth, near the Victoria theatreâ€”it must have been about 6 o'clock, because I had done my lightingâ€”my sister lives at 10, Thomas-street, which leads into Oakley-streetâ€”she was not at home, and I met my brother-in-law, who is at work at the Exhibitionâ€”we went to a public-house, and met the prisoner thereâ€”I do not know the name of it, as I am a stranger thereâ€”we had several drops of drink togetherâ€”I left at 10, or half-past, and left him there with my brother-in-lawâ€”I must have left at 10, because I reached home at 11, when St James'-chapel was striking, and it took me an hour to walkâ€”the prisonerâ€”was there from 6 till the time I leftâ€”I do not remember his leaving my companyâ€”he may have done soâ€”I cannot swear that he did not, because he might have gone out while I was talking to my brother, but I do not remember his leavingâ€”I would swear he was there from 6 till half-past 9â€”I do not remember after 9, because I had several drops of drinkâ€”I got rather elevated at 9 o'clock; I might be deceived in the timeâ€”I will swear he remained with me three hours, from 6 to 9, because my brother-in-law said to me, "Margaret will be home now"â€”he said she could not see the secretary of the club she went to, before half-past 8, and I must have left at 10 to have reached home at 11â€”I recollect the prisoner being there till 9, because I asked my brother-in-law if I had a chance of seeing Margaret, who is my sister, and I said I would not waitâ€”I did not go thenâ€”we stopped and had a drop more drink, and I went on the following dayâ€”I will swear the prisoner was in my company from 6 to 9 without leavingâ€”he did not go away at 9, but I got a little drop of drink thenâ€”I will swear I left him there in company with my brother-in-law at 10o'clock.

Cross-examined by MR. CLERK. Q. How long have you borne the name of William Ready? A. Thirty yearsâ€”I have never gone by any otherâ€”I was in the army in my mother's maiden name, as William Longâ€”I left the army in 1856â€”I enlisted in that name because I was a married manâ€”I did not run away from my wifeâ€”I enlisted in the militia at Hampsteadâ€”I was in the army thirteen monthsâ€”I cannot say positively how long I have known the prisoner, but some yearâ€”I cannot say whether he has always borne that nameâ€”I cannot say whether I saw him in May last, as I very seldom go over thereâ€”I light gas in Euston-road and Osnaburgh-street, and round in that districtâ€”we commence at a quarter-past 3 and finish at half-past 4â€”I have been over to Oakley-street times out of number, because my sister lives in Thomasâ€”street and I go to see herâ€”she does not go to the public-house in Oakley-streetâ€”when I met my brother-in-law I said, "is Margaret at home?" he said, "No; she has gone down to my club, and as site is not at home, we will go up to the corner and have a drop, and wait for her to come inâ€”his name is James Dixonâ€”I do not think he is hereâ€”I do not know whether the house has any signâ€”I do not know how far Oakley street is from the Blackfriars-roadâ€”I always go by Waterloo-bridge or Westminster-road, and sometimes I take the twopenny 'busâ€”I do not know where the Blackfriars-road it, but I could find outâ€”I have never been tried in this Court or in a police-courtâ€”I have been fifteen years employed in the Enfield Gas Companyâ€”I was obliged to give it up when I was in the militia, but my superintendents reinstated me, and I am in their employment nowâ€”when I was in the public-house, I was in the front barâ€”I was there from 6 till

9â€”I sat down sometimesâ€”we were smoking and drinkingâ€”my brother-in-law was there, and a man named Mosely, who left to go to the Exhibitionâ€”he paid for some stoutâ€”Mrquote Carthy was not thereâ€”I never saw him before, to my recollectionâ€”this is the first time I have ever seen him in my lifeâ€”I spent a shillingâ€”Quebeck paid for a pot of stout, and my. brother-in-law paid for several dropsâ€”I had seen Quebeck three months before this in the New-cut on a Sunday morningâ€”I did not go to his house in Oakley-street thenâ€”he said he was very sorry the public-house was not openâ€”I knew him by the name of "John"â€”I did know his surname before to-dayâ€”I always called him "Jack," and he called me "Bill"â€”I made his acquaint
ance in Lambeth, being with my brother-in-law, and I bought a waistcoat of him very cheap one night, and paid him half-a-crown for itâ€”he is a tailor, and makes waistcoats out of old clothes.

COURT. Q. When did you hear that he was in custody? A. Next day a party told me that Jack the tailor was in custodyâ€”it was a man who drinks in my brother-in-law's companyâ€”he said, "Jack the tailor is taken and locked up"â€”I said, "What for? I"â€”he said, For passing a bad shilling or something"â€”I said, "I was drinking with him last night"â€”he said, "It was last night he was taken"â€”I did go before the Magistrateâ€”I did not take any notice till my brother-in-law told me he was fully committed for trial, and I said, "I will go and see him"â€”I went and saw him, and came hereâ€”he told me that he was locked up wrongfullyâ€”I said, "It is a great pity for anybody to be locked up innocently"â€”he said, "The person that locked me up swears I was in the house at half-past 8"â€”I said, "How could you be there and in my company tooâ€”he said, "Will you be so kind as to get your lighting done and come down for me?" and so I did; I have sent a porter to do my lighting for me, and have come here.

JURY to ANN ABBOTT. Q. You swear that this man gave the half-crown, and not the other?A. Yes, he dropped it from amongst some coppers which he had, he was leaning on the barâ€”I did not men
tion about receiving the half-crown till the other party came in, and did not mention it until then to any one but my daughterâ€”I spoke to her directly; I did not wish the father to knowâ€”from the time I took the half-crown to the time I mentioned it to my daughter, was about three minutesâ€”from the time I put the half-crown in the till to the time I took it out, nobody put any money in the till or had access to it.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

157.
HENRY SURMAN HAMMOND (39), Was indicted
for bigamy.

AUGUSTA WELOH . I am the wife of James Welch, of 14, Albert-squareâ€”I know the prisoner; I recollect his being married about eighteen years agoâ€”I was not presentâ€”my step-sister was bridesmaidâ€”she is deadâ€”the prisoner's wife is alive, I saw her this morningâ€”I know they lived together up to about twelve months ago.

Cross-examined by MR. WOOD. Q. When were they married. A. In 1842 or 1843-1 only know it from my step-Sister, who told me that she was bridesmaid; the gentleman who gave the bride away is also deadâ€”I know that they lived together during the time I mentionâ€”they visited me down to eighteen months agoâ€”I saw the prisoner about twelve months agoâ€”he always spoke of his wife in the highest manner.
JOHN SPINKS (Policeman, L 56). I took the prisoner on 5th December, at Portsea, on a warrant for deserting his wife and family, whereby they

became chargeable to the parish of Camberwellâ€” he said, "I have not deserted them; I sent them money at different times, I sent her a post-office order last Thursday for 10s.â€”I brought him to London, and he was examined in his wife's presenceâ€”I heard him say, that he was willing to take her home and live with her as he had done beforeâ€”I produce a certificate of the marriage from the register's office. (This certified the marriage of Henry Surman Hammond and Charlotte Welch, bachelor and spinster, by banns, in the year, 1843)â€”I also produce another certificate, (This certified the marriage of Henry Hammond and Annie Sanden, bachelor and widow, by banns, at Saint Gerogerquote s, Battersea, on 30th October, 1860.

THOMAS KIRK . I am clerk at Saint Georgerquote s, Batterseaâ€”I recollect the prisoner being married there on 30th October, 1860, to Annie Sandenâ€”I acted as clerkâ€”I have seen Charlotte Hammondâ€”she was not the person he was married to then.

p.hi: Submitted that the case not proved, as it was not shown who the person was, who was married according to the first certificate.
considered that there was a case for the jury, if only upon the prisoner's admission when he was charged with deserting his wife.

div1.p:
